div1.p: I.

pole/mou kai\ ma/xhs: Socrates and Chaerephon come just after Gorgias has finished his lecture. Callicles receives them with a jest, the point of which lies in the ou(/tw. In the double expression, the more general precedes, as is natural, the more definite.
metalagxa/nein: occurs also in Rep. 429 a with e)pisth/mhs, and Leg. 873 c with ai)sxu/nhs. It is rare.
to\ lego/menon: in appos. with the sentence. See G. 137, 3; H. 626 b.

kato/pin e(orth=s: proverbial, like post festum. This would call up to the Greek mind their public exhibitions, and the banquets with which they closed. Here is probably also an allusion to the extravagant enthusiasm which led the Athenians to designate as festivals those days on which Gorgias lectured. See Introd. § 4 end

kai\ ma/la g' a)stei/as: Hirschig remarks the frequency of such answers as these, which avoid the repetition of the last word of the preceding question. Cf. Theaet. 168 e a)ll' ou)/ toi sou= ge, w)= *qeo/dwre, a)/meinon, Crat. 391 b.

a)ttei/as: properly belonging to a city. It became an adj. of quality inasmuch as city festivals and celebrations are naturally superior to those of the country. It is used here in a good sense, though it may also mean “citified.”
e)pedei/cato: the aor. is necessitated by the time-limit (o)li/gon pro/teron).
o)li/gon pro/teron: the first word is an acc. of extent; the second is adverbial.
tou/twn: the pl. refers to the fact and its consequences.
o(/de: is deictic.

e)n a)gora=|: the omission of the art. shows that this was a phrase like ‘in town,’ ‘on change.’ By this time, a)gora/ had come in Athens to mean simply the exchange, or marketplace, where people assembled not for public debate (that was in the Pnyx), but for business. It was a favorite resort of Socrates, since there the concourse of people offered him the best opportunity for prosecuting his god-given vocation (cf. Introd. to Apol. § 25, and Apol. 33 a ff.). Cf. Xen. Mem. i. I. 10 a)lla\ mh\n e)kei=no/s ge a)ei\ me\n h)=n e)n tw=| fanerw=|: prwi/ te ga\r ei)s tou\s peripa/tous kai\ ta\ gumna/sia h)/|ei kai\ plhqou/shs a)gora=s e)kei= fanero\s h)=n, kte(.
a)nagka/sas: the literal meaning is not to be pressed. Chaerephon as the constant companion of Socrates took the liveliest interest in all his actions.
ou)de\n pra=gma: shows the asyndeton of ordinary conversation.—

e)gw\ ga\r kai\ i)a/somai: prob. contains some allusion to the story of Telephus, who when wounded by Achilles received from the oracle the assurance o( trw/sas (kai\) i)a/setai. The myth was made the subject of a noted tragedy by Euripides.
w(/ste e)pidei/cetai : w(/ste, when combined with the ind., can for all practical purposes be treated as if it were compounded of ou(/tws and te/. Cf. Lat. itaque. See on 458 d.

e)pidei/cetai: here used absolutely in the same sense as above. The fut. has two sides, one corresponding to each condition; thus it is equiv. to (1) e)qe/lei e)pidei/knusqai ei) dokei=, and (2) e)pidei/cetai e)a\n bou/lh|. Cf. a different case in 502 b, with note.
ti/ de/: the question shows that Chaerephon had not anticipated any great eagerness on Socrates' part.
e)p' au)to/: the pronoun is emphatic. See on 458 a. The emphasis is heightened by ge/.

o(/tan bou/lhsqe kte(.: contains an invitation, the basis of which is given by the clause with ga/r. The original conclusion of the condition was to be e)pidei/cetai, but in the course of the ga/r clause the speaker lost sight of this and continued with the co-ordinate construction.
par' e)me\ h(/kein oi)/kade: this shows that the speakers are neither in nor before the house of Callicles. On the place of meeting, see Introd. § 17.

e)qelh/seien a)/n: Socrates uses the opt. with a)/n a great deal, esp. when he first meets a person. It is the mood of courtesy, but not of argument. In this dialogue the opt. preponderates at the beginning, but the subjv. overtakes it in the argumentative passage 471, 472; while in the whole dialogue the proportion of subjs. to opt. is 3 to 2.
dialexqh=nai: emphasized in order to contrast Socrates' method with the e)pi/deicis of Gorgias.
du/namis (vis): i.e. the power and inner meaning of the art, with which the e)pa/ggelma should correspond,—the scope or compass.
e)pagge/lletai kte(.: cf. Apol. 33 b w(=n mh/te u(pesxo/mhn ma/qhma mh/te e)di/daca. e)pagge/llesqai is the regular word in Greek for ‘advertise,’ ‘profess.’

th\n de\ a)/llhn e)pi/deicin: it does not follow from this that Socrates considered the dialexqh=nai as a kind of e)pi/deicis. It is only an example of the idiomatic Greek usage of a)/llos, which does not include but excludes the word with which it is connected. Cf. 473 c politw=n kai\ a)/llwn ce/nwn, Apol. 36 b. See G. 142, 2, N. 3; H. 705. We must use a circumlocution, or another word, in English. In Cal licles' answer, however, the attributive force is regained.
w(/sper su\ le/geis: const. closely with ei)sau=qis, as referring to the invitation of Callicles to come to his home.

ou)de\n oi(=on to\ au)to\n e)rwta=n: there is nothing like asking the man himself. The articular infinitive is a favorite with Plato. He uses it most commonly in the acc. The nom. comes next in frequency, with the gen. a close third. The dat. is much less frequent. The pr. tense occurs nine times oftener than the aor., showing a great advance on Pindar. See Am. Jour. Phil. III. 193-201.

au)tw=|: on account of its meaning (“the master,” Kr. 51. 5, 4; H. 681 c) is placed in this emphatic position. On the matter itself see Introd. § 7, and the passage from Meno quoted Introd. N. 12. Auditors are present also at the following dialogue (cf. Introd. § 17 end).
e)ke/leue: imperf., because the same bidding or invitation was given to the different members of the group. He bade us all.
kalw=s le/geis: expresses more satisfaction than eu)= le/geis just before.
ti/ e)/rwmai: deliberative subjunctive.
o(/stis e)sti/n: o(/stis is regularly used to ask the question ‘who’ after a neg. (cf. 524 e, 526 b); but in all cases it may be used to express the idea of quality. See on 453 b.

w(/sper a)\n . . . a)pekri/nato a)/n: w(/sper a)\n ei) is phraseological, and the second a)/n comes in unconsciously with the conditional apodosis. The use of the aor. with a)/n in the apodosis, following an imperf. with ei) in the protasis, where both refer to the same sphere of time, is not uncommon. In Plato, according to GMT. 414, it appears to be confined to such phrases as ei)=pon a)/n, a)pekrina/mhn a)/n. But similar constructions with other verbs are found in Dem., Aristoph., Soph., Eur., Xen., etc. Cf. Dem. xix. 162, Ar. Eq. 507.
dhmiourgo/s: see on 452 a.

manqa/nw: one example suffices to make the idea of Socrates clear to Chaerephon; two are not enough for Polus. This is, however, due to the fact that Chaerephon is familiar with Socrates' methods, while they are new and strange to Polus.
a)pokri/nesqai kte(.: this is the ti/ of Socrates' question above in c. The tense shows that it is a general standing announcement.

h)= pou a)/ra kte(.: spoken in a wondering, admiring tone which expects an answer. “Surely, then, you must have but little difficulty in re-plying, Gorgias.” The irony lies in (the inferential) a)/ra as well as in r(a|di/ws. On the pushing nature and insolence of Polus, see Introd. § 14. What is said generally in Meno 70 b (see Introd. N. 12) of the pupils of Gorgias applies excellently to him.

e)mou=: by a very natural shift,
after tou/tou.—‘Gor. You may try the experiment if you please, Chaerephon. Pol. Yes, 'egad, and upon me too, if you like, Chaerephon.’ Cope.
kai\ a)peirhke/nai: gives the ground of Polus' offer. Possibly he may also wish to intimate that Gorgias may now fairly retire, and yield the field to another.
ti/ de\ toi=to: sc. diafe/rei. “What difference does this make?” Cf. 497 e. Polus does not wish to slight his master, but only to win admiration for himself.

(*hro/dikos: this brother of Gor gias (see Introd. § 4) must not be confounded with another physician of the same name who came from Selymbria (Rep. iii. 406 a, Phaedr. 227 d, Prot. 316 d), and was famed as the first to insist upon the value of gymnastics for health.

o(/per: after ti/na by an easy transfer to the actual idea,—‘name.’
Aristophon's brother was thecelebrated painter Polygnotus of Thasus.
Polus speaks as from a book— perhaps from his own book (462 b).
He overdoes the use of those figures, with which Gorgias also was accustomed to amuse himself, i.e. ‘paronomasia’ (kata\ te/xnhn . . . kata\ tu/xhn) and other phonetic figures in regard to the names of which theorists themselves were not at one. He uses the poetic ai)w=na instead of bi/on. His statements are indefinite and cloudy, and finally he brings forward a wholly general attribute—as Socrates proves in e by the distinction between poi/a and ti/s—of the matter in question, instead of its name. To speak of rhetoric as kalli/sth tw=n texnw=n is furthermore dialectically inappropriate, although it well agrees with the artistic design by drawing attention thus early to this idea. For other examples of similar mannerisms, see the speeches which go under the name of Gorgias (i.e. in the appendix to Blass' edition of Antiphon), and which, whether genuine or not, show admirably the peculiarities of the Gorgianic school.

pareskeua/sqai ei)s: equipped for. The phrase is a military one; hence lo/gous is almost equiv. to the later logomaxi/an, ‘disputation.’ The reference is to the readiness with which Polus begins his harangue.
ti/ ma/lista: how so, pray? To Gorgias' view the question has been well answered.

ou)k . . . a)lla/: the construction is colloquial. ou)k is to be translated no! The following clause with ge/ serves to give the reason for ou)k, “that is, if.” The negative color of the whole complex causes the speaker to ground his position by a)lla/ where one would more naturally find ga/r. It is not necessary to fill out the ellipsis with a)\n h(/dion se/ either in Greek or English.
dh=los ga/r moi: on the personal construction, see on 449 b.
diale/gesqai: the most unassuming name by which Socrates can characterize his practice, so completely the reverse of the commonly used rhetoric. The inf. is an acc. verbal noun.
w(/sper tino\s ye/gontos: equiv. to w(/sper a)\n ei)/ tis e)/yege.

u(petei/nato: cf. the Eng. use of ‘lay down a proposition or principle’ to serve as analogy for future guidance. Note the asyndeton which appears somewhat harsh, but is not uncommon in clauses with w(/sper. Cf. Alcib. I. 108 d ti/ ou)=n to\ kata\ tau/thn o)rqw=s gigno/meno/n e)stin; w(/sper e)kei= e)gw/ soi to\ kata\ th\n te/xnhn e)/legon o)rqw=s, th\n gumnastikh/n, kai\ su\ dh\ ou)=n ou(/tws e)ntau=qa ti/ fh/|s;

Socrates accepts tentatively the statement which has been so continually advanced, that r(htorikh/ is a species of art, in order to proceed with the discussion. The correctness of this statement is brought under question later.

a)gaqo/n ge: the self-satisfaction of Gorgias is so great that he speaks like a Homeric hero. Note the condescension (perhaps unconscious) in the following ka/lei dh/ (you may call me so, then), of which, however, Socrates takes no notice.
ei) dh/: if . . . really.
a)/lloqi: on these travels, see Introd. § 5. The vagueness of the adverb stamps the whole statement as somewhat boastful.

to\ de\ mh=kos tw=n lo/gwn: Socrates does not mean that the answers should be restricted to a certain length; but he wishes to exclude those answers which, instead of keeping strictly to the question under discussion, branch off and lose themselves in different trains of thought. By using kai/ before *pw=los, Socrates gives us to understand that he fears something similar from Gorgias.
ei)sau=qis a)poqe/sqai: put off till another time.
o(/per u(pisxnei=: with reference to 447 e.

ei)si\n kte(.: though Gorgias speaks like a master, with the air of authority, he would still like to leave a way of escape open for himself, —which unfortunately his boastful e)pa/ggelma has rendered impossible, although he had not yet distinctly promised to speak with brevity.

a)nagkai=ai . . . polei=sqai: the personal construction proceeds from the ‘prolepsis’ of the subject of the inf.,—a common occurrence with di/kaios and dh=los. The real subject of the infinitive is then e)ni/as tw=n a)pokri/sewn. Of this construction Plato affords other examples. Cf. Meno 79 d a)po/krisin th\n dia\ tw=n e)/ti zhtoume/nwn . . . e)pixeirou=san a)pokri/nesqai, Phaedo 92 d toi=s dia\ tw=n ei)ko/twn ta\s a)podei/ceis poioume/nois lo/gois. In translation the adj. must be made neuter, or a circumlocution must be used. “There are certain answers in which it is necessary for one to deliver himself more at length.” See H. 944 a; Rid. § 230.

dia\ braxuta/twn: simply a circumlocution for the superlative adv., and accordingly const. with w(s acc. to the usual rule. Kr. 49, 10, 1; H. 651 a. In the next sent., e)n seems to have much the same force as dia/ here.

mhde/na a)\n . . . ei)pei=n: the use of mh/ here is not to be considered as due
to indir. disc. which would require ou), but as being in an inf. clause which is in apposition with e(/n.
r(htorikh=s ga\r kte(.: ga/r introduces the reason for the question which is announced in the challenging phrase, fe/re dh/. Hence the position of the causal clause.

peri\ ti/: ‘peri/ with acc., ordinarily of action; peri/ with gen., ordinarily of thought or speech; but thought or speech may be considered as action, and shifts are not uncommon.’ B.L.G. Cf. peri\ th=s r(htorikh=s below (12).

nh\ th
 (/*hran: Socrates rarely uses the same oath twice in the same dialogue. Cf. nh\ to
 ku/na 466 c, ma\ to
—;466 e, *di/) 470 e, 516 d, to
 ku/na to
 *ai)gupti/wn qeo/n 482 b, to
 *zh=qon 489 e. See on 463 d.
o(/ti a)pokri/nh|: the explanatory clause freq. borders on the causal, as here.

pa/nu e)pieikw=s: fairly well. In this self-laudation, Gorgias has in view only the form of his answers without reference to their connexion with the subject-matter. He only wants to show that he is a master of brachylogy, and therefore answers in the shortest formulae of affirmation and negation.
e)pisth/mh: not really different from te/xnh, inasmuch as the orator is e)pisth/mwn r(htorikh=s te/xnhs.
poi/ous tou/tous: the acc. instead of the nom. on account of the proximity of lo/gous. The const. of the previous clause is continued.
tou\s ka/mnontas: an example of one of the most common kinds of anticipation, where the subj. of the dependent sent. is drawn forward under the government of the leading verb.

ou)k a)/ra peri\ pa/ntas kte(.: accordingly the definition of Gorgias is too wide. Cf. Prot. 312 d i)/sws a)/n, h)=n d' e)gw/, a)lhqh= le/goimen, ou) me/ntoi i(kanw=s ge: e)rwth/sews ga\r e)/ti h( a)po/krisis h(mi=n dei=tai peri\ o(/tou o( sofisth\s deino\n poiei= le/gein.

ou)kou=n peri\ w(=nper le/gein, kai\ fronei=n: sc. poiei= dunatou\s with each clause. Apparently Socrates makes no immediate use of this point, so that it might appear unnecessary. But by contrasting thought with speech he thus at the beginning of the discussion emphasizes the importance of the contents as opposed to the form, a distinction on which he subsequently bases his refutation of Gorgias.
dunatou\s ei)=nai (sc. poiei= from 449 e): on the difference between a)=ra and a)=ra ou), where an affirmative answer is expected, see on 479 c.
eu)eci/an te . . . kai\ kaxeci/an: opposites are regularly connected by te . . . kai/.
e(ka/sth: when the second clause explains the first, the asyndeton is but little felt.
h( te/xnh: const., in spite of the article, not with e(ka/sth, but with ou(=. This is the pred. while e(ka/sth is sub-ject. “Of which each (art) is the art.”
h(\ a)\n h)=: the indef. rel. sentence is necessary, owing to the very general character of Gorgias' statements hitherto.
tau/thn: as referring to h(\ a)\n h)=| is also indefinite. “If this you call rhetoric—any art which has to do with discourses.”

w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n: this phrase occurs in Plato 77 times (GMT. 777, 1). The w(s is not to be considered as final, as in the Eng. ‘so to speak,’ but is rather comparative, in the meaning ‘in a word,’ though it is often convenient to translate by ‘so to speak.’ It is closely connected with the following pa=sa, as in 456 a with a(pa/sas, 450 d with ou)deno/s, Phaedo 78 e with ou)damw=s. Cf. Kr. 55, 1, 2. Its force is shown by its opposition to a)kribei= lo/gw| in Rep. i. 341 b pote/rws le/geis to
 a)/rxonta, to
 w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n h)\ to
 a)kribei= lo/gw|, and its employment here shows the inability of Gorgias to give a clear and sharp definition of his art.

ku/rwsis: accomplishment, consequently effect, power. This unusual word, which Thucydides vi. 103 uses in the meaning decision, resolution, determination, is replaced below in e by the equally unusual ku=ros. More common is the verb kurou=n confirm and kurou=sqai bring to pass, 451 b, c. Cf. also a)/kuros void, inoperative, Crito 50 b, Prot. 356 d.
o)rqw=s le/gwn w(s e)gw/ fhmi: this addition is also characteristic of his self-confidence.

a)=r' ou)=n manqa/nw kte(.: this question is put without any expecta
tion of an answer. oi(/an is used, and not ti/na, because there is no inquiry after the name of the art (which for the moment is considered satisfactory), but after its nature or kind, which must now be more clearly defined. In the following methodical discussion Socrates makes clear what was present, but in a confused form, in Gorgias' mind. The question now is as to the means of the ku/rwsis. The ground of distinction is formed by the contrast so familiar to the Greeks between lo/gos and e)/rgon (le/gein and pra/ttein). Cf. Apol. 32 a.

tw=n me/n: in part. apposition with pasw=n. See H. 624 d. The correlative is e(/terai de/ (12), while e)/niai de/ is to be connected with de/ontai as one division of the tw=n me/n, and as correlative with the implied subject (ai( me/n) of de/ontai. Below we find h)\ . . . h)/ instead.
to\ th=s texnh/s: the business, function of the art. See H. 730 b.
ou) fh/s: on the adhaerescent ou) see GMT. 384; H. 1028.

h( a)riqmhtikh\ kai\ logistikh/: arithmetic is the theoretical science of numbers; logistic, the practical art of reckoning. See the following chapter. On the omission of the article, see Kr. 58, 2, 1; H. 660 a; and note on 469 d.

petteutikh/: seems to be a general name for various games which were played on a board with pieces, whether dice or checkers. The addition of ge/ indicates that the member of the series is not usually classed with the others; cf. Crito 47 b tau/th| a)/ra au)tw=| prakte/on kai\ lumnaste/on kai\ e)deste/on ge kai\ pote/on kte(.
au)tai=s . . . e)sti/n: cf. below in e h( dia\ lo/gou to\ ku=ros e)/xousa.
ou)x o(/ti: not but that, although.
tw=| r(h/mati: as far as actual words are concerned; “but you could not have earnestly meant it.”
u(pola/boi a)/n tis: regular formula for introducing an objection; cf. Apol. 20 c. The opt. is potential.—

dusxerai/nein: in the proper sense of dusxerh/s, treat harshly, i.e. to make difficulties. Cf. 483 a kakourgei=s e)n toi=s lo/gois. Remark the delicate irony of the words a)ll' ou)k kte(., which consists in this, that Socrates apparently passes very gently over the contradiction which exists between the words and the actual meaning of the teacher of oratory.

o)rqw=s ga\r oi)/ei: acknowledges and accepts the suggestion made by Socrates. Note the oratorical swing in the addition of dikai/ws u(polamba/- neis, which serves also to preserve the dignity of the master who is ever ready to encourage good work in the pupil.
i)/qi: is simply an encouraging interjection like fe/re dh/ 449 c.—
kai\ su/: acknowledges the courtesy of Gorgias' preceding words.

th
 a)po/krisin h(
 h)ro/mhn: is brachylogic for th
 a)po/krisin tou= e)rwth/matos o(\ h)ro/mhn.

diaperai/nein: denotes the suitable conclusion which Gorgias ought to make to his answer, by establishing some distinction characteristic of rhetoric. Socrates assumes then a little ironically that this object has already been almost attained. Since, however, he wishes in what follows to make clear that two or more arts can belong to the same species and yet be entirely distinct from one an
other, it is necessary for him to give and compare several examples.
w(=n nu=n dh\ e)/legon: logically follows texnw=n.

tw=n peri\ ti/: the sentence would be correctly filled out thus: tw=n peri\ ti/ dia\ lo/gou to\ ku=ros e)xousw=n. The use of tw=n, both here and in the following answer, shows that the inquiry is directed to the function of a class. On the other hand h( peri\ ti/; just below inquires after the function of the individual art. As an example of Plato's poikili/a, notice the variety in the expressions e)n lo/gois to\ ku=ros e)/xousa, dia\ lo/gwn to\ ku=ros e)/xousa and lo/gw| kuroume/nwn.
o(/sa a)\n tugxa/nh|: however great each happen to be, i.e. to any magnitude you please.

w(/sper oi( e)n dh/mw| suggrafo/menoi. Socrates refers to those who bring forward motions in the assembly of the people or have them recorded by the grammateu/s to be then communicated to the assembly, at the command of the president, by the herald. If there was a previous motion either of the senate or an orator on the same subject before the body, instead of recording and reading the common preamble of both motions, the words ta\ me\n a)/lla kaqa/per h( boulh/ (or whatever the name of the proposer was) were employed, followed by the modification or amendment. This corresponds in a general way to our ‘amend after the words,’ etc.

pro\s au(ta\ kai\ pro\s a)/llhla kte(.: ‘the relative as well as the absolute properties.’ Cope. The reckoning can only be made with odd and even numbers; hence pro\s au(ta/ means even to even, etc.; pro\s a)/llhla, even to odd, etc. The definition of logistikh/ runs thus in Charmides 166 a h( logistikh/ e)sti/ pou tou= a)rti/ou kai\ perittou= e)pisth/mh, plh/qous o(/pws e)/xei pro\s au(ta\ kai\ pro\s a)/llhla. The pl. must be construed according to the sense, not the form.

a)ne/roito: sc. ti/s e)stin, the subject of which is given in the proleptic accusative. Cf. Prot. 351 e th
 h(donh
 au)th
 e)rwtw=n ei) ou)k a)gaqo/n e)stin.
i)/qi su/: the rest of the sentence is to be supplied from the preceding words of Gorgias. The clause with ga/r gives the basis of the following question. Cf. 449 c, d.
peri\ ou(=: according to analogy we should expect peri\ o(/. But cf. a similar shift in 453 b and e with peiqw/. See also 491 a and note on 449 d.
ta\ me/gista. Gorgias, like Polus, finds it extremely hard to come out of the rut into which he has fallen, and give a scientific definition of his art.

VII. The scolion was a peculiar kind of drinking-songs, paroi/nia, sung at banquets. The one here alluded to is mentioned by Plato in Euthyd. 279 a, Phileb. 48 d, Legg. 631 c, 661 a. It probably was composed by Simonides, although according to some it was by Epicharmus. After Bergk's (Poet. Lyr. Gr. iii.^{4} 645) rhythmical changes the words acc. to the Scholiast read as follows:
*(ugiai/nein me
 a)/riston a)ndri\ qnatw=|, deu/teron de\ fua
 kalo
 gene/sqai, to\ tri/ton de\ ploutei=n a)do/lws, kai\ to\ te/tarton h(ba=n meta\ tw=n fi/lwn.
The last line of the scolion is omitted by Socrates, because, for his argument, only those advantages can be cited which involve the practice of some art.
katariqmou=ntai: the advantages are arranged according to their value in the enumeration. Instead of an object the clause with o(/ti follows, introducing the dir. discourse.

dhmiourgoi/: the word is found as early as Homer and denotes all who carry on a business which is public and useful to the people; as, physicians, soothsayers, singers, goldsmiths. Later, the expression was extended to free manual laborers, without, however, losing any of its respectability. Hence it corresponds to our use of the word ‘master’ (master-workman, master-mason). Cf. 455 b. It is noteworthy that only such things are enumerated as, like the assumed result of rhetoric, were reckoned among external advantages; for rhetoric, according to the view of Gorgias, should procure in the state either high office or honors. Hence the scolion is very applicable. Socrates brings forward the physician, the bodytrainer, and the banker, in order to contrast with the subjective judgment of Gorgias the subjective opinions of others, and thus to show the subjectivity of the answer.

paidotri/bhs: the body-trainer for boys taught in the gymnastic schools (palai=strai). He is often confounded with the gumnasth/s, whose proper office was the scientific treatment of the whole subject of bodily exercises, and whose field was the public gumna/sia, where he instructed grown men in general and also those who were training for the games (a)qlhtai/). Both the paidotri/bhs and the lumnasth/s are often mentioned alongside of the physician, since the nurture and care of the body was their common aim. Cf. Crito 47 b.
ei)/poi prw=ton: the a)/n before parastai=en is felt as extending over the whole sentence.

u(gi/eia: if the word is sound, it must be taken as an absolute addition to the proper question which ends with w)= *sw/krates. The diffuse
ness of the whole passage favors the view that the construction must not be rigidly pressed here.
ta)/n: for toi a)/n, as we frequently find menta)/n for me/ntoi a)/n. Cf. Apol. 29 a deino\n ta)\n ei)/h.

kai\ au)to/s: like et ipse, “likewise,” while recognizing the claims of the physician, shows also a consciousness of his own importance as compared with Gorgias. This calls forth in the reply the address w)= a)/nqrwpe, which indicates some degree of contempt and surprise.
The very mode of speaking declares the pride of wealth.
dh=ta: with the imv. makes the claim for recognition more urgent than the sim ple dh/. Kr. 69, 20; H. 1037, 6.—

e)a/n: whether, introducing the indir. question. But Goodwin (GMT. 493, 680) denies that e)a/n can ever mean ‘whether,’ insisting that every expression like the present is conditional. The side-thrust at Gorgias is very appropriate, as he himself received much money from his teaching and lived magnificently upon it.
a)mfisbhtei=: affirms (in contradiction of his opponent), “disputes this and says.”
to\ meta\ tou=to: adverbial acc. H. 600 a; 719 b.
au)tou=: shift from the rel. to the leading clause. G. 156; H. 1005.

au)toi=s toi=s a)nqrw/pois: the pronoun emphasizes personal freedom as opposed to power over others. In thus stating the aim and purpose of all the sophists' efforts, Gorgias (acc. to Plato) fails completely to notice the mutual contradiction of the two members.

tou= a)/llwn a)/rxein: Heindorf desires tw=n a)/llwn, which would better accord with the ordinary usage. Still the indefiniteness of the expression may not be without object in showing the inexactness of thought which naturally prevailed at a time when the art of speaking was just being brought within the reach of all.
Construe e)/gwge (le/gw) to\ oi(=o/n te ei)=nai pei/qein kte(.
oi(=o/n te: expresses ‘position,’ oi(=os ‘disposition.’ Gildersleeve, Am. Jour. Phil. vii. 165.

kai\ e)n a)/llw| cullo/gw| (sc. tw=n politw=n): is paraphrased with a limitation in the following clause. In this division of the various kinds of bodies in which the orator would have occasion to display his powers we see the basis of the three chief varieties of oratory (ge/nh, genera) which are generally recognized by later critics. The first, to\ dhmhgoriko/n (sumbouleutiko/n, deliberativum), was employed e)/n te toi=s bouleuthri/ois kai\ tai=s e)kklhsi/ais. The second, to\ dikaniko/n (iudiciale), was employed e)n toi=s dikasthri/ois. The germ of the third, to\ e)pideiktiko/n, which was not distinguished by Anaximenes, can be discerned in the words kai\ e)n a)/llw| cullo/lw| kte(. This last was first defined by Aristotle, who used as the basis of his division the oratorical characteristics of the several varieties, not the place of their delivery, as Gorgias does here.
e)n duna/mei kte(.: “the possession of this power will involve the servitude of the physician,” etc.

dou=lon. This expression seems to be Gorgias' own, as is to be gathered from the passage in Philebus 58 a, cited by Heindorf. Protarchus says there: h)/kouon me\n e)/gwge, w)= *sw/krates, e(ka/stote *gorgi/ou polla/kis, w(s h( tou= pei/qein (du/namis) polu\ diafe/roi pasw=n texnw=n: pa/nta ga\r u(f' au(th=|
dou=la di) e(ko/ntwn a)ll' ou) dia\ bi/as poioi=to, kai\ makrw=| a)ri/sth pasw=n ei)/h tw=n texnw=n.—The Gorgianic balancing dou=lon me\n . . . dou=lon de/ gives a certain dignity to the words.

ou(=tos: is scornful, as in Crito 45 a.—The thought is expressed first positively, then negatively, then again (by a kind of apostrophe—since soi/ cannot be considered as addressed to Socrates) positively. Gorgias cannot refrain from again declaring more distinctly what he has already indicated by a)/llw|. Cf. 464 c h( kolakeutikh\ ai)sqome/nh, ou) lnou=sa le/gw a)lla\ stoxasame/nh, where, however, the same device is of value in giving more clearness to the statement.
ta\ plh/qh: sc. in the different assemblies.
e)llu/tata: more definitely. The answer given comes nearer to being an answer indeed.
peiqou=s dhmiourgo\s h( r(htorikh/: this definition which Socrates has gathered from Gorgias' verbiage, was not invented by Plato, but was apparently well known in Athens at the time.
peiqou=s: to be understood in a passive sense, as peiqw\ poiei=n below shows.
ei)s tou=to teleuta=|: instead of the regular ei)s, occasionally e)n and pro/s are used with but little difference of meaning.

ti\: is not the object of le/gein, but is probably to be construed with e)/xein somewhat as follows, have you any reason to say. The object of le/gein is contained in the following e)pi\ ple/on . . . du/nasqai (“its power extends further than”), with which indeed Hirschig construes ti\.

eu)= i)/sq' o(/ti: is occasionally found construed with the inf. like an ordinary verb of perception, even in cases where there is no intervening clause as here to attract a following inf. Cf. Xen. Hell. ii. 2. 2 *au/sandros tou\s frourou\s . . . a)pe/pempen ei)s ta\s )*aqh/nas . . . ei)dw\s o(/ti o(/sw| a)\n plei/ous sullelw=sin ei)s to\ a)/stu, qa=tton tw=n e)pithdei/wn e)/ndeian e)/sesqai. Owing to the shift in the construction, e)lw/ is left absolute at the beginning of the sentence.
ei)/per kte(.: the leading idea of the pred. lies in the participle.
ti/ ou)=n dh/: inquires what is to follow from the admission of the statement.
th\n peiqw/: proleptic.

h(/tis pot' e)stin: but h(\n oi)=mai is used below, according to the rule that o(/stis is required after a negative, while it may occur—though o(/s is regular—with a positive. Cf. 447 d, and see Morris on Thuc. i. 136. 4.—
h(\n su\ le/geis: indispensable addition to h(/tis. On peri\ w(=ntinwn, see on 451 d.
tou= e(/neka dh/: an example of the ‘rhetorical question’ which Demosthenes uses to great advantage. Rid. § 325 cites also from Gorgias 457 e, 458 a, 487 b.

ou) sou= e(/neka: in this answer we have merely an indefinite contrast between person and thing; which is much more clearly defined below in 457 d kata\ fqo/non oi)/ontai to\n e(autw=n le/gein and e ou) pro\s to\ pra=gma filonikou=nta le/gein . . . a)lla\ pro\s se/. Socrates guards himself against any suspicion that he may be influenced by personal feelings in his criticism of Gorgias. Cf. 454 c.
w(s: not to be joined with ma/lista as a superlative phrase, but correlative with ou(/tw.

w(/sper a)\n ei): introduces frequently, as an illustration of a general principle, a supposed case similar to it. It is easy to add a second hypothetical clause, not coördinated with the first, but which, combined with the apod., has the first as a common protasis. Cf. below, 468 d, and Apol. 27 d.
Zeuxis, the celebrated painter and contemporary of Socrates, was a native of Heraclea in Lower Italy. He was the pupil of Apollodorus,
who, by a more delicate appreciation and application of the principles of light and shade in painting, greatly furthered the development of the art, and obtained for himself the surname of ‘Sciagraph.’ The paintings of Zeuxis, who belonged to the Ionic school, were noted for their delicacy and fine coloring. Besides the Helena which he painted for the Crotoniates (Cic. de Inv. ii. 1. 1), his most celebrated picture was the Penelope, wherein he depicted with great success pure matronly modesty. The story of his contest with his rival Parrhasius is well known.
zw=|a: a general expression for every kind of pictures.

kai\ pou=: Socrates wishes here to make clear that if we wish to define an object exactly, i.e. so as to make it easily recognizable, it is not sufficient to give the characteristic which it has in common with other objects, but rather it is necessary to mention that characteristic which belongs to it alone and distinguishes it from all other objects. So, for example, it is not sufficient to say that Zeuxis is a painter, i.e. one who either paints or has painted pictures; but in order to distinguish him from other painters, who also paint or have painted pictures, we must state more nearly the kind of pictures which he has painted (poi=a), as ‘he who painted the Helena or the Penelope.’ But even this is not entirely sufficient, for there are still other painters who have painted these same objects; but when we say, ‘he who painted the Helena in Croton (pou=),’ we have definitely defined Zeuxis. pou= could also, and more naturally, refer to the scene of his labors,—where he had his studio. We must note (1) that o( ta\ zw=|a gra/fwn is only the common designation of all painters, by which they are distinguished from the lo/gous or no/mous or suggra/mmata gra/fontes, (2) that o( gra/fwn can and must be understood in the same way in which we so often understand o( a)dikw=n, o( kratw=n, etc., i.e. as a generic word, not limited in time (H. 827), (3) that poi=os is often scarcely to be distinguished from ti/s (cf. Xen. Anab. iii. 1. 14 e)gw\ ou)=n to
 e)k poi/as po/lews strathgo
 prosdokw= tau=ta pra/cein; poi/an d' h(liki/an e)mautw=| e)lqei=n a)name/nw;). With these points understood, we see that the present example suffices to show that to define rhetoric as peiqou=s dhmiourgo/s, i.e. h( th
 peiqw\ a)pergazome/nh te/xnh is insufficient, so long as the peiqw/ wrought by it is not more exactly specified in order to distinguish it from that wrought by other arts which come under the same general definition. Cf. moreover the answer of Gorgias, below, 454 b, which corresponds to the example before us exactly, even as far as the pou= is concerned.
e)/grafe: were a painter.
ou) dh=ta (sc. ou) pei/qei)

a)lla\ kte(.: chiastic with the question preceding. The affirmative of the first member of the question is made much more emphatic by the previous express denial of the second member, which must therefore itself be emphatically uttered. Usually the answer does not follow so closely the words of the question; cf. below, 501 c, and Parm. 128 a ou(/tw le/geis h)\ e)gw\ ou)k o)rqw=s katamanqa/nw; *ou)/k, a)lla\ kalw=s sunh=kas o(/lon to\ gramma o(\ bou/letai. Different, however, are 454 a, b, and 496 d, below. Cf. Rid. § 305.
w(=nper: on the omission of the prep. see Kr. 51, 11, 1; H. 1007. Cf. below, 517 c e)n panti\ tw=| xro/nw| o(\n dielego/meqa, Apol. 27 d. So in Lat., i.e. Nep. Cim. 3.
ta\ tou= a)riqmou=: the properties of number. Cf. ta\ th=s yu/xhs, ta\ tou= bi/ou. See on 450 c.

to\ peritto/n: in such combinations the article is usually omitted with the second member, and only inserted when the two members are to be looked upon as more distinct. Cf. above, 451 b with c, and 454 e, 455 a; see Kr. 58, 2, 1.

o(/son: sing. because each antecedent is of equal value.
Neither o(/son e)sti/n, nor o(/sa e)sti/n, above, conflict with the passage 451 b, c.
poi/as peiqou=s kai\ th=s peri\ ti/: cf. above, poi/as peiqou=s kai\ peri\ ti/.

te/xnh: no one need be disturbed by the substitution of te/xnh for dhmiourgo/s, as the two words have kindred ideas. There is also no appreciable difference between poi/as here and h(=stinos a few lines above. Cf. 453 e, and see on 453 c.
e)/moige: the form of the question shows that an affirmative answer is expected.

tau/ths: draws attention to the earlier explanation in 452 e, from which is drawn (toi/nun) the following definition, which in form follows as an epexegesis to tau/ths th=s peiqou=s. The definition answers the poi=on as far as the external matters of persons (speakers) and place are concerned, and is used by Socrates (c) in order to obtain a definition that characterizes the nature of the peiqw/. Gorgias does not use o)/xlois with the disparaging feeling which it sometimes has, but as a general word for assemblies.
peri\ tou/twn kte(.: answers the question peri\ ti/ 4, above. On the change of case, cf. 449 d.

a)ll' i(/na kte(.: this sentence is a good example of those curious anacolutha which occur so often in the conversation of ordinary life, where a slight emphasis on a single word may perhaps change the whole construction, and cause the speaker to lose
himself in a network of clauses, of which, while the idea is clear enough, the grammatical construction is hopeless. The idea here is this: “I thought you meant that, but still I asked; and you must not be surprised if I again ask something which seems to be evident enough; for it is absolutely essential for our argument that we proceed upon definitely expressed statements, and not upon mere suspicions, which may prove to be misunderstandings.” In the construction the speaker proceeds well enough until he is thrown off the track by e)gw\ d' e)panerwtw=. The use of this seemingly independent clause (it is really, together with dokei= me/n, in dependence on o(/) causes him to branch off, in the clause o(/per ga\r le/gw, in order to explain the reason for his repeated questioning, and at the same time to reiterate one of the fundamental principles of dialectic.
o(/per ga\r le/gw: refers to 453 b.
u(ponoei=n: “to form a pre-opin
ion of what another is likely to think on a subject without his having expressed himself,” to impute to him certain views, and thereby to forestall his explaining himself.
u(po/qesin: is a plan or principle which Gorgias has laid down for himself, and which conditions the direction in which (kata/) the thesis is to be developed until the end is reached (perai/nhs).
i)/qi dh\ kte(.: see on tau/ths, in b, above.
kalw=s ga\r oi)/ei: see on 451 a. Note the difference in tone of Gorgias' answer, as compared with 450 c.
fai/hs a)/n: has the force of an affirmative. You would say ‘yes’; so ou)/ fhmi often means I say ‘no’, I deny. See Kr. 64, 5, 4.

e)pisth/mh: from e)pi/stasqai to understand, i.e. properly, correct understanding, knowledge. This takes the place of ma/qhsis, which strictly denotes the process of learning, whose result is e)pisth/mh, because this idea better suits the above opposition between memaqhke/nai and pepisteuke/nai.
dh=lon ga\r au)=: confirms the distinctness of the two ideas which Socrates had already affirmed much more positively than Gorgias.

pepeisme/noi: so far as the inward conviction is concerned, ma/qhsis and pi/stis agree; objectively, how ever, they are very different, for ma/qhsis involves the acquisition of knowl-edge, while ignorance is the necessary concomitant of pi/stis.

bou/lei ou)=n kte(.: Socrates now proceeds to analyze (diai/resis, divisio) the general definition in order to obtain that special definition (o(rismo/s, definitio) which, according to the requirements of logic, must include, together with the statement of genus (to\ ge/nos, genus proximum) also the addition of the characteristic (diafora\ ei)dopoio/s, differentia specifica) which separates it from other species of the same genus.

h( r(htorikh\ kte(.: the first definition which had its origin in the technic of the rhetorical schools (see on 453 a) has now acquired a more exact and complete expression by the help of this dialectical investigation. Note the change from peri\ tw=n dikai/wn to peri\ to\ di/kaion. Cf. 454 b, e.

peistiko/s: able to persuade. Equiv. to i(kano\s pei/qein, as didaskaliko/s to didaskali/an pare/xwn or i(kano\s dida/skein. Neither this nor pisteutiko/s used above can properly be construed with the genitive. With didaskaliko/s, however, we find examples, as Euthyph. 3 c *)aqhnai/ois ou) sfo/dra me/lei, a)/n tina deino\n oi)/wntai ei)=nai mh\ me/ntoi didaskaliko\n th=s au(tou= sofi/as. See Kr. 47, 26, 9; H. 754, b. In the addition of mo/non lies a gentle intimation of some defect, the result of which for the estimation of rhetoric appears more plainly later.

e)n o)li/gw| xro/nw|: draws attention to a great defect of the Athenian judicial system. It was often impossible to present before the court a clear exposition of the points at issue, as the speeches were limited to a certain length, which was carefully measured by the kle/yudra,—a practice which Socrates also complains of in Apol. 19 a e)pixeirhte/on u(mw=n e)cele/sqai th
 diabolh
 h(
 u(mei=s e)n pollw=| xro/nw| e)/sxete, tau/thn e)n ou(/tws o)li/gw| xro/nw|, and 37 a u(ma=s tou=to ou) pei/qw: o)li/gon ga xro/non dieile/gmeqa.

fe/re dh\ kte(.: introduces a new discussion designed to test the definition just obtained, which, although from the point of view of form it satisfies excellently the double requirement made above in 454 a, still leaves some uncertainty as to the exact meaning of Gorgias. Hence the question, ‘What do we really mean thereby?’ Socrates professes to be not yet quite certain himself (ou)d' au)to/s), notwithstanding that he has contributed the most to the more close definition of the poi=on. His doubts are directed especially to the peri\ ti/ as it has been just defined according to the specifications made by Gorgias. This discussion forms the transition to the examination of the true value and ethical tendency
of rhetoric. On the use of kai/ in questions, cf. Xen. Hell. iii. 3. 11 te/los au)to\n (to\n *kina/dwna) h)/ronto (oi( e)/foroi) ti/ kai\ boulo/menos tau=ta pra/ttoi, what purpose he actually had in so doing.
o(/tan peri\ kte(.: on the whole passage, cf. Prot. 319 b.

i)atrw=n ai(re/sews: during the rise of philosophy in Greece, a science of medicine also gradually developed, which became hereditary among the priests of Aesculapius. Among these various schools arose; as in Cos, Cnidus, Rhodes, and in several cities of Magna Graecia. After a while it became customary for a state to take a noted physician into the public service; as Democedes, who was hired one year by the Aeginetans, the second by the Athenians, and the third by Polycrates of Samos (Hdt. iii. 131).

e)/qnous (from the same root as e)/qos, ei)/wqa): denotes a class of people drawn into association either for the purposes of habitation or from force of custom (calling, trade). For dhmiourgoi/ see on 452 a. In such formulae as a)/llo ti h)/ and ou)de\n a)/llo h)/ the copula is frequently omitted. See H. 1015 b.
ou)d' o(/tan: is in close connexion with a)/llo ti h)\ to/te o( r(htoriko\s ou) sumbouleu/sei.
h)\ pw=s le/geis kte(.: intimates that possibly Gorgias will not accept this limitation of rhetoric.
eu)= e)/xei: it is proper, it is in order. Cf. Phaedo 107 a ei) dh/ ti *simmi/as . . . e)/xei le/gein, eu)= e)/xei mh\ katasigh=sai.—
ta\ (not to\)
th=s te/xnhs: because the question is no longer as to the nature of the art, but as to its claims and effects, one by one.
to\ so\n speu/dein: consult your interest.

tina\s sxedo\n kai\ suxnou/s: Cron would take this in its entirety as almost
equivalent to “quite a number”; but it seems better to give each word its rights, some, I had almost said many. In Phaedo 58 d parh=sa/n tines kai\ polloi/ ge, we have almost the reverse of the present case; that is, the higher estimate is asserted, while in the present passage it is denied. The hope of obtaining pupils is the greatest spur to the Sophist to continue a discussion which cannot but be unpleasant to him. It serves also to draw out his true sentiments.

a)ll' e)gw\ kte(.: Gorgias allows himself to be led on by the examples which Socrates has brought forward, and which seem to him excellently adapted (hence kalw=s u(fhgh/sw) to make clear the efficacy of his art. He therefore tries to prove for it as great as possible a scope, and thereby entirely loses sight of his former definition of the peri\ ti/.
ta\ de/: without a preceding ta\ me/n, to complete and correct the statement. See Kr. 50, 1, 12.

e)k tw=n dhmiourgw=n: “in accordance with the architects,” instead of the advice of the architects. Other striking examples of such compression are Prot. 358 c ou)d' e)/sti tou=to e)n a)nqrw/pou fu/sei, e)pi\ a(\ oi)/etai kaka\ ei)=nai e)qe/lein i)e/nai a)nti\ tw=n a)gaqw=n, Xen. Cyr. iii. 3. 41 xw/ran e)/xete ou)de\n h(=tton e)/ntimon tw=n prwtostatw=n for th=s tw=n prwtostatw=n.

le/getai tau=ta kte(.: this admission of Socrates seems to Gorgias to confirm his assumption, and to imply that Socrates was not in earnest in his opposition. At the death of Themistocles, Socrates was about four years old.
w(=n . . . e)/leges: sc. at 455 b. So

crates makes for the moment no ob
jection to Gorgias' course, thus stimulating him to the detailed statements which follow.
nikw=ntes ta\s gnw/mas: the verb nika=n is construed with various accusatives which belong to the ‘cognate’ class, as *)olumpia/da, pagkra/tion, yh/fisma, etc. G. 159 R.; H. 716 a.
pa/lai e)rwtw=: for the pres. with pa/lai, see H. 826; G. 200, n. 4, and cf. the similar Lat. use of jam diu with the present (Gildersleeve, Gr. § 221).
daimoni/a: has become by this time so weakened as to mean simply wonderful, extraordinary. Cf. the similar weakening of strong words in English; i.e. ‘awful.’

ti\s: by adding to the vagueness, enhances the vastness of the power, like the Lat. quidam. Cf. Cic. ad Fam. x. 12. 1 idque contigit meritorum tuorum in rem publicam eximia quadam magnitudine, owing to the rather exceptional greatness, etc.

ei) pa/nta ge ei)dei/hs: Socrates' object is finally attained, and Gorgias, lulled completely by this ironical expression of admiration, bursts forth into an eloquent laudation of his art, and a defence of it against all censure. The omission of the apodosis gives to the sentence the effect of an exclamation. Such a usage is also common in English.

a(pa/sas ta\s duna/meis: may be a compression of a(pasw=n tw=n texnw=n ta\s duna/meis. Of course sullabou=sa is only a figure of speech, though Gorgias claims his rhetoric to be the art of all arts. In his exposition he contents himself with a pair of examples only. That this view is really due to Gorgias is shown by the passage in Philebus, quoted on 452 e.

tw=n a)/llwn: with whom he was on like terms of intimacy. The following passage gives the two leading departments of the physician's profession—pharmacy, fa/rmakon piei=n, and surgery, temei=n h)\ kau=sai parasxei=n —which in ancient times, as is also the case to a large degree at present, were frequently united by the same practitioner. The knife and the cautery, as the two leading instruments of the surgeon's profession, are often mentioned together. Cf. 480 c, 521 e; Prot. 354 a; Aeschy. Ag. 848 o(/tw| de\ kai\ dei= farma/kwn paiwni/wn,|h)/toi ke/antes h)\ te/montes eu)fro/nws|peiraso/mesqa ph=m' a)postre/yai no/sou.
parasxei=n: cf. Apol. 33 b kai\ plousi/w| kai\ pe/nhti pare/xw e)mauto\n e)rwta=n. As here 475 d, Prot. 348 a. See Kr. 55, 3, 21.

o(/ph| bou/lei: more exactly we should expect o(/poi, and some of the inferior Mss. have it here. But the ideas of ‘where’ and ‘whither’ are often confounded in Greek, while in Eng. ‘where’ has become the rule for ‘whither’ in ordinary conversation. The remark here is very fitting in the mouth of Gorgias, in view of his extensive travels. Cf. Introd. §§ 4, 5.

ou)damou= a)\n fanh=nai: cf. Xen. Mem. i. 2. 52 a)napei/qonta ou)=n tou\s ne/ous w(s au)to\s ei)/h sofw/tatos, kai\ a)/llous i(kanw/tatos poih=sai sofou/s, ou(/tw diatiqe/nai tou\s e(autw=| suno/ntas, w(/ste mhdamou= par' au)toi=s a)/llous ei)=nai pro\s e(auto/n. Also Phaedo 72 c. Similarly in Latin. Cf. Cic. de Fin. v. 30. 90 tantam vim esse virtutis ut omnia, si ex altera parte ponantur, ne appareant quidem and ii. 28. 90 Socrates voluptatem nullo loco numerat. Compare also the exactly similar Eng. colloquialisms, ‘to be nowhere,’ and ‘to be left quite out of sight.’

ton ei)pei=n dunato/n: le/gein is more usual; but the same difference which exists between e)/lege and e)/lece or ei)=pe exists also between their infinitives. So here ei)pei=n means to make or deliver a speech. Cf. Prot. 329 a ta/x' a)\n kai\ toiou/tous lo/gous a)kou/seien h)\ *perikle/ous h)\ a)/llou tino\s tw=n i(kanw=n ei)pei=n.

e)n plh/qei: though properly much more general in its meaning than e)kklhsi/a| or sullo/gw| used above, is probably employed only for the sake of variety. The distinct and definite statement with which Gorgias closes his characterization (h( me\n ou)=n kte(.) brings up to his mind the thought that perhaps some might object to the indiscriminate employment of such an art. He is thus led to a defence of it which is so injudicious that it affords the adversary the very best weapons for attack.

th=| a)/llh| a)gwni/a|: carried away by the excitement of his own thoughts, Gorgias forgets the caution which he had hitherto exercised in his conversation with Socrates, as well as the definition of rhetoric which the two had agreed upon above, and is led to set forth his art quite in the manner of the Sophists (the Eristics), as a means of defence and offence; a weapon which, though it required the use of the mind instead of the body, the lips instead of the arms, was no less a department of the science of fighting than boxing or the other exercises of the soldier. Some Sophists —i.e. Euthydemus and Dionysodorus —were at the same time teachers of fencing. Boxing, pukteu/ein, which, in connexion with palai/ein, or wrestling, formed the pagkratia/zein, went beyond the range of ordinary gymnastics, and belonged to the peculiar art of the athletes. Fighting in full armor (o(plomaxi/a) was not followed as a profession until after the Peloponnesian War. As in all these exercises, so in rhetoric the great object was not public, but private, not advantage to the community, but advancement for the individual.
e)/maqe: the unexpressed subject, as of xrh=sqai, is the indefinite ‘one.’
a)pokteinu/nai: if one gets as far as the kentei=n, it is but a short step to the a)pokteinu/nai.
foith/sas: foita=n is the regular word for attendance at a school; hence foithth/s, a ‘scholar.’
eu)= e)/xwn to\ sw=ma: not merely by the gift of nature, but also, as puktiko\s geno/menos, by education.
pare/dosan: used like tradere in the sense ‘impart, or transmit by teaching.’ The object (afterwards taken up in tou/tois) is to be supplied from the sense of what precedes.

mh\ u(pa/rxontas: an integral part of the subst. inf. clause; hence the mh/. u(pa/rxein has here its primitive meaning, to be the first cause, to be there to begin with, as opposed to a)mu/nesqai. Cf. Leg. ix. 879 d mh/te ga\r u(pa/rxwn mh/te a)muno/menos to\ para/pan tolma/tw plhgai=s to\n toiou=ton nouqetei=n. a)/rxein is also similarly used in Leg. ix. 869 c a)muno/menos a)/rxonta xeirw=n pro/teron, but with a different feeling. The asyndeton of two opposites is not unfrequent.—

metastre/yantes: which is regularly transitive (e.g. Rep. ii. 367 a metastre/fontes au)toi=n th\n du/namin, utriusque vim pervertentes) is used here absolutely in the sense reversing the matter. Cf. Hom. b 67 qew=n d' u(podei/sate mh=nin,|mh/ ti metastre/ywsin (cause a reverse) a)gassa/menoi kaka\ e)/rga.
th=| i)sxu/i: corresponds to eu)= e)/xwn to\ sw=ma, as te/xnh| to puktiko\s geno/menos, so that both are considered dependent upon training.
ou)k o)rqw=s: a case of litotes.
oi( mh\ xrw/menoi: equiv. to oi(\ a)\n mh\ xrw=ntai o)/rqw=s. Hence the mh/.
pro\s apantas: as above, 456 d.
e)/mbraxu: denotes what is otherwise expressed by w(s e)n braxei= (sunelo/nti) ei)pei=n, and shows that the following peri\ o(/tou a)\n bou/lhtai is absolutely without limitation.

ou)de\n kte(.: the dangerousness of the art is to be offset by the natural feeling of equity which will compel each of the two aspirants to leave uninjured the public position which both desire, as well as the do/ca, which is the orator's continual and chief aim.
ou)de/n ti: strengthens the negation. Cf. the Eng. ‘none the more.’ The acc. of this neg. is used, but never the dat. with the comparative.
o(/ti: is correlative with tou/tou e(/neka. For the following double kai/, see on 457 e.

e)a\n de\ kte(.: shows again the opposition of practice to theory. Gorgias continually recurs to the same thoughts, as if the rolling swell (o)/gkos) of words could conceal the poverty of ideas. This belongs to the mimetic element of the dialogue.
ka)=|ta: as well as ka)/peita, is often used after a partic. as if it were following a finite verb.
XII.
oi)=mai: the asyndeton shows that Socrates himself is not overpleased.
e)/mpeiron: sc. by having taken part in them either as speaker or listener.

lo/gwn: employed here as the general word including both the public speech as well as the private conversation, which is more properly dia/logos. Cf. Prot. 335 d e)a\n su\ e)ce/lqh|s, ou)x o(moi/ws e)/sontai h(mi=n oi( dia/logoi with 337 a xrh\ tou\s e)n toioi=sde lo/gois paragignome/nous koinou\s me\n ei)=nai a)mfoi=n toi=n dialegome/noin a)kroata/s. The word sunousi/a is similarly used in 461 b.
kaqewpake/nai: the compound verb, as compared with the simple, shows that the opinion has been gained by a consideration of a number of cases. Cf. 465 d.
du/nantai: sc. oi( le/gontes or oi( dialego/menoi, from the preceding lo/gwn.
diale/gesqai: belongs to e)pixeirh/swsin. The ou(/tw sums up and re-emphasizes the preceding participles, on which lies the chief weight.
diorisa/menoi pro\s a)llh/lous: “after having, by mutually giving and receiving information, defined to each other's satisfaction the nature of the question under discussion.”—
maqo/ntes and

dida/cantes: stand to each other as active and passive; they denote the means by which the disputants have been enabled to define the question at issue (diorisa/menoi), and are hence subordinate to the preceding participle. Plato rather likes such collocations of active and passive ideas. Cf. d below, ei)po/ntes kai\ a)kou/santes, and 462 a.

h)\ mh\ safw=s: an afterthought. Had it been present originally in Socrates' mind, he would have said mh\ o)rqw=s h)\ kte(.; but not being present, the negative was attracted to the verb of saying, by the regular Greek rule. Looking at it in this light, it is not necessary (with Cron) to supply a
second fh=| from the preceding mh\ fh=|, which would hardly come under the head of the simple following the compound.

xalepai/nousi: the pl. occurs here as it did with a)mfisbhth/swsin above, because from o( e(/teros to\n e(/teron we naturally draw the idea “both.” Cf. in Latin, Cic. de Fin. iii. 2. 8 quod cum accidisset, ut alter alterum necopinato videremus, etc., and the expression for ‘both’ in the Romance languages.— The use of the pronouns throughout this long sentence is both interesting and instructive; a)llh/lous, e(autou/s, e(/teros, e(/teron, e(autw=n, sfw=n au)tw=n (bis). The distinction between reciprocal and reflexive is sometimes very narrow.

filonikou=ntas kte(.: when both reproach each other thus, they place themselves on the same level as participants in a disputatious contest, where each seeks his own honor, not the truth, as Socrates shows in Phaedo 91 a, where he contrasts the filoso/fws and filoni/kws e)/xontes, and says of the latter, o(/tan peri/ tou a)mfisbhtw=sin, o(/ph| me\n e)/xei peri\ w(=n a)\n o( lo/gos h)=|, ou) fronti/zousin, o(/pws de\ a(\ au)toi\ e)/qento tau=ta do/cei toi=s parou=sin tou=to proqumou=ntai. Cf. e, below, on pro\s to\ pra=gma. They bear it hardly, and think that out of envy, envy of themselves, the opponent said it, actuated by a factious spirit, and not by a desire to search into the matter before them in the discussion.
loidorhqe/ntes kte(.: the two following participles, though logically co-ordinate with loidorhqe/ntes, really give its two sides.

oi(=a . . . a)/xqesqai u(pe/r: the use of the acc. with the infin. after forms of oi(=os is very rare, and seems to be an extension of the personal use of the infin. with oi(=os. See GMT. 759; Madv. 166 c, and note on 452 e. Cf. Apol. 23 e *me/lhtos me\n u(pe\r tw=n poihtw=n a)xqo/menos, *)/anutos de\ u(pe\r tw=n dhmiourgw=n kte(. We soon feel anger and indignation for one whom we consider abused.
ou) pa/nu a)ko/louqa: ‘not quite consistent.’ Cope.

a)ko/louqa: denotes the naturally following result; su/mfwna, the inner agreement of two statements standing in juxtaposition. Cf. Xen. Anab. ii. 4. 19 nea/niskos de/ tis . . . ei)=pen, w(s ou)k a)ko/louqa ei)/h to\ e)piqh/sesqai kai\ lu/sein th\n ge/furan, Lach. 193 e ta\ e)/rga ou) sumfwnei= toi=s lo/gois. Plato delights in applying musical terms to logical conditions; hence the frequency of sumfwnei=n and diafwnei=n, as also of suna/|dein, sunw|do/s. Cf. 461 a, 482 b.

fobou=mai: has here a double reference, (1) to an action to be performed (inf.); (2) to an effect to be avoided (mh\ with subjv.). Cf. Xen. An. i. 3. 17 e)gw\ ga o)knoi/hn me
 a)
 ei)s ta\ ploi=a e)mbai/nein a(\ h(mi=n doi/h, mh\ h(ma=s tai=s trih/resi katadu/sh|, foboi/mhn d' a)
 tw=| h(gemo/ni w(=| doi/h e(/pesqai, mh\ h(ma=s a)ga/gh| o(/qen ou)k e)/stai e)celqei=n. In the first we have the will-side of the fear; in the second, the apprehension.
ou) pro\s to\ pra=gma: the neg. ou) is regular with the inf. of the indir. discourse.

pro/s: denotes the end which the subject has in view. In the present case this is paralleled by tou= with the infin.,—one of the many Greek modes of expressing finality (H. 960; GMT. 798). With pro\s se/ also the main idea of the pro/s is that of hostile purpose; the hostility, however, does not lie in the pro\s, but in the general tone. In a certain sense filonikei=n might also be applied to Socrates, as his search for truth was a continual struggle throughout his whole life.
kai\ su\ . . . kai\ e)gw/: when the second member of a comparison is contained in a relative clause with o(/sper or w(/sper, the Greek idiom re quires kai\ in both members.

h(de/ws a)\n e)legca/ntwn . . . le/goi: of these two conditional clauses the first is logical, the second ideal. The present conversation is a practical example of Socrates' view; hence the logical conditional form is used for the practical present case. The rest of the sentence follows naturally in the opt. as being rather theoretical, and applicable to some other time than the present. The participles represent the same tenses of the optatives.
ou)k a)hde/steron kte(.: cf. 506 c kai/ me e)a\n e)cele/gxh|s, ou)k a)xqesqh/somai/ soi, w(/sper su\ e)moi/, a)lla\ me/gistos eu)erge/ths par' e)moi\ a)nagegra/yei.
mei=zon ga\r au)to/: the correlative to o(/sw|per is wanting, as is often the case. au)to\ is always emphatic; the unemphatic pronoun is tou=to.

ou)de\n kte(.: Socrates was convinced that correct views determine the will and actions, and that sin and error are due to lack of knowledge. Hence instruction, if it carry conviction with regard to what is good and true, must also bring about moral improvement. Cf. what he says in Apol. 26 a dh=lon ga\r o(/ti, e)a\n ma/qw, pau/-
somai o(/ ge a)/kwn poiw=, and the celebrated phrase ascribed to him, ou)dei\s e(/kwn a(marta/nei.

do/ca yeudh/s: the force of oi)=mai extends over the whole sentence, and we should therefore logically expect do/can yeudh=. But by the use of the nom. Socrates holds the object up to view like an image.
ei) de\ kai/: the contrast would rather be given by the harsh ei) de\ mh/, but Socrates modifies it with his usual courtesy.
to\n lo/gon: in the same sense as in 457 d, above.

u(fhgei=: indicate, sc. by your words and example. Gorgias reconsiders his assent by the expression xrh=n e)nnoei=n. With xrh=n and e)/dei the opposition is to the inf., not to the obligation. By giving his reason, Gorgias stimulates himself to change from ‘we ought to have’ to ‘we must’ (skopei=n ou)=n xrh/).
kai\ u(ma=s: as contrasted with the others, who had come earlier.
a)potenou=men: to be completed according to 465 e suxno\n lo/gon a)pote/taka and 466 a. So frequently, e.g. Prot. 335 c, 336 c, 361 a.

mh/ tinas: is connected, in a loose kind of epexegesis, with to\ tou/twn, and hence also depends on skopei=n. For the ind., cf. Lach. 196 c, o(rw=men mh\ *niki/as oi)/etai/ ti le/gein, Lysis 216 c e)/ti de\ kai\ to/de skefw/meqa mh\ h(ma=s lanqa/nei to\ fi/lon w(s a)lhqw=s ou)de\n tou/twn u)/n.

tou= me\n qoru/bou: here we recognize the importance of the silent listeners, whose presence we infer from such remarks as this, and who serve at this juncture to keep the discussion going. Next to them is Chaerephon, who here acts as their spokesman, and answers the boulome/nous ti kai\ a)/llo pra/ttein. The qo/rubos simply denotes a rather loud expression of protest against the apparent purpose of Gorgias, and of pleasure in the continuation of the dialogue.

mh\ ge/noito kte(.: a most emphatic denial in the form of a wish. The sentiment is similar to that of Pindar (Isth. i. 1 f.), alluded to in Phaedr. 227 b ou)k a)\n oi)/ei me kata\ *pi/ndaron kai\ a)sxoli/as u(pe/rteron pra=gma poih/sasqai to\ sh/n te kai\ *lusi/ou diatribh\n a)kou=sai.

Callicles is very eager to get the conversation directed to his own more especial field—politics. Hence his support of Chaerephon's protest, which he emphasizes by the addition of the expression kai\ me\n dh\ kai\ au)to/s, where the kai\ me/n approximates closely in force to kai\ mh/n.
ou)k oi)=d' ei): commonly equiv. to haud scio an, sometimes, as here, to haud scio an non. On ei) in this double meaning, see Kr. 65, 1, 8.
w(/ste . . . xariei=sqe: compare with w(/ste . . . pra/ttein, a few lines above.

to/ g' e)mo/n: has almost the same force as e)gw/, only less personal. Like the phrases with peri/ and a)mfi/, it became very common in later Greek. Cf. Rep. vii. 533 a e)pei\ to/ g) e)mo
 ou)de
 a)
 proqumi/as a)poli/poi with Symp. 210 a e)rw= me
 ou)=n e)gw\, kai\ proqumi/as ou)de
 a)polei/yw. Kr. 43, 4, 26.

ai)sxro/n: note that Gorgias is impelled to a continuation of the dialogue only by regard for his own honor. This motive was especially strong with the Sophists; cf. Prot. 352 d ai)sxro/n e)stin e)moi\ sofi/an mh\ ou)xi\ pa/ntwn kra/tiston fa/nai. With ai)sxro/n and similar words which im ply a negation, it is more usual to find mh\ ou). GMT. 817. It is also more common to employ the dat. of reference, instead of the acc. with the infinitive. Rid. § 183.
to\ loipo/n: not ‘furthermore,’ with Kr. 46, 3, 2, but “finally,” “in conclusion,” after those present have expressed their desires.
e)paggeila/menon: for the meaning, see on 447 c. Here it acquires almost the force of “challenge,” since the subject of the inf. must be supplied out of the following o(/ti tis bou/letai.
ou) dida/skonta: the regular neg. with w(/ste is mh/. The ou) here may be due to the fh/|s above, which throws an indir. disc. coloring over the whole. See Gildersleeve, Am. Jour. Phil. vii. 174.

e)/n ge o)/xlw|: Gorgias wishes to protect himself by a restriction which, while it defers, for a brief interval, his defeat, shows plainly the weakness of his professions. See the criticism of Socrates which follows.

e)n toi=s mh\ ei)do/si: the reason for a change of neg. such as occurs in this and the following clauses is often hard to perceive. Here it seems to be the oscillation from generic to particular, which is going on continually in Socrates' mind. Having made his general point with mh/, he recurs to the case under discussion with ou). So o( de\ mh\ i)atro/s . . . a)nepisth/mwn (cf. before, e)n toi=s mh\ ei)do/si), but o( ou)k ei)dw\s, e)n ou)k ei)do/si. It would be possible, but not so good, to take the latter cases as examples of adhaerescent ou).
tou=to sumbai/nei h)\ a)/llo ti: according to the position of a)/llo ti before or after the h)/ is the latter to be translated “than” or “or.”

e)ntau=qa/ ge: Gorgias notices the danger of such a concession, but still thinks he can limit the force of the argument to the single case. Perceiving this, Socrates immediately extends his statement to make it apply kai\ peri\ ta\s a)/llas a(pa/sas te/xnas.

pra/gmata . . . mhxanh\ peiqou=s: Socrates never lets slip an occasion to emphasize the essential opposition of the aim of rhetoric to the truth of facts, an opposition admitted, indeed, by the Sophists themselves. Cf. the statement of Tisias in Phaedr. 272 d o(/ti ou)de
 a)lhqei/as mete/xein de/oi . . . to
 me/llonta i(kanw=s r(htoriko
 ei)=nai.
pollh\ r(a|stw/nh: Gor

gias is continually wandering away from the discussion of the nature of rhetoric to the praise of it, and being set right again by Socrates, who, while he brings back the discussion to the subjects which Gorgias had declared to be the proper province of rhetoric, is at the same time paving the way for an examination of its moral value.
dia\ to\ ou(/tws e)/xein: sc. mh\ maqo/nta kte(.—au)ti/ka e)piskeyo/meqa: a formula for getting rid of a side issue like ei)sau=qis skeyo/meqa Prot. 357 b.—
ti\: is adverbial.

pro\s lo/gou: to the advantage of our discourse. But little different from pro\s lo/gon. Cf. Prot. 351 e e)a\n pro\s lo/gon dokh=| ei)=nai to\ ske/mma.— to/de: draws the attention in advance to the series of closely interconnected questions, introduced by a)=ra, which, by their very intimate relation one to another, oppose, with a certain importunity, Gorgias' continual wandering and vagueness, and also, by their delicate allusion to the somewhat extravagant expression used above (455 d), have a decidedly ironical tinge, which is rendered more appar ent by the doubtful oi)=mai of Gorgias' answer.
a)=ra: see on 476 a.
proepista/menon: the partic. is again the most important part of the statement, as in 457 c, 453 b.
th=s r(htorikh=s: this passage differs from 455 d only in arrangement.

e)/xe dh/: a request to pause, whereby the point reached is declared to be an important one, which merits further consideration. Cf. Prot. 349 d e)/xe dh\ . . . a)/cion ga/r toi
e)piske/yasqai o(\ le/geis. When thus used, e)/xein is of course intransitive. H. 810.
h)/toi . . . h)/: or at least. In English we should naturally use ge\ with the second member. Cf. Apol. 27 d tou\s dai/monas h)/toi qeou/s ge h(gou/meqa h)\ qew=n pai=das.—
para\ sou=: const. with u(/steron maqo/nta alone; pro/teron with ei)de/nai.
ta\ tektonika/: “the principles of building.”

kata\ to\n au)to\n lo/gon: according to the same principle (analogy). ‘The argument which follows is to our notions sophistical enough. Not so, however, from the Socratic point of view, according to which every virtue is a form of knowledge, and every vice the result of ignorance.’ Thompson. See on 458 a.

ou)kou=n a)na/gkh kte(.: a few lines below is found a repetition of the first clause of this sentence, in almost the same language, where, too, the statement is natural, and is used as a basis for a further deduction; here, on the contrary, it is out of place, and besides, is not followed up at all in the next sentence. These reasons have led to the omission of the bracketed words, by which we get a clearly logical argument, as follows: “The just man performs just actions.” “Yes.” “Must he not therefore wish always to perform just actions?” “Apparently.” “The just man will never, then, wish to perform unjust actions,” etc.
XV.
le/gwn: equiv. to o(/ti e)/leges, that you were saying.
ou)d' e)kba/llein: when two verbs which govern different cases are construed with but one object, it is customary to construe this object with the nearer verb. Cf. below (5).

xrh=tai/ te kai\ a)dikh=|: the co-ordination of the two ideas by te . . . kai/ brings into greater prominence the impropriety of thus misapplying otherwise useful skill, than the more usual a)di/kws xrh=tai of the following clause.

a)lla\ tw=| a)dikou=nti: the mhde\ e)celau/nein is a result which may or may not follow the e)gkalei=n, according to circumstances. The real opposition is between tw=| dida/canti and tw=| a)dikou=nti, hence the second is put in the same case as the first, although the acc. would be required by e)celau/nein. Cf. Prot. 327 a pa=s pa/nta e)di/daske kai\ e)pe/plhtte to\n mh\ kalw=s au)lou=nta.
a)/n pote a)dikh/sas: represents the same tense of the optative.
o(/ ge: gives the basis of the statement. The neuter may be due to the pra=gma immediately preceding (H. 631 a), or it may simply be used ad sensum. Cf. 465 d.
ou(/tw: under these circumstances. See on 503 d.
suna/|dein: a musical term. See on 457 e.

o(ra=|s dh\ kai\ au)to/s: properly the following clause should be independent, stating the conclusions reached in the investigation; but by bringing it under the government of the inserted o(ra=|s kte(. an appeal is again made to the fairness of the opponent. Cf. Apol. 24 d o(ra=|s, w)= *me/lhte, o(/ti siga=|s, ib. 31 b nu=n de\ o(ra=te dh\ kai\ au)toi/, o(/ti oi( kath/goroi kte(.
ma\ to\n ku/na: cf. 466 c, 482 b, Apol. 22 a. Socrates is rather fond of this formula of asseveration, possibly out of aversion to any light handling, even of the Greek divini ties. See on 463 d.

ou)k o)li/ghs sunousi/as: a delicate allusion to 458 c, which shows Socrates' fine feeling in not insisting on a discussion which must be unpleasant and also humiliating to Gorgias. The word sunousi/a is elsewhere employed so as to include the discourses (dia/logoi), e.g. Prot. 310 a ti/ ou)=n ou) dihgh/sw h(mi=n th\n cunousi/an; i.e. in the sense of the Eng. “meeting.”
On Polus, who here again thrusts himself into the discussion, see note to 448 a, and Introd. § 14.

kai/: belongs, according to the sense, with doca/zeis. Is what you say also really your opinion? We should expect a second kai/ with w(/sper, according to usage. See on 457 e. Others construe kai/ with su/.

h)\ oi)/ei: or do you think. The
second question repeats the first in a varied form. Both questions are ‘rhetorical,’ expecting no answer, and express a protest against the idea that the art of rhetoric has anything to do with a knowledge of what is right.

mh\ ou)xi\... lang=greek>ei)de/nai kte(.: two negs. after h)sxu/nqh mh\ prosomologh=sai, on account of the negative force of the expression. Cf. Prot. 352 c, d. See H. 1034 b, and on 458 d. The construction is the same as that after a)parnh/sesqai below, which is followed by a double neg. because the question ti/na oi)/ei veils the assertion ou)dei/s. ou)xi\ is merely more emphatic than ou).
e)a\n mh\ e)/lqh| tau=ta ei)dw/s: more logically, e)a\n e)/lqh| tai=ta mh\ ei)dw/s.—

dida/cein: depends upon some verb of saying to be supplied from prosomologh=sai. The asyndeton with e)/peita instead of ka)/peita (cf. Apol. 23 c) is not uncommon, and the clause is to be construed in dependence on o(/ti (because). By this time, however, Polus' flow of words has run away with him; he has only energy enough left to hurl at Socrates the words tou=q' o(\ dh\ a)gapa=|s, before he abandons his struggling sentence altogether and starts afresh. Such passages as this show Plato to have been no mean dramatist.

i)/sws: gives expression in passing to the hint that perhaps the contradiction was not so clearly deduced from Gorgias' words as Socrates supposed. The whole sentence, however, shows Polus' complete inability to grasp the real point at issue.
a)groiki/a: is the reverse of paidei/a. By this very criticism, Polus betrays that he is himself just as lacking in the polish of a gentleman, which he denies to Socrates, as in scientific knowledge.
w)= ka/lliste: the epithet suits the pompous rhetor excellently.

u(ei=s: the addition of the word “sons,” though not strictly necessary, is quite natural, especially among people where the support of the parent by the son was so strictly enjoined as among the Greeks.
e)gw\ kai\ *gorgi/as: besides being the Greek idiom, the initial position of e)gw/ softens the supposition for Gorgias. The Latin has the same position.

di/kaios d' ei)=: the sense is to be supplied from what precedes. Cf. Lach. 180 d ei)/ ti e)/xeis tw=|de tw=| sautou= dhmo/th| a)gaqo\n sumbouleu=sai, xrh\ sumbouleu/ein: di/kaios d' ei)=. The regular neg. of the inf. after dokei= would be ou). mh\ is here due to the conditional color. For the personal const. see on 449 c.

a)naqe/sqai: the figure is drawn from the draughts-board; it is the regular word for ‘taking back’ a move. Similarly, Prot. 354 e a)ll' e)/ti kai\ nu=n a)naqe/sqai e)/cestin, ei)/ ph| e)/xete a)/llo ti fa/nai.
ti/ tou=to le/geis: equiv. to ti/ e)sti tou=to o(\ le/geis. Kr. 57, 3, 6; H. 1012 a.
e)a\n kaqe/rch|s: as it were, by a dam or a fence.
xrh=sqai: because in makrolo- gi/a the orator has at his disposal all the devices of his art.

*)aqh/naze: Athens was noted as a po/lis filo/logos (Leg. I. 641 e), and freedom of speech (parrhsi/a) was held to be the fundamental principle of a democratically governed state. Cf. Dem. Phil. iii. 3 u(mei=s th
 parrhsi/an e)pi\ me
 tw=n a)/llwn ou(/tw koinh
 oi)/esqe dei=n ei)=nai pa=si toi=s e)n th=| po/lei w(/ste kai\ toi=s ce/nois kai\ toi=s dou/lois au)th=s metadedw/kate.
th=s *(ella/dos: is the part. gen. dependent upon ou(=. The Eng. would find e)n with the dat. more natural.—
e)/peita: after all. GMT. 856.
a)nti/qes: equiv. to but consider on the other hand; lit. put in opposition.
sou= makra\ le/gontos kte(.: Socrates makes a similar remark in Prot. 335 c, when he really prepares to leave the gathering rather than waste his time in words.
kh/desqai: implies personal interest in the matter.
w(/sper nu=n dh\ e)/legon: is to be taken with the following clause, a)naqe/menos.
fh\|s ga\r dh/pou: by quoting his own vaunting words against him, Socrates compels Polus also to adopt the dialectic form.
dh/pou: throws a tinge of irony into the question.
XVII.
tau=ta: is simply the proposition which Socrates makes, and the words a)lla\ poih/sw tau=ta is a formula of acceptance.
a)lla/: well then, is often thus used in answers. After an imv., as here in Soph. El. 376 ff., *h*l. *fe/r' ei)pe\ dh\ to\ deino/n . . . XP. a)ll' e)cerw= toi pa=n o(/son ka/toid) e)gw/.

ti/na fh\|s ei)=nai: though assuming it as self-evident that rhetoric is a te/xnh, Polus is compelled, in commencing, to put his question quite generally. Socrates, in his answer, confines himself simply to deducing the consequences of Gorgias' admissions. The substitution of h(/ntina for ti/na is according to the strict rule, which, however, is not rigorously adhered to.
w(s . . . ei)rh=sqai: cf. Rep. x. 595 b w(s pro\s u(ma=s ei)rh=sqai. The active ei)pei=n is more common. See Madv. 151; H. 956; GMT. 777. 2.

o(\ fh\|s su\ poih=sai te/xnhn: is to be explained according to 448 c pollai\ te/xnai e)n a)nqrw/pois ei)si\n e)k tw=n e)mpeiriw=n e)mpei/rws hu(rhme/nai, according to which an art arises from experience. Polus, however, has by this time forgotten his own words.
e)n tw=| suggra/mmati: see on 448 c and Introd. § 14.

e)mpeiri/a: here not an empirical science, but merely a dexterity acquired by much practice. Cf. 463 b. The following question is no advance on his first one, and seems to show that Polus has no definite plan.

xa/ris: is the grace which causes pleasure, and depends principally on the person of the orator; h(donh/, the pleasure with which the hearer is inspired by his speech. Quintilian (Inst. or. ii. 15. 24) translates the expression by the words peritia gratiae ac voluptatis. Polus has not yet heard the specific difference which distinguishes rhetoric from other e)mpeiri/ai of the same class. Hence he again falls into the same error in his question as he did in his answer above, 448 c. In this way, however, the conversation is again turned to the consideration of the value of rhetoric.
to\ meta\ tou=to: see on 452 c.
ei) ou) kte(.: ou) because Polus expects an affirmative answer.
ei): whether.
tima=|s: equiv. to kalo\n fh\|s ei)=nai or peri\ pollou= poiei=, as in Crito 47 a.
to\ xari/zesqai: pres. for the habit.
xari/sasqai: aor. for the single example.
tau)to\n d' e)sti/n: with surprise and disgust. Polus overlooks the fact that there can be two orders belonging to the same species.
ti/nos . . . tau/ths: in close connexion with what precedes. See on 461 d and 449 e.

mh\ a)groiko/teron h)=|: it is not necessary to supply a verb of apprehension, though that is the idea suggested by mh/ with the subjv. GMT. 309; H. 867. The employment of the form here is an attempt to concili ate. In 486 c, 509 a kai\ ei) a)groiko/tero/n ti ei)pei=n e)sti, Socrates has laid aside all idea of conciliation, and speaks the truth with boldness. a)/groikos is opposed to a)stei=os, and means rude (see on 447 a). It is to be taken in connexion with the reproof administered by Polus in 461 c. Truth often incurs the reproach of a)groiki/a. Note that Socrates still preserves towards Gorgias his courtesy and respect.
ou)deno/s: explanatory of tino/s.
mhde\n e)me\ ai)sxunqei/s: cf. Hom. g 96 mhde/ ti/ m' ai)do/menos meili/sseo.

yuxh=s de\ stoxastikh=s kte(.: in this characterization, Socrates includes all the good that can be said of the art of rhetoric. It requires cleverness in perceiving and distinguishing between various relations, hardihood to work before the eyes of the world, and skill in dealing with men.

stoxastikh=s: is originally connected with shooting and throwing, but is often metaphorically used. With this definition, cf. Isoc. c. Soph. 294 d tau=ta de\ pollh=s e)pimelei/as dei=sqai kai\ fuxh=s a)ndrikh=s kai\ docastikh=s e)/rgon ei)=nai. In regard to courage in speaking, cf. Cic. de Or. i. 26. 121.
kolakei/an: the Greek word means more than the English “flattery.” Under it is included everything whose aim is the agreeable rather than the good.
e)pithdeu/sews: notice the variety in the use of the words e)pith/deusis and e)pith/deuma, which are to be distinguished as pra=cis and pra=gma, the one being a concrete manifestation of the other.

e)mpeiri/a kai\ tribh/: these words are but little distinguished. The first denotes, as has already been said (on 462 c), the result obtained by practice; the latter is more especially that which is derived from work without any definite object or clear consciousness. So rhetoric is called in Phaedrus 260 e a)/texnos tribh/, and in 270 b tribh\ kai\ e)mpeiri/a. See on 462 c.

kommwtikh/: is not only finery in dress, but also hair-curling, ointments, cosmetics, etc. Cf. Quint. ii. 15. 25 mangonum artificium, qui colorem fuco et verumrobur inani sagina mentiuntur. The addition of ge\ emphasizes the examples newly thought of.
ei) ou): see on 462 d.
14 ff.

a)pokrinou=mai . . . pri\n a)\n a)pokri/nwmai: after the model of the anticipatory conditional. pri/n, “before,”
takes the inf.; “until,” the indic. subjv. or opt., according to the sphere of time. See Gildersleeve, Am. Jour. Phil. ii. 465 ff.

a)=r' ou)=n kte(.: the question implies doubt, and is intended to stimulate Polus' attention; but for some cause, probably dulness, he merely renews his previous question.—The meaning of ei)/dwlon is made clear by Theaet. 150 e feudh= kai\ ei)/dwla peri\ plei/onos poihsa/menoi tou= a)lhqou=s.
ta\ ga\r kaka\ kte(.: that which according to its nature can be characterized as a)gaqo/n, must be esteemed kalo/n. If, however, it is kako/n, then it must be esteemed ai)sxro/n.
w(s h)/dh ei)do/ti: is a stinging rebuke to Polus.

ma\ to\n *di/a, a)ll' e)gw\ kte(.: Socrates' words implied that Polus was either too dull or too careless to understand him.
