Gorgias, while tacitly admitting Polus' incompetency, tries to smooth over his defeat by confessing to his own inability to catch Socrates' meaning as it is at present stated. If the master, au)to/s, cannot understand, the pupil may be pardoned for the same fault. Polus, though defeated in his attempt to rout Socrates (461 b ff.), only retires to recover breath before making a final effort (466 a).

ma\ to\n *di/a: is a real asseveration, used designedly by Gorgias, who is too much of a gentleman to indulge in oaths,—this being the only instance in this dialogue. It is significant that Polus, in spite of his heat, is likewise only once (473 a) betrayed into the common nai\ ma\ *di/a. Callicles uses oaths roundly enough, but restricts himself to nh\ tou\s qeou/s, nai\ ma\ *di/a, and ma\ *di/a. On Socrates' habit, see on 449 d, 461 b.
*pw=los de\ . . . o)cu/s: in this re

mark Socrates both apologizes for and explains the reason of the obscurity of his statements; but it is, at the same time, an excellent char
acterization of the impetuosity and heat of Polus, whether he be the questioner or the respondent. It also contains an allusion to the name itself (pw=los a colt, filly).

The division of kolakei/a given above was made without specifying the standard of division, and only enumerates the different varieties. Socrates now, at Gorgias' instance, reduces the whole subject to a regular system, by referring kolakei/a back to a higher species, qerapei/a, on the basis of a distinction according to reality and appearance. Now, since qerapei/a has for its object the eu)eci/a tou= a)nqrw/pou, we get two more points of view: (1) that of the object (a)nqrw/pou), as composed of body and soul; and (2) that of the treatment, as being either positive or negative.
oi(=on toio/nde le/gw: is a formula for introducing an example or a special case in illustration of a general statement.
eu)= e)/xein ta\ sw/mata: ta\ sw/mata here, as well as to\ sw=ma kai\ th\n yuxh/n below, is acc. of specification. H. 718 a.
to\ toiou=ton: the article is used on account of its reference to what has just been described. This is more definitely given in the o(/ti (relative) clause which follows.

e)/xei de\ kte(.: in this change of subject lies no ambiguity either to the Greek mind or to us. It was, besides, a regular way in Greek of expressing “although.” The subject is the same indefinite one which must be supplied as the object of the preceding poiei=. See on 456 d.
XIX.
duoi=n kte(.: the dual in Plato's time is fast fading out, and he uses it as an artistic feature. It disappears entirely before the close of the fourth century B.C. Notice the asyndeton.
mi/an o)noma/sai: like e(ni\ o)no/mati kalei=n, prosagoreu/ein.—ou(/tws: is idiomatically used, “thus briefly” or “thus at the moment.” See on 503 d.
ou)k e)/xw: I am not in position, regularly takes the aor. infinitive.
a)nti/strofon me\n . . . a)nti/strofon de/: an example of ‘anaphora.’

a)nti/strofon: denotes a part corresponding to a similar part on the opposite side of the symmetrical whole. The function of gymnastic and nomothetic is to lay down, each in its own department, certain positive directions whereby the constitution of the subject under treatment is preserved and improved. The arts of healing and the administration of justice seek in practice to put a stop to the disregard of these directions, and to restore the normal condition. Ac cording to their object, therefore, medicine and gymnastic, as well as the making and administration of law, all belong to the same class, e)pikoinwnou=si me\n dh\ a)llh/lais.

dikaiosu/nh: is used here in the same sense as dikastikh/ 520 b below; why, it is hard to understand. It may have been chosen in view of the earlier definition of the object of rhetoric in 454 b, 455 a. The i)atrikh/ is beyond cavil good; on the contrary, dikastikh/ is susceptible of a bad construction, whereas here there was need of no doubtful word. Though not customary, there is no reason why dikaiosu/nh should not be understood as the practical exercise of that character of the di/kaios, which for an Athenian was naturally to be found in the dikastikh/. The word, then, means here “administration of justice.” That the word is genuine is shown by Quintilian's translation iustitia in ii. 15. 28.
ai)sqome/nh and

gnou=sa: are distinguished both as regards the object and the manner of their activity. gnw=sis is directed to the nature, which is only comprehended by thought; ai)/sqhsis is merely the visual perception of the outward form or effects, the cause of which, lying in the nature of the object, is not comprehended. By a)lla\ stoxasame/nh the idea of ai)sqome/nh is not merely repeated, but also more exactly defined. Similarly, 452 e, and in a different order 521 d, e. On the heaping up of participles and their subordination, see Kr. 56, 15 with notes.
u(podu=sa: as it were under a cloak or mask by which its real nature is concealed. The usage is borrowed from the stage; cf. Luc. Pisc. 33. The simple acc. with this verb is not uncommon.

qhreu/etai th
 a)/noian: the application of the figure of the hunt to those arts which seek only the appearance, is frequent in Plato, and most developed in the Sophistes. With the same employment of abstract for concrete Demosthenes expresses himself, Ol. ii. 7 th
 ga e(ka/stwn a)/noian a)ei\ tw=n a)gnoou/ntwn au)to
 e)capatw=n kai\ proslamba/nwn ou(/tw hu)ch/qh.
w(/sper oi( pai=des (sc. ei)sin): in such comparisons the nom. is as common as the attracted case. Madv. Syn. 20, 3.
e)pai+/ei peri\ kte(.: this otherwise poetic verb is used several times by Plato. Cf. 518 c; Apol. 19 c; Crit. 47 b, 48 a; Lach. 186 e. It also takes the acc. Kr. 68, 31, 2.
tou=to ga\r pro\s se\ le/gw: brings up again Polus' persistent efforts to make Socrates say that rhetoric was kalo/n (462 c, 463 d, e).

stoxa/zetai: here equiv. to aim at; above 464 c in the derived mean
ing guess at.
a)/neu tou= belti/stou: is brachylogic. Without regard to what is best.
w(=n prosfe/rei: denotes the means which each employs, and whereby it works upon others.
w(/ste . . . mh\ e)/xein: the mh/ could very well be omitted, but Greek usage sanctions the redundancy.
u(posxei=n logo/n: to render account. Cf. Prot. 338 d pa/lin ou(=tos e)moi\ lo/gon u(posxe/tw.
XX.
o)yopoiikh/: is not attributive to kolakei/a, but the latter is predicate with u(po/keitai, as flattery. Hence the point of the following kata\ lo/gon.

u(po/keitai (equiv. to u(pote/qeitai): is not used in the sense which we elsewhere find, lie at the foundation of, as in Prot. 349 b e(ka/stw| tw=n o)noma/twn u(po/keitai/ tis i)/dios ou)si/a, but like u(pode/duken above, 464 d.

kakou=rgos kte(.: these four adjectives go in pairs. The two first describing the nature of kolakei/a per se, contain the kako/n of it; the first is more general, the second adds the special (Kr. 69, 32, 2), at the same time emphasizing the result for the world at large. The second pair contains the ai)sxro/n, the verdict on the value of such skill. The following participle, with its datives, defines more narrowly a)pathlh/.

oi( gewme/trai: the word denotes “mathematicians” in general. So i.e. Theodorus of Cyrene is continually called gewme/trhs in the Theaetetus. Higher arithmetic also is included under geometry, because the Greeks employed geometrical methods to represent the higher relations of numbers. In the following proportion, we are reminded at once of an arithmetical formula; while the Greeks were reminded of the due proportion of lines and figures, in accordance with the development of mathematical science among them. The relations of the ideas can, by means of this threefold division into pairs, be brought into a simple but complete scheme. See on 464 a above.
h)/dh ga\r kte(.: mathematics was looked upon by Plato as a preparation for ‘dialectic.’
o(\ kommwtikh\ pro\s gumnastikh/n: in this formula e)sti/ is always wanting.

ma=llon de/: introduces a comparison equally true, but more to the point of the argument (cf. 449 a), by the completion of the proportions already worked out, and by their extension to the whole system of ideas thus far developed.—It might seem strange that sophistic is paired with nomothetic, and not with philosophy. Philosophy, however, is the science of principles in general, while in this dialogue only ethical and political principles are discussed. These latter, however, the law-giver must make use of, —i.e. must be a philosopher, as is proved in the much more comprehensive and thorough discussion in the Republic.

o(/per le/gw: refers, as it always does, to a previous statement; here to 464 c, where the close relationship of the te/xnai, which have to do with the same object (body and soul) was spoken of. This idea is here expressed by the words a(/te d' e)/ggus o)/ntwn, which recall at once the expression above, a(/te peri\ to\ au)to\ ou)=sai. The subject of die/sthken is not expressed, but is a general one, to be taken out of the preceding proportions, which embrace all te/xnai and e)mpeiri/ai, and the same subject must be thought of with o)/ntwn. On account of the position of a(/te e)/ggus o)/ntwn the de/ is drawn away from the second member of the contrast, fu/rontai.—

fu/sei: means the essential peculiarity, actual nature, of the ideas. Instead of these, however, with fu/rontai we have the persons introduced who employ and practise the te/xnai and e)mpeiri/ai, and who from ignorance of their true nature bring them into activity at the same time, and thus mix together matters which, properly considered, are quite distinct.

e)n tw=| au)tw=|: probably denotes the soul as the place of action, and peri\ tau)ta/ the moral questions treated, both of which are reckoned together above (464 c) in the expression peri\ to\ au)to/. Socrates restricts himself to the two e)mpeiri/ai to which r(htorikh/ belongs, inasmuch as the object of the whole investigation is only an exact understanding of the nature of rhetoric. This passage is referred to below, in 520 a.—Plato can explain more accurately the relation of sophistic and rhetoric to each other, because he was the first to explain the difference scientifically, whereas Gorgias, though he was unwilling to be reckoned among the sophists, could give no reason therefor.

e)pesta/tei: we have to imagine such e)pista/tai as, like the kubernh/ths, paidotri/bhs, poi/mhn, are at the same time e)pisth/mones. Cf. Prot. 312 d, where the sophist is defined as e)pista/ths tou= poih=sai deino\n le/gein, i.e. e)pista/menos poih=sai kte(., a definition which furnishes, at the same time, an example for the fu/rontai e)n tw=| au)tw=| kai\ peri\ tau)ta\ sofisth\s kai\ r(h/twr above.
kateqewrei=to: cf. 457 c. Here is meant a thorough critical examination from a higher point of view.

to\ tou= *)anacago/rou: see on 450 c, 453 e, and Kr. 47, 5, 10. Anaxagoras, the friend of Pericles, agreed with the Atomic school and Empedocles, in holding that, in their original condition, the elements or atoms (according to him, unlimited in number, but of a certain definite quality) were mixed all together, without any definite arrangement. Into this confusion order was introduced by nou=s, or the thinking spirit; or at least, this spirit gave the impulse towards it. His thesis describing the primitive condition of matter was this: o(mou= pa/nta xrh/mata h)=n. Cf. Dyer-Cron, Introd. to Apol. § 10.
tou/twn: perhaps with an intentional ambiguity.—Gorgias himself was not entirely without philosophical culture. See Introd. § 6. But as to Polus, we have no information.

tw=n te i)atrikw=n kai\ u(gieinw=n: both expressions are frequently connected to denote the same idea, both subjectively and objectively. Now, since u(gieino/n is that which u(gi/eian e)mpoiei= (Rep. iv. 444 c) and i)atrikh/ is e)pisth/mh tou= u(gieinou=, the latter must perforce be the art whose object is to restore the body to a healthy condition.
o(\ me\n ou)=n kte(.: with this the discussion returns to the point which had given occasion to the above digressions (o(/per me/ntoi).

e)kei=no: refers to o)fopoii/a. The employment of a neuter demonstrative or relative referring to an antecedent in the masculine or feminine adds to the generalness of the conception. Cf. 463 b, 460 e. But e)n sw/mati may have had some influence.

me
 ou)=n: here, as also in i)/sws
me
 ou)=n and o(\ me
 ou)=n just preceding, ou)=n does not denote sequence, but adds force to the statement about to be made in view of what has already been said.
e)moi/: hints a contrast.
XXI.

ti/ ou)=n fh/|s: Polus braces himself, and assumes again the office of questioner; but shows, by the vagueness (cf. above, 462 c with note) and inappropriateness of his question, that he is either singularly inattentive or stupid. Hence he receives a sharp rap over the knuckles with the admonition that his question had been some time settled (465 d).

ti/ ta/xa dra/seis: is taken by Cron to mean “what can you possibly (ta/xa) bring forward?” i.e. in the course of the discussion. The scholiast understood it as meaning “what will you do presently,” when you get old, as we see by the addition presbu/ths geno/menos. Probably it is but an exclamation of wonder and surprise; our colloquial “What'll you do next?”

e)n tai=s po/lesi: is to be connected with fau=loi nomi/zesqai. In spite of his qualification, Polus proceeds to put as bad a color on his assumed view of Socrates as possible, by adding a)gaqoi/ (cf. 449 a) to r(h/tores. Cf. 469 a. He does not aim at a refutation of Socrates; with him the question is still not the true nature of Rhetoric, but its value and power in the state.

e)rw/thma kte(.: probably Socrates only wishes to show that, from the point of view of dialectic, the preceding question is so inappropriate that he is obliged to look upon it as a merely rhetorical one, by which Polus only states his own sentiments. Cf. below c.

ou)de\ nomi/zesqai: much more
crushing than fau=loi nomi/zesqai. “They are not considered at all,” “they have no value whatever.” On nomi/zesqai, cf. Ar. Nub. 962 o(/t' e)gw\ (o( di/kaios lo/gos) ta\ di/kaia le/gwn h)/nqoun kai\ swfrosu/nh )neno/misto (“was in high repute”).
me/n: almost equiv. to mh/n, indeed.
dh/: equiv. to just. “But that is indeed just what I do (ge) say.”

w(/sper oi( tu/rannoi: by this comparison Polus endeavors to emphasize the importance of his art, careless of the fact that he thereby detracts from its moral value. He employs his strongest expression of power actually used (a)pokteinu/asin), not even using the circumlocution oi(=oi/ t' ei)si/n. In spite of his following reassertion, however, the question is really only a rhetorical one, in which he voices his own statements. See on a above.
nh\ to\n ku/na: see on 461 b.—
a)mfignow= . . . le/geis: ‘I am in doubt at every word you say.’ Cope.
ei)=en: “very well,” accepts the issue.
XXII.
du/nasqai me/n: the correlative has me/ntoi, which is much stronger than de/.
w(=n bou/lontai: is a circumlocution for the part. gen.; hence the indicative.
w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n: see on 450 b.
ou)kou=n kte(.: Polus is surprised that Socrates should see any difference in the two phrases.

ou)/ fhmi (nego): repeats ou)/x, w(/s fhsi. Polus does not understand Socrates, who has in mind the results of the admission that the possession of power is a good. The question is merely rhetorical, with an accent of astonishment.

ma\ to/n: the omission of the divinity occurs not infrequently. Cf. Ar. Ran. 1374 ma\ to/n, e)gw\ me\n ou)d' a)/n, ei)/ tis e)/lege/ moi tw=n e)pituxo/ntwn, e)piqo/mhn kte(. H., 723 a, says that the deity is omitted with humorous effect; but it is much more likely here that Socrates is a little vexed, but stops at once any exhibition of it. The Scholiast's note, eu)labei/as xa/rin, may be interpreted as indicating this motive, or the motive assigned to Socrates on 461 b.
fh/|s: with a clear reference to Polus' previous statements in b, which he is thus led to reiterate.
ga\r ou)=n: is frequently found thus in phrases of acquiescence.

ou)kou=n a)podei/ceis kte(.: the fut. in neg. questions forms a lively expression for urgent demand. Kr. 53, 7, 4; H. 844 a.—The pred. noun with the supplementary partic. follows the same rule of agreement, as with the supplementary infinitive.

e)cele/gcas: the refutation consists in the proof, and the proof is at the same time a refutation. We must not insist on the priority of the aorist participle (H. 856 b); but the complex is to be considered, and from that point of view it would make no difference whether we had a)podei/ceis e)cele/gcas or a)podei/cas e)cele/gceis.

h( de\ du/namis kte(.: contains one of the propositions on which Socrates bases the statement made above (466 e) and afterwards repeated, pw=s a)\n . . . me/ga du/nainto. The other proposition is that the possession by the orators of the power of doing what they please is not a good possession.
e)celegxqh=|: in the pregnant sense. “If by a refutation of the position taken he be not convinced.” Cf. 482 b.

ou(=tos a)nh/r —: ‘aposiopesis.’ Polus is so astonished that he does not know what to say. The complete exclamation (always without the article) occurs 489 b. Cf. 505 c. Polus' astonishment, as well as stupidity, are still more evident in the words which follow, sxe/tlia le/geis kai\ u(perfua=. sxe/tlios is taken from Homer, where, however, it is only used of persons (except rarely in the Odyssey); u(perfuh/s is not unknown in Attic, but occurs in Plato (except here and 477 d) only in the adverbial form.

tou/tou pro/sqen: can, of course, be considered as a gloss on a)/rti, but it heightens the effect, from a mimetic point of view, as well by its meaning, “a moment ago,” as by its position at the end of the sentence.
de/: almost equiv. to “although.” It is often used in the second of clauses thus connected to emphasize the opposition.
w)= lw=|ste *pw=le: ‘paronomasia’ in Polus' style. See on 448 c.
i(/na kai\ ei)dw=: expresses curiosity, rather than a desire for information. Socrates, as leader of the discussion, makes at once an advance, by fixing a very important distinction.
o(\ a)\n pra/ttwsin, o(\ pra/ttousin: the former is generic, the latter is a circumlocution. A few lines below o(/per poiou=sin is the special case, explanatory of tou=to.
pi/nontes para\ kte(.: the preposition is personal; “from the hands of.”

oi( ple/ontes: the merchants (e)/mporoi) who engage in transmarine trade. Notice the confusion of the order, in which we can see the natural freedom of conversation. The subject of e)sti/n is ou) tou=to o(\ poiou=sin, the predicate o(\ bou/lontai. The subject oi( ple/ontes floats until the plural verb appears. The neg. in ou)kou=n is not felt here. H. 1048 a (b).
pra/gmat' e)/xein: is passive to pra/gmata pare/xein.

a)/llo ti: ‘a)/llo ti h)/ challenges an affirmation with respect to some special portion of the sentence; a)/llo ti challenges an affirmation with respect to the whole sentence which follows it.’ Riddell, § 22.

a)=r' ou)=n e)/stin kte(.: see a more detailed investigation of this theory in Lysis. Cf. 216 d dokei= moi w(sperei\ tri/) a)/tta ei)=nai ge/nh, to\ me\n a)gaqo/n, to\ de\ kako/n, to\ d' ou)/t) a)gaqo\n ou)/te kako/n.
pollh\ a)na/gkh: the answer is not according to the form of the preceding question, but according to the sense, as if ou)de\n e)/sti tw=n o)/ntwn had preceded.
sofi/an, u(gi/eian, plou=ton: types of the three great classes of property, —mental, physical, and material.
a)=ra: for position, see on 472 d.
au)=: on the other hand. To actions are opposed things, which, however, belong to a similar category.
be/ltion: sc. than its opposite. When the comparison is self-evident, the Greek, like the English, frequently omits the second member.
XXIV.
e)kei=na, e)kei=no: the immediate repetition of the same pronoun with different reference is remarkable.
tau=ta: refers back to a(/.
sfa/ttein: is purposely substituted as a harsher word for a)pokteinu/nai. It implies that the person killed is defenseless: “to slaughter like an ox.”

a(plw=s ou(/tws. thus sim- ply, “without limitation,” as one would have to assume if the view of Polus is to stand. Cf. Prot. 351 c ou)k oi)=da a(plw=s ou(/tw, w(s su\ e)rwta=|s, ei) e)moi\ a)pokrite/on e)sti/n, w(s ta\ h(de/a te a)gaqa/ e)stin kte(. Cf. 464 b.

ti/ ou)k a)pokri/nei: a challenge in the form of a question, because Polus hesitates to answer. He is beginning to feel concerned for his fondly cherished view and bold state
ments. The same form recurs a few lines below, where Polus is just clearly recognizing his defeat. These artifices belong to the dramatic side of the dialogue, and take the place of the tedious repetitions which weary us in the narrative form; i.e., in Prot. 360 c, d sune/fh—e)pe/neusen— kai\ e)ntau=qa e)/ti e)pe/neusen—pa/nu mo/gis e)ntau=qa e)pe/neusen—ou)ke/ti e)ntau=qa ou)/t' e)pineu=sai h)qe/lhsen e)si/ga te.

ei)/per tau=ta o(mologou=men: is the general premiss, while what follows up to ou)ka/kion is the special application of this to tyrants and orators. For the structure, see on the similar case in 453 c.
au)tw=|: is said from the standpoint of the critic, although referring to the subject of oi)o/menos. The Greek does not cling to the reflexive. Kr. 51, 2, 5; H. 684 a.
tugxa/nei de\ kte(.: is connected with the participle as an independent clause,—a usage common after relatives. Kr. 59, 2, 6. 9; H. 1005. The Eng. idiom requires ‘although’ or ‘whereas.’
e)n th=| po/lei tau/th|: in this undefined city of which they were speaking, the abode of the tyrant or orator under criticism (o( toiou=tos).
o(/ti e)/stin: that it is possible. There need not be in all cases a conflict between what one wishes and what seems best, but the possibility of a single case is enough for Socrates' argument.

w(s dh\ su\ kte(.: is quite ironic; as if you would not! It is really a com
parison, “it is just as true as the fact that,” etc. By this fling Polus seeks to evade confession of his defeat.
dh/santa: equiv. to ei)s to\ desmwth/rion a)gago/nta.
zhlwto/n: enviable. By an easy shift, the personal idea is transferred to the action itself.
eu)fh/mei (fave lingua): says Socrates, because the denial of all moral principles implied in the words of Polus seems to him like a sin against divinity. Cf. Prot. 330 d.
tw=n: the art. with incorporated antec. is Platonic. Kr. 51, 12, N.
dikai/ws: is slipped in unfairly by Polus. Cf. 466 a.
pro/s: is the only preposition that occurs at all frequently in Attic prose as an adverb.

ou(/tws kte(.: ‘Life is not the highest good, but guilt is certainly the greatest evil.’ This was one of the life principles of Socrates. Cf. the beautiful exposition in Apol. 28 b ff., especially 29 b and 30 d, Crito 48 b.

bouloi/mhn a)\n ou)de/tera: I would WISH neither; because also to suffer wrong is not a good thing. With Polus wish and preference coincide. —This quibble of Socrates is interesting, as showing the difficulties by which early thinkers were beset. For an accurate statement of principles, an accurate use of synonyms was indispensable; and this was not yet possible, even with the cultured.
su\ a)/ra kte(.: Polus cannot tear himself away from his fast-rooted ideas. Hence all teaching is vain.
w)= maka/rie: has somewhat of an ironical coloring. The nearest English equivalent is the half serious “Oh, you awful fellow!”—

e)mou= dh\ le/gontos: as an offset to Polus' words a)ll' e)/gwge tou=to le/gw. “Let us have, then, argument for argument.” The gen. may depend on e)pilabou=, as in 506 b, but it is more likely gen. abs. See on a)ntilamba/nesqai, 506 a, and Symp. 214 e e)a/n ti mh\ a)lhqe\s le/gw, metacu\ e)pilabou=, a)
 bou/lh|, kai\ ei)pe\ o(/ti tou=to yeu/domai. The original meaning is made clear by Prot. 329 a ta\ xalkei=a plhge/nta makro
 h)xei= kai\ a)potei/nei, e)a
 mh\ e)pila/bhtai/ tis (unless one takes hold of it).
tw| lo/gw|: instrumental dat., “with your argument.”
e)n a)gora=| plhqou/sh|: is not tem
poral, as in Xen. An. i. 8. 1 h)/dh de\ h)=n a)mfi\ a)gora\n plh/qousan, i.e. towards noon. It simply indicates the presence of a multitude.

e)gxeiri/dion: is not a “dagger,” but a short sword for striking and thrusting; the former is shown by kateage/nai th=s kefalh=s. Cf. Xen. Hell. ii. 3. 23 paraggei/lantes neani/skois . . . cifi/dia u(po\ ma/lhs e)/xontas paragene/sqai.

teqnh/cei: one of the two Greek verbs with fut. perf. active. See H. 467. The fut. perfect expresses the certainty as well as the immediateness of the result; cf. kateagw\s e)/stai au)ti/ka ma/la, and see GMT. 79.
th=s kefalh=s: is a gen. of the part affected. H. 738 b. Cf. Ar. Ach. 1180 th=s kefalh=s kate/age peri\ li/qon pesw/n. The acc. could have been used; cf. 515 e ta\ w)=ta.—
au)tw=n: follows tina/, —a case of ‘hyperbaton.’

The art. is omitted before trih/reis, although it has a different gender from that of the preceding substan tive. Cf. Phaedo 111 c kai\ to/n ge h(/lion kai\ selh/nhn kai\ a)/stra o(ra=sqai u(p' au)tw=n oi(=a tugxa/nei o)/nta. Omission of the art. where both substantives are of the same gender is not uncommon. The two kindred ideas are thereby brought together into one conception. In the present passage, by this means we have the objects enumerated divided into classes: (1) the navy-yard, with the war-vessels therein contained; (2) the remaining vessels, whether they be public or private property. Similarly, Dem. Ol. ii. 9 tw=| _ta\ xwri/a kai\ lime/nas kai\ ta\ toiau=ta proeilhfe/nai.
ou(/tw ge: limits the answer, as if Polus still wished to save something from his earlier statement.

ou)kou=n kte(.: the sentence is merely a statement in the form of an interrogation, and assumes an assent by the opponent, provided no express demurrer is raised. Socrates gives opportunity for this after du/nasqai (29), but as none is made, he proceeds again with skeyw/meqa kte(.—
pa/lin au)=: because in this new conception is contained a correction of the former view held by Polus.

fai/netai: has its subject in to\ me/ga du/nasqai, and its predicate in a)gaqo/n te ei)=nai. “Does not then this great power of yours (pa/lin au)=) appear to you (only provided the one who does what seems good to him proves to be doing what is profitable) to be both a good thing,—and that, as it seems, is the real (to/) great power; otherwise it is an evil thing and small power.” The sentence begins with a question which is lost in an affirmation.

ei) de\ mh/: is phraseological, “otherwise.” The contrast is with tou=to, and through this with e)a
 me
 kte(. The subject of kako/n (e)sti) kai\ smikro
 du/nasqai is, of course, the phrase to\ pra/ttein a(\ dokei=, to be supplied from the context. H. 904, 906 a, b.
a)/llo ti: see on 467 d.

su\ me\n ou)=n kte(.: Polus evades the answer and forces it upon Socrates, partly because he is not able to give it, for the distinction demanded lies equally remote from the circle of his thoughts and his feelings; partly because he does not wish it, for he has a suspicion that it will contradict all the views which he has thus far expressed. The less, however, he is in position to confute Socrates by arguments, the greater is his confidence in his ability to do so by facts.
XXVI.
xalepo/n: is ironic; but in a)ll' ou)xi/ the irony turns to sober earnest. Not so with the irony of Socrates.
mh\ ka/mh|s, a)ll' e)/legxe: note the difference between positive and neg. imperative.
eu)ergetw=n: is to be explained according to 458 a. On the supplementary partic., see G. 279, 1; H. 983.
ta\ ga\r e)xqe\s kai\ prw/|hn: means “recent events.” Homer also uses the phrase xqiza/ te kai\ prw/iza, B 303. The Greek idiom requires kai/ where the Eng. uses “or.”

polloi\ a)dikou=ntes a)/nqrwpoi: in most cases when the participle is used as an attribute, we can still feel the participial plus as compared with the adjective. Here, however, that has almost completely disappeared, and the participle is as much an adj. as prosh/kwn, pre/pwn, etc.

ta\ poi=a: it is a matter of individual preference whether the art. be used or not; cf. 449 e. When used, the article limits the attention to what has been already alluded to; here, ta\ e)xqe\s . . . tau=ta. In Eng. one also occasionally hears the art. with the interrogative.

*)arxe/laon: Archelaus, an ille
gitimate son of Perdiccas, seized the throne in B.C. 414, after his father's death, and reigned until 399, when he was murdered by Craterus or Crateuas (name and motive are alike uncertain). The facts brought forward by Polus in their darkest colors are probably correct; but Archelaus laid the foundation for the later importance of Macedonia by introducing Greek culture. He invited famous artists, among others Euripides, to his court. There is also a tradition that he invited Socrates, but that is hardly credible.

o(ra=|s: well expresses the lively interest which Polus, as well as many other Greeks, took in that admired ruler, whose apparent success was doubtless envied by many an aspiring and ambitious man. The answer of Socrates sounds somewhat pedantic, but it is probably jesting, and designed to cool the extravagant ardor of Polus, while at the same time it prepares the way for ou)/pw sugge/gona tw=| a)ndri/ below.
a)lla\ . . . ge: nevertheless, at least. H. 1046, 2, a.
15-This passage is translated by Cicero, Tusc. Disp. v. 12.

au)to/qen: “instinctively,” “of yourself.” This is not translated by Cicero, but it forms a good contrast to suggeno/menos. Polus thinks the very fact of Archelaus being a ruler implies that he is fortunate. That the Persian king was generally esteemed the personification of happiness is shown by Apol. 40 e.
paidei/a and
dikaiosu/nh: together denote moral cultivation.—
o(/pws e)/xei: construed with the part. gen. See G. 168, N. 3; H. 757 a.

a)/ndra kai\ gunai=ka: virtue, and hence also the foundation of eu)daimoni/a, is, according to Socrates, one and the same for all, while the pupils of Gorgias recognized different varie
ties for different classes. Cf. Meno 71 e prw=ton me\n ei) bou/lei a)ndro\s a)reth/n, ei) de\ bou/lei gunaiko\s a)reth/n kte(. On the omission of the art. with gunai=ka, see on 469 e.
ou(=tos . . . o( *)arxe/laos: the position emphasizes the name; ‘this man—Archelaus!’

pw=s ou)k a)/dikos: sc. e)sti/n. This admission, coupled with the opinion that Archelaus is an enviable and happy man, which is very evident from the ironical narrative which follows, shows most plainly the utter opposition between Polus' view and the moral principle which Socrates champions.
w(=| ge: introduces the authority of indisputable facts. See on 460 e.
32 ff.
kai\, kai\, kai/: is in sense almost equiv. to “and therefore.” The construction begun in the clause w(=| ge . . . a)delfou= is naturally varied in kai\ . . . *)alke/tou by being made personal.
ei) e)bou/leto, h)=n eu)dai/mwn: is an unreal conditional sentence, with opposition to the present. The close proximity of the two clauses in the apodosis explains the omission of the second a)/n.

despo/thn kai\ qei=on: denotes two kinds of moral obligation to which Archelaus paid no attention; ceni/sas adds a third, the violation of which was considered among Greeks the worst of crimes, a sin against *zeu\s ce/nios. Cf. Hom. N 624, Xen. An. iii. 2. 4. The heaping up of the words katamequ/sas, e)mbalw/n (like a thing), e)cagagw/n, a)pe/sfacen, h)fa/nisen makes the impression of the repeated acts of violence very vivid.
to\n a)delfo/n: is emphasized by its position in advance of its governing verb (partic.).

*perdi/kkou: Perdiccas II. reigned from B.C. 454 (?) until 414 or 413, after having dispossessed his brother Alcetas. During the Peloponnesian war he pursued a very prudent but faithless policy.—The extraordinary number of participles employed by Polus has an artistic value in showing the tumultuousness of his feelings.
ou)k e)boulh/qh (he did not choose)

eu)dai/mwn gene/sqai: is very sarcastic. The conclusion introduced by toiga/rtoi is equally emphatic. Polus admires in Archelaus the strength of will which hesitates at nothing to accomplish its aim; regret with him is weakness.

kai\ i)/sws e)/stin o(/stis kte(.: in these words, in spite of their sarcastic form, lies the only attempt at proof which Polus makes, i.e. an appeal to the opinion of others; he of course thinks that no one will own himself to be such a man.

kai\ kat' a)rxa/s: leads us to expect in the following kai\ nu=n a confirmation and climax of praise, —which, however, is changed instead to blame by tou= . . . h)melhke/nai. Note the zeugma in combining tou= . . . h)melhke/nai with e)ph/|nesa. See on 520 b h)\ tw=| au)tw=|. The praise was bestowed in 448 d.
po/qen: is a question with a negative force, to which the affirmative kai\ mh/n corresponds.

e)pei\ dokei=: in such phrases the e)pei/ has the force of “although,” “whereas.” Cf. Prot. 335 c sofo\s ga\r ei)=: e)gw\ de\ ta\ makra\ tau=ta a)du/natos e)pei\ e)boulo/mhn a)\n oi(=o/s t' ei)=nai. Apol. 19 e. The conj. merely indicates a relation between the two ideas. If these two ideas harmonize, the relation becomes causal; if not, it becomes adversative.
w)= maka/rie (cf. 469 c): implies the reproof which follows.
e)n toi=s dikasthri/ois: the manner of argument practised there frequently incurs Plato's disapproval. Cf. Apol. 34 b ff. The emphasis is laid on h(gou/menoi and dokou=sin.
e(/na tina/: the indef. pron. emphasizes the number, “a paltry one.”

katayeudomarturhqei/h tis: the Greek idiom does not require intr. verbs to be used impersonally in the passive. Cf. Xen. Apol. 24 katayeudomarturei=n e)mou= with Dem. in Meid. 136 katayeudomarturou=mai.
dokou/ntwn ei)=nai ti/: equal to eu)doki/mwn. Cf. the English colloquialism ‘he pretends to be something.’
o)li/gou: almost; the remnant of the phrase o)li/gou dei=n. H. 743 b.

marturh/sou s kte(.: Nicias, the celebrated general in the Peloponnesian war, who met his death in the Sicilian expedition (B.C. 413), was leader of the moderate wing of the aristocratic party. Aristocrates, the son of Scellias or Scellius, belonged, as we can judge from Ar. Av. 125 and Thuc. viii. 89, to the extreme or oligarchical order. He was one of the generals condemned to death for negligence at the battle of Arginusae. Xen. Hell. i. 7. Socrates here speaks of both as if they were still living. (See Introd. § 18.) Next to them, Socrates mentions the house of Pericles; he could not name the statesman himself because he was already dead when Gorgias visited Athens for the first time; but he, with his house, was a champion of the Athenian democracy. So we have here representatives of the chief political parties as witnesses for Polus. They agreed with each other in that they esteemed power in the state,—even tyranny,
—though purchased at the price of wrong-doing, to be the highest good.
20 ff.

e)a
 me
 bou/lh|, e)a
 de/ bou/lh|: are not pleonastic after e)a
 bou/lh|, but are due partly to courtesy (cf. Prot. 353 b ei) de\ mh\ bou/lei, ei)/ soi fi/lon), and serve also by specifying to emphasize the possibility of a free choice among all parties.

w(=n oi( tri/podes: in this way these men show that they were dokou=ntes ei)=nai ti/. They also, by the magnificence of their offerings, proved their piety, and their ‘testimony’ would be therefore the more weighty. Nicias was, according to all accounts, an honorable man. Thucydides says (vii. 86) of him, in referring to his mournful death: h(/kista dh\ a)/cios w)
 tw=n ge e)p' e)mou= *(ellh/nwn e)s tou=to dustuxi/as a)fike/sqai dia\ th
 pa=san e)s a)reth
 nenomisme/nhn e)pith/deusin. By Dionysion is to be understood not a temple, but a spot sacred to Dionysius,—a sacred precinct. Nicias built there a kind of shrine, which possessed, among other treasures, some very costly tripods which he had dedicated to Dionysus after he had discharged the office of Choregus—a very costly liturgy in itself. The tripods were arranged apparently e)fech=s with a kind of ostentation.
e)n *puqi/ou: sc. i(erw=|. The offering of Aristocrates must have been, according to the words of Socrates, also costly and well-known.
a)nagka/zeis: sc. to agreement by convincing reasons; often followed by o(mologei=n, but without it in Theaet. 196 b tou/tw| au)tw=| h)nagka/zomen mh\ ei)=nai yeudh= do/can.

e)kba/llein e)k th=s ou)si/as kai\ tou= a)lhqou=s: this is ambiguous, for ou)si/a can denote property, material possessions as well as physical existence. Accordingly Polus appears here in the investigation as a tyrant, who drives others from house and home. But it is this same power which the orator wishes to obtain (before a court) by his speech.

se\ au)to\n . . . ma/rtura: the dialectical proof is a course of logic, a process of reasoning, which Socrates carries through, with the help of his adversary, by question and answer. Hence by his enforced agreement a man becomes a witness against himself.

e)/stin kte(.: Socrates does not hereby recognize this adducing of ‘testimony’ to be a correct tro/pos e)le/gxou, but rather implies by the words w(s su/ te oi)/ei kte(. (cf. 471 d, 473 b) that it is only a pretended one, which cannot stand against the true one.
sxedo/n ti: does not weaken the idea, but merely softens the expression. The question under discussion is really the cardinal one of life, ‘How can I be happy?’

au)ti/ka: is one of the ways of introducing an example in Greek. Cf. Prot. 359 e pa=n tou)nanti/on e)sti
 e)pi\ a(\ oi(/ te deiloi\ e)/rxontai kai\ oi( a)ndrei=oi. au)ti/ka ei)s to
 po/lemon oi( me
 e)qe/lousin i)e/nai, oi( de\ ou)k e)qe/lousin. The addition of prw=ton shows that there are still other conflicts between their views; i.e. in reference to the nature and value of punishment.
ei)=nai: is thrown forward for the sake of emphasis, as e)/sti above. After h(gou=mai, nomi/zw, and similar verbs the pred. is often found without a copula. Cf. 473 a.
e(/n: with this are connected other points of difference.
ei)=en: see on 466 c.

a)=ra: the position here is still more remarkable than in 467 e and 476 a.—The whole weight of the question falls on a)\n tugxa/nh| di/khs kai\ timwri/as. The former, di/kh, usually denotes simply the carrying out of the law, the infliction of justice; the latter, timwri/a, the fine or penalty which falls to the
injured person or the state. These are both external demands on the criminal, called forth by his crime, and by which an expiation of it is to be effected. On the other hand, ko/lasis is the discipline which the guilty party himself undergoes, designed to prevent further transgression; while zhmi/a (470 a) is only the injury or damage which he sustains in expiating his crime. From the outset Socrates shows that, even according to the view of his opponent, wrongdoing does not give happiness under all conditions. This point is not made superfluous by the discussion of 469 c-470 c; for there the question concerns du/namis, not eu)daimoni/a.

kai\ tugxa/nh| di/khs: seems a strange addition after didw=| di/khn, with which it appears to be almost synonymous. But the two phrases are probably intended to be but the subjective and objective, the active and passive expression of the same idea; as the u(po/ with the gen. would indicate.
fi/lon ga/r se h(gou=mai: there

fore Socrates does not allow himself to be deterred by the trouble it will involve to bring Polus to the same opinion. tau)ta\ le/gein (kai\ fronei=n) is held as a sign of friendship, just as diafe/resqai of enmity. See on 510 c and Sall. Cat. 20 nam idem velle atque idem nolle, ea demum firma amicitia est. At the same time the words contain a delicate reply to Polus' discourteous exclamation. Socrates will soon bring him to say what is in his own view a)/topon.
e)n toi=s e)/mprosqen: cf. 469 b.

to\ a)dikei=n . . . ei)=nai: is cited as an example of rather uncommon use of the indir. disc. inf. after ei)=pon (GMT. 753, 3), but the clause is to be looked at rather as the object of ei)=pon in the sense of “declare.”

kai\ e)chle/gxqhn u(po\ sou=: of course the addition of Socrates after Polus' reply throws a quite different coloring over this sentence. Polus' self-assurance is apparent in vai\ ma\ *di/a, his positiveness in a)lhqh= ge oi)o/menos. i)/sws shows no uncertainty, but is only the conscious under-statement which is common in English. See on 480 a.

a)ll' e)/ti tou=to kte(.: refers to 470 c and is just as ironical. In sharp contrast with the false assurance which trusts its own cleverness is Socrates' faith in the immutability of truth, to\ ga\r a)lhqe\s ou)de/pote e)le/gxetai.

lhfqh=|: pictures vividly the actual scene. In compound verbs the metaphorical meaning often predominates, and leaves the actual in the background (cf. e)p' au)tofw/rw| katalamba/nesqai). In what follows, notice the rhetorical heaping up of the most frightful punishments; which reminds us of Aesch. Eum. 186 ff. karanisth=res o)fqalmwru/xoi | di/kai sfagai/ te spe/rmato/s t' a)pofqorai\ | pai/dwn, kakou= te xlou=nis h)d' a)krwni/a, | leusmo/s te kai\ mu/zousin oi)ktismo
 polu
 | u(po\ r(a/xin page/ntes. Cf. Rep. ii. 361 e mastigw/setai, streblw/setai, dedh/setai, e)kkauqh/setai tw)fqalmw/, teleutw=n pa/nta kaka\ paqw
 a)nasxinduleuqh/setai.
kai\ a)/llas kte(.: notice the o(moiote/leuta.
e)pidw/n: sc. lwbhqe/ntas.
katapittwqh=|: an especially severe manner of punishment. The criminal was put into a sack smeared with pitch,—the so-called tunica molesta,—which was then set on fire.
diafugw/n: “if he succeed”; opposed to lhfqh=|.
o(/ti a)\n bou/lhtai: Polus has again forgotten the explanation of the difference between dokei=n and bou/lesqai.—
eu)daimonizo/menos: to be thought eu)dai/mwn by the multitude is to be so, in Polus' estimation.

kai\ tw=n a)/llwn ce/nwn: cf. Hom. B 191 a)ll' au)to/s te ka/qhso kai\ a)/llous i(/drue laou/s, 480 d, Phaedo 110 e li/qois kai\ gh=| kai\ toi=s a)/llois zw/|ois te kai\ futoi=s. The same idiom is found in Latin, as equites et aliud vul gus. See on 447 c.
tau=ta le/geis: Polus is trium
phant, as if Socrates' position (tau=ta) were now overthrown.
mormolu/ttei: the expression for terrifying with ghost stories. The ‘mormo’ was the ‘bad man’ with which children were frightened. Cf. Crito 46 c.
w)= ge/nnaie: is probably designedly used because the means employed are unfair, being only a pretended, not a real proof. Cf. 471 e.
o(/mws de/: although in reality no point has been made, yet Socrates is ready to assume one and proceed upon that.
e)a\n a)di/kws e)pibouleu/wn: can be completed from c. The change in the expression is due to the collocation of the two words.
o( diafeu/gwn: “whoever remains unpunished.”
turanneu/sas: “he who attains to the tyranny.” The more important idea precedes.

ti/ tou=to: what can this mean? The inappropriate laughter of Polus is probably in accordance with the precept of Gorgias that in serious things one must draw the audience to his own side by laughing. Arist. Rhet. iii. 18 (Rhet. Gr. ed. Sp. i. 160): dei=n e)/fh *gorgi/as th
 me
 spoudh
 diafqei/rein tw=n e)nanti/wn ge/lwti, to
 de\ ge/lwta spoudh=|.
katagela=n: to laugh it down. Socrates' opinion of the a)/llo ei)=dos e)le/gxou is shown by the addition, e)le/gxein de\ mh/.

e)rou= tina toutwni/: by again having recourse unto the opinion of others, Polus again reverts, though in a different manner, to his ‘witnesses’ (469 e), and shows that the rhetorical method of proof is alone comprehensible to him. By inviting Socrates to put the question to those present, he reminds him of the analogous practice of e)piyhfi/zein (rogare populum), and gives him a chance to plead his own inaptitude as an excuse for not employing rhetorical methods. Socrates in his reply also shows that to accept the opinion of the majority —the method which the state had settled upon as the best way of establishing the truth—was as unsatisfactory, when employed by the individual, as the rhetorical methods. The fact to which Socrates alludes is the well-known trial of the generals who had won the battle of Arginusae and afterwards fell victims to political intrigue. The full proceedings are detailed by Xen. Hell. i. 6. 33 ff. and 7. Socrates was senator this year (Ol. 93. 3, 406 B.C.), and in the memorable assembly e)pista/ths tw=n pruta/newn. As such, he opposed the unlawful proceeding with an intrepid courage which he here humorously calls inaptitude in e)piyhfi/zein. Socrates mentions the circumstance also in Apol. 32 b, but in a different manner. On the chronological difficulty, see Introd. § 18.
h( fulh/: of course that to which Socrates belonged, h( *)antioxi/s.
ge/lwta parei=xon kai\ kte(.: a ‘hysteron proteron.’ See Rid. § 308.
tou/twn: i.e. the various means with which Polus had hitherto attempted to confute Socrates.
o(/per nundh/: 472 c.
para/dos: viz. to\n e)/legxon. Cf. below, dido/nai e)/legxon “to give a chance for refutation.”
ou)de\ diale/gomai: because scientific investigation by means of conversation is naturally confined to individuals.

e)pei\ . . . a)dikei=n: this is not meant in earnest, but is a reductio ad absurdum of the preceding words of Socrates, which are so opposed to Polus' view. On e)pei/ cf. 471 e, and see GMT. 718, where this clause is cited as interrogative.
kai\ ga\r e)piqumw=: implies a doubt whether Socrates can really advance anything in support of his view. On the following answers of Polus, see Introd. § 14.

w(/sper kte(.: as an actual fact, the discussion has been concerning the question whether a)dikei=n or a)dikei=-
sqai were the greater evil, since the middle of ch. XXIV.
ti/ de\ dh/; how so, then?—The predicate is thrown forward in the following clause, because the chief weight of the contrast falls upon it.
ou)kou=n kte(.: the kalo/n is here the species under which the a)gaqo/n and the h(du/ are subordinated.
w(s e)/oikas: logically, in such cases as this, an inf. is to be supplied; but it is doubtful if any such ellipses were felt by the Greeks.—
kalo/n te kai\ a)gaqo/n,—kako\n kai\ ai)sxro/n: ‘chiasmus.’

to/de: is probably an acc. with le/geis understood. Cf. Phaedo 65 d ti/ de\ dh\ ta\ toia/de and Xen. Mem. iii. I. 10 ti/ de\ tou\s kinduneu/ein me/llontas. On the other hand, Phil. 27 e ti/ de\ o( so\s bi/os and Soph. Aj. 101 ti/ ga\r dh\ pai=s o( tou= *laerti/ou make for the nom. The context must be the guide.

ei)s ou)de\n a)poble/pwn: with regard unto nothing, that is, without searching for some characteristic common to all these things, in accordance with which you would be justified in calling them kala/. The word a)poble/pw is used also when reference is made to an idea or principle, which conditions a person's action or the manner of appearance of any phenomenon.
kata/: is used of the scale according to which a thing is to be measured.

pro\s tou=to: points emphatically back to pro\s o(\ kte(., in a way more remarkable here than in 469 c. The relative clause itself is an extension of kata\ th\n xrei/an, laying especial stress on the relativity of the kalo/n.
e)n tw=| qewrei=sqai: notice the use of the passive to denote the point of view from which sw=ma is kalo/n.
e)kto\s tou/twn: i.e. the points of view mentioned in h)/ . . . h)/.
prosagoreu/ein: i.e. to designate by the addition of a characteristic, as if one were addressing a person by name.

kai\ mh/n: introduces us to a new variety of the beautiful, i.e. the results of mental activity. The no/moi, e)pithdeu/mata, and maqh/mata are, with reference to the subject of investigation, fittingly introduced as representatives of this class.

ta/ ge kata\ tou\s no/mous kte(.: it must be confessed that we could do very well without ta\ kala/. If kept, it must be considered as a repetition and restriction of ta/ ge kata\ kte(., and tou/twn must be explained by h)\ w)fe/lima kte(. in appo sition. See H. 950. But Rid. § 271 b seems to have a different view of the sentence, which he holds to be a case of inversion of government, and with this Cope seems to agree in his translation: “And moreover, in all that belongs to laws and habits of life, their beauty, I presume, is to be found nowhere beyond these limits; that is to say, either the utility or the pleasure that is in them, or both.”
kai\ kalw=s kte(.: this lively as
sent of Polus shows that he thinks that Socrates is at last veering round to his position. The manner in which he is gradually undeceived is interesting.
h)/toi kte(.: if the text is sound, Socrates here speaks with less exactness than above, omitting what can be easily supplied.
fe/re dh/: the result obtained is applied to the case under discussion.
lu/ph|: here denotes, as the following a)lgou=si explains, only physical pain. No reference can be meant to the gnawings of conscience.
u(perba/llei: here construed with gen. like u(pere/xei (5). Cf. Leg. v. 734a.

a)/llo ti: see on 467 d. Polus had several times given as an authority the opinion of the masses, and had even, in 474 b, by the words ou)/t' a)/llos ou)dei/s spoken in their name. He thus appears, like Protagoras in Prot. 353 a, as their representative. w(mologei=to properly applies to u(po\ sou=, and the present is to be supplied to u(po\ tw=n pollw=n a)nqrw/pwn.
de/caio a)/n: pays back for Polus' question in 474 b. The construction is varied by the substitution of a)nti\ with gen. instead of h)/ after ma=llon.
a)nti\ tou= h(=tton: sc. kakou= kai\ ai)sxrou=.

gennai/ws: bravely; scorning the pain. The comparison is the same as in 480 c pare/xein . . . w(/sper te/mnein kai\ ka/ein i)atrw=|, and seems to be a Socratic one. Cf. Xen. Mem. i. 2. 54. For the construction, see on 456 b.
fa/qi h)\ mh\ (sc. fa/qi): affirm or deny. See on 454 d.
kata/ ge tou=ton to\n lo/gon: a conditional admission, implying that with a different treatment possibly a different result might be obtained.
ou)/t' a)\n kte(.: a)/n draws attention to the emphatic words. On the position and repetition, see H. 862, 864; GMT. 223, 226.

o(ra=|s ou)=n, o( e)/legxos kte(.: we might also have had o(ra=|s ou)=n to\n e)/legxon o(/ti para\ kte(. But the form chosen by Plato greatly heightens the contrast. Socrates, moreover, is referring to his own words in 472 c parabalo/ntes ou)=n par' a)llh/lous skeyw/meqa, ei)/ ti dioi/sousin a)llh/lwn. Hence also the addition of the expressions marturw=n and e)piyhfi/zwn to the more general o(mologw=n.

a)=ra me/giston: the more usual particle for “whether” is ei), but cf. Phaedo 70 d i)/dwmen a)=r' ou(twsi\ gi/gnetai a(/panta. H. 1016. In the sentence following, we have a)=ra introducing a direct question previously announced by th=|de as in 459 d.
kola/zesqai dikai/ws a)dikou=nta: the adverb is necessary, because upon it rests the main point in the proof.
a)=ra to\ au)to\ kalei=s: the position makes the question more pointed.
kai\ diaskeya/menos ei)pe/: the ex

hortation to Polus to think well before he speaks is at the same time an intimation to the reader that the principle touched on in the question is of the greatest importance, as indicative of a man's moral views, and
hence is not to be accepted without earnest investigation. How necessary this exhortation is, can be perceived from a question of Polus in 477 c.
XXXII.

ka/ei: the examples are chosen from cauterizing and surgery, because the healing art is in general for the body what the puni tive administration of justice is for the soul. See on 456 b. The second example is an advance on the first, in so far as the result of the treatment —corresponding to the general idea pa/qos—can be expressed in the substantival form tmh=ma.
sullh/bdhn: turns from the particular to the generic, and extends to all cases the law which has been noticed in special cases. It belongs, of course, to the last clause oi(=on kte(.
to\ di/khn dido/nai: the article determines the subject. GMT. 790.
o)rqw=s: denotes in general the proper or appropriate exercise of any function, and thus leads up to dikai/ws, which is specially ethical.
ei)/per kala\ kte(.: the argument, made according to the modus tollendo ponens with natural abbreviations, rests on the exposition made in 474 d f.
th\n w)feli/an: cognate accusative. After u(polamba/nw we must supply w)felei=sqai. The asyndeton which follows is of the very common explanatory class.
a)=ra ou)=n: introduces a new section of the argument, regarding the statement advanced by Socrates in 469 b.

kataskeuh=|: is distinguished from paraskeuh/ in that it denotes a preparation designed to endure; paraskeuh/ is for the emergency. Consequently the constitution of the body, so far as it is the result of physical culture, is naturally a kataskeuh/.

ponhri/an: not kaki/an. The latter word, according to the prevailing usage, denotes, as applied to the soul, moral depravity only, as above (a). The former denotes a bad condition in general, which may or may not be due to moral depravity. But as the bad condition usually involves bad constitution, ponhri/a comes to mean much the same as kaki/a. The use of the words depends upon kataskeuh/.

kai\ ta\ toiau=ta: shows that the enumeration is not complete. The omitted member is given below in d (a)ko/laston) and e a)kolasi/a, and thereby the number of ponhri/ai (i.e. varieties of ponhri/a) is made to correspond with the number of cardinal virtues (a)retai/).

pw=s, w)= *sw/krates; Polus shows by the question that he has not yet completely grasped the relationship of the ideas, good and beautiful, bad and ugly (cf. 477 a), although it has been twice expounded by Socrates.
a)niaro/s and

a)ni/a: like a)lgeino/s and a)lghdw/n, characterize the lu/ph from its physical side, i.e. the pain caused by the punishment. Cf. also Prot. 355 e and Gorg. 499 a, where a)nia=sqai is opposed to xai/rein. With bla/bh| sc. u(perba/llon, and also with a)mfo/tera, which is the adverbial acc. like tou)nanti/on and the like. See G. 160,2; H. 719 b. The words a)niaro/tato/n e)sti do not indeed harmonize with the rest of the sentence and may without injury be cut out, but still they are not unnatural in this careless form of conversational speaking and do fit the following question a)=r' a)lgeino/teron.
tou/twn: is of course to be understood in the partitive sense.

a)po\ tou/twn ge: ‘ex his quidem quae disputata sunt.’ Stallbaum.
Polus has a suspicion of what is coming and so expresses himself guardedly, as if he wished to leave a door open behind him. On the contrary, Socrates speaks with great decision, and probably has in mind Polus' words in 471 a qaumasi/ws w(s a)/qlios ge/gonen.
u(perfuei= w(s mega/lh| bla/bh|: a case of what was originally attraction, but which by long usage has become phraseological. See H. 1003 b; Rid. § 197.
XXXIV.
xrhmatistikh/: this and the i)atrikh/ appear already in 452 a ff., where they are associated with gumnastikh/.

eu)porei=s: is used in a transferred sense, as is more frequently the case with a)porei=n. “If you are not at once (ou(/tws) prepared with an answer.” We must imagine a short pause as occurring before ei). Such halts and explanations by means of examples, analogies, suggestive questions, and the like, are of course in accordance with the artistic design of the dialogue, but also serve to keep the attention of the reader. Note the interrogative form of one of Polus' answers. On ou(/tws see on 503 d.
a)kolastai/nontas: appears again in Rep. 555 d, but otherwise seems to be restricted to comedy.
polu\ diafe/rel: this utterance comes from Polus' heart because he still continues to regard the practice of law as the proper field for the exercise of the art which he teaches.
a)palla/ttetai: the subj. is to be supplied from the previous question of Socrates (a)=r' ou)=n . . . i)atreuo/menoi). The trans. use of i)atreu/ein is not common.
u(gih=: on the form, see H. 231 b.
a)=r' ou)=n kte(.: Socrates proceeds now to fulfil the promise made in 473 a.
ou(/tws: is explained by the partic. which follows.
tout' h)=n kte(.: on the gender, see H. 617; G. 138, N. 2 c. The impf. of ‘awakening’ is often employed with a)/ra or its equivalents (w(s e)/oike). See H. 833.

th
 a)rxh
 mhde\ kth=sis: is the substantival, hence the general expression for the previous particular partic. clause. th
 a)rxh/n is construed with kth=sis, which thus far retains its verbal nature.
i)atrikh\ gi/gnetal: carries out the analogy already so far developed. swfroni/zein in the soul corresponds to i)atreu/ein (ka/ein kai\ te/mnein) in the body.
tou=to: i.e. to\ e)/xein kaki/an e)n sw/mati, to be supplied from the preceding clause.
deu/teros: cf. the Eng. colloquial ‘second best.’

o( nouqetou/menos: contains an intimation that the improving punishment need not necessarily be the infliction of physical pain, but may be perceptible only by its effect on the soul. Cf. Apol. 26 a tw=n a)kousi/wn a(marthma/twn ou) deu=ro no/mos ei)sa/gein e)sti/n,
a)ll' i)di/a| labo/nta dida/skein kai\ nouqetei=n. The following expressions can be conceived as denoting progressively severer modes of punishment without going into details.
e)piplhtto/menos: the act. usually governs the dative. See on 472 a.
a)diki/an: in accordance with the general purpose of the discussion this word is used as a general representative of the various varieties of kaki/a of the soul.
ou(=tos: is pred. and is explained by the preceding clause. The subject is the following rel. clause.
diapra/chtai: cf. 473 c.—The three expressions for the idea of punishment correspond to those above used, since kola/zein o)nei/desin (Leg. viii. 847 a) is but little different from e)piplh/ttein.

w(/sper a)\n ei)/ tis: a case of very natural ellipsis. Cf. the analogous Lat. use of tanquam si, ut si. When used by itself this expression becomes a relative phrase, equivalent to the Lat. tanquam sicut. In this sense it is written as one word. GMT. 227, 868. The comparison to a child occurs in Homer, and is found also elsewhere in Plato, e.g. Phaedo 77 d dedie/nai to\ tw=n pai/dwn and e i)/sws e)/ni tis kai\ e)n h(mi=n pai=s o(/stis ta\ toiau=ta fobei=tai. Cf. above, 470 c.
mh\ dido/nai di/khn: cf. 478 e just above, where the same verb is used with w(/ste mh/, and below, b, c, where pa=n poiou=si is used like diapra/caito in this passage without w(/ste.
to\ ka/esqai kai\ to\ te/mnesqai: the repetition of the art. is unusual, and serves to keep the two ideas separate.
o(/ti a)lgeino/n: on the causal o(/ti after verbs of fearing, see GMT. 377.
a)gnow=n ge: Plato frequently employs participial clauses as a kind of addendum to sentences which are either interrupted by the answer of the respondent or already complete in themselves.
oi(=on: what sort of a thing.
kaqora=n ... a)gnoei=n: is epexegetical to toiou=to/n ti, and corresponds to sunisxo/menos . . . fobou/menos and a)gnow=n in the comparison above.
mh\ u(giou=s sw/matos: a harsh use of the comparative gen. equiv. to h)\ mh\ u(giei= sw/mati. See Madv. Syn. § 90.

sunoikei=n: divorces the human personality from the soul and body, by a union of which it exists. With kaqora=n kte(., Plato thins especially of the nou=s to which he opposes that part which, in its subserviency to the lusts and appetites, willingly withdraws from the control of reason.

saqra=|: is used of injuries and defects of all kinds, whether of material things, as jars (493 e), or of the body (Dem. Ol. ii. 21 ka)
 r(h=gma (fracture) ka)
 stre/mma (dislocation) ka)
 a)/llo ti tw=n u(parxo/ntwn saqro
 h)=|). From this meaning comes its transferred use in application to the soul or the state. Notice that the unhealthy soul is designated as saqra/ from a physical point of view, a)/dikos in its dealings with its neighbors, and a)no/sios in its attitude towards the divine.
noi: epexegetic partic. to pa=n poiou=sin.
o(/pws a)\n w)=sin kte(.: is a circumlocution for a third substantive.
ta\ sumbai/nonta: “the results” obtained.
sullogi/sasqai: “to sum up what has been proved.” See on 478 a above, in regard to the answers of Polus.
ei) mh\ kte(.: affirms and admits; but because nothing else can be done.

a)=r' ou)=n: regularly introduces a conjecture, which is expected to be confirmed by the other party; a)=ra alone is also often so used; a)=ra ou) expects distinctly an affirmative answer. Often a)=r' ou)=n approximates to a)=r' ou). Cf. 450 a.
me/giston kako/n: sumbai/nein has (in addition to the inf.) the constr. of tugxa/nw. Hence the omission of the partic. is allowable. GMT. 890.
kai\ mh\n kte(.: in this and in the following utterance of Socrates, the question is denoted merely by the tone.
deu/teron kte(.: cf. the similar usage above in 478 e. If the reading is sound, we must infer from the following clause that to\ a)dikei=n has the same force as to\ a)dikou=nta dido/nai di/khn.

to
 *)arxe/laon... lang=greek>to
 kte(.: the main force of the example lies in the predicate, to
 . . . dido/nta, as the art. shows. Constr. to/n with dido/nta, to which a)dikou=nta is subordinate.
diafero/ntws: is construed like the corresponding verb. Cf. Apol. 29 b e)gw\ tou/tw| i)/sws diafe/rw tw=n pollw=n a)nqrw/pwn.
XXXVI.
h( mega/lh kte(.: the use of the adj. is a slightly sarcastic allusion to Polus' extravagant encomiums on rhetoric. The rhetorical question has the force of a neg. Hence the following causal clause.
au)to\n e(auto\n kte(.: the prefixing of au)to/n emphasizes the reflexive. H. 688. The subj. of fula/ttein is indefinite; cf. 456 d.

i(kano/n: the use of this word is an example of mei/wsis, or understatement, the peculiar characteristic of American humor. A similar case is Ant. Tetral. A. b 2 e)moi\ de\ zw=n te a(/nqrwpos a)natropeu\s tou= oi)/kou e)ge/neto a)poqanw/n te . . . i(kana\s lu/pas . . . prosbe/blhken.

u(/poulon: is stronger than sa- qro/n. The disease leaves the surface, and fastens on the innermost kernel of the soul. We are reminded of the Ovidian Principiis obsta. sero medicina paratur, | cum mala per longas convaluere moras (Rem. Am. 91 f.).
ti/ ga\r dh\ kte(.: the rhetorical question has the force of an emphatic affirmation, ti/ being almost equiv. to ti/ a)/llo.
patri/dos a)dikou/shs: the speeches in the assembly are hereby put in the same category with the judicial.
a)dikou/shs: is a colloquial repetition of a)diki/as.

ei) mh\ ei): cf. Lach. 196 a ou)/te ga ma/ntin ou)/te i)atro
 . . . le/gei to
 a)ndrei=on ei) mh\ ei) qeo/n tina le/gei au)to
 ei)=nai. Cf. Lat. nisi si; i.e. Cic. ad Fam. xiv. 2. 1 noli putare me ad quemquam scribere, nisi si quis ad me scripsit.
ei) u(pola/boi tou)nanti/on: except in case one should assume, on the contrary, that, etc.
o(\s a)\n kte(.: follows a pl. on account of its generic signification, and governs tw=n fi/lwn as a part. gen. Examples in Kr. 58, 4, 5.

mu/santa: to go into danger blindly, i.e. with closed eyes,—to be blind to the existence of danger, as such, was apparently thought to be a mark of great courage and determi nation; hence mu/santa is paired here with a)ndrei/ws. Why one should act so, is explained by to\ . . . diw/konta. One of the functions of the participle is to express manner; hence it is quite natural to find it side by side with an adverb.
tw=n a)/llwn oi)kei/wn kte(.: see on 473 c.
o(/pws a)\n kte(.: is correlative with e)pi\ tou=to. Notice that here the o(/pws is a purely final particle, as it was not in a, b above.
i)/sws soi o(mologei=tai: the per

sonal dat. soi\ seems strange, since it can neither be understood as 482 b below, ou)/ soi o(mologh/sei *kalliklh=s,
nor as 477 d above, ai)/sxiston a)diki/a . . . w(molo/ghtai h(mi=n, for o(mologei=tai (conveniunt, consentanea sunt) has its dat. in toi=s e)/mprosqen. But it is not superfluous; its force seems to be this: “but perhaps you can make it agree with what precedes.” Thus the dat., as well as i)/sws, would serve the author's purpose in delineating Polus' character, who by such shallow artifices seeks to weaken his admissions, and, as far as possible, relieve himself from any responsibility in the results,—a design which Socrates balks by his following question. See on 477 d, 478 a, and H. 770, 771.
ka)kei=na: kai/ assumes ei) ta/de a)/topa dokei=, thus noticing Polus' observation.

lute/on: a metaphor drawn from such usage as lu/ein ge/furan. Cf. Prot. 332 e, Xen. An. ii. 4. 19. A different meaning appears in dialu/ein to\n lo/gon, 458 b, after dialu/ein th\n sunousi/an in 457 c.

tou)nanti/on: the heaping up of such kindred ideas as au)=, au)=qis, pa/lin is not uncommon (see examples in Kr. 69, 12); tou)nanti/on means “on the contrary”; au)=, “on the other hand”; metabalo/nta (intransitive), “vice versa.”
ei) a)/ra: if, assuming the ordinary view to be the correct one (a)/ra).—
tina\: is object, and with it ei\/te . . . o(ntinou=n is in apposition. e)xqro/s is a personal enemy, as distinguished from pole/mios, a national enemy.
e)a\n mo/non mh\ au)to\s kte(.: because experiencing injury might be held as a kind of substitute for the punishment due for inflicting it.
au)to/s: refers to the subject of kakw=s poiei=n, which is indefinite.—
tou=to kte(.: the insertion of this clause, which is due to the preceding e)a\n mo/non kte(., defers the completion of the sentence to panti\ tro/pw| kte(.

pra/ttonta kai\ le/gonta: the two species of activity do not exclude each other, for the effect of pra/ttein may be more thoroughly completed by le/gein, and vice versa.—The acc. case is in agreement with the unexpressed indefinite agent of paraskeuaste/on. On the case of the agent with verbal adjs., see G. 281, 2; H. 991 a.

o(/pws mh\ dw=| kte(.: this sentence is remarkable on account of the variety of the constructions found after o(/pws,—three out of the perhaps eight varieties being found, viz. subjv., a)/n with subjv., fut. indic. We should not attempt to make any sharp distinctions here, for Plato is capable of changing the construction for the sake of variety. We may, however, say this much. o(/pws mh\ dw=| is purely final, the conjunction not
differing from i(/na. When the delinquent is brought before the judge, there is some doubt as to his escape, and o(/pws a)/n (equiv. to e)a/n pws) gives expression to this doubt. In the long sentence following the a)/n gradually fades away, and the most common relative construction with the fut. indic. closes the series. On ei) de\ mh/ after e)a/n, see on 502 b.

e)a\n de\ e)/lqh|: in thus stating the opposite alternative, Socrates takes for the moment the standpoint of the orators. That it is only for the moment is seen from Crito 49 c ou)/te a)ntadikei=n dei= ou)/te kakw=s poiei=n ou)de/na a)nqrw/pwn, ou)d' a)\n o(tiou=n pa/sxh| u(p) au)tw=n.
a)nali/skh|: to make the statement of the wrong complete, the way in which the money is wasted is added.

XXXVII. On the role assigned to Callicles here, see Introd. § 15. After Polus has shown himself in capable of maintaining his views of rhetoric against the superior dialectical skill of Socrates, Callicles enters the discussion with a thought quite similar to the one with which Polus had entered it in 461 b. The view of life on which all of Socrates' deductions rest is so abhorrent to his innermost nature and all his hitherto cherished ideas that he cannot be brought to look upon the principles here advocated as the earnest convictions of a reasonable man. He does not, however, rush into the lists so roughly as Polus, but, being a more polished man of the world, turns first to Chaerephon, who is thoroughly acquainted with Socrates' views. He, however, wittily refers him to the master, in the same words with which Callicles himself had in 447 c referred Socrates to Gorgias.

nh\ tou\s qeou\s a)ll' e)piqumw=: a)lla/ is used after an expression of asseveration, as in 463 d. The words of Chaerephon contain the challenge, “Why don't you rather turn to Socrates himself?” to which Callicles replies, “But that is just what I do desire.” In Callicles' manner of expression we discern his excitable nature as well as his strong faith in his own views, which he is the more surprised to find opposed, not only by Socrates, but also by Chaerephon. Artistically also his words form the text for the discussion which follows.
fw=men . . . pai/zonta: this is a very unusual construction for fhmi/. G. 260, 2, N. 1.

a)natetramme/nos: cf. a)natre/pein ta\ pra/gmata, po/lin, oi)ki/an. For if you be both in earnest, and the thing which you say prove to be (tugxa/nei) true, would not the only (a)/llo ti h)\) conclusion be that the manner of life of us men has been entirely upside down?

tw=n a)nqrw/pwn: is emphatically added because Callicles does not intend that under h(mw=n only a limited circle shall be understood. Cf. Ar. Plut. 500 w(s me\n ga\r nu=n h(mi=n o( bi/os toi=s a)nqrw/pois dia/keitai.
pa/nta ta\ e)nanti/a: like pa=n tou)nanti/on, quite the contrary.

ei) mh/ ti kte(.: Socrates recognizes indeed the opposition in their views of life, but refers it to the different exercise of a common feeling, —love,—which varies according to the difference in the objects to which it is directed. The comparison of love of wisdom with other varieties of human love is often found in Plato, e.g. Phaedo 68 a.

pa/qos: denotes a state of mind brought about by external influences. According to cause and circumstances it may be love, hate, admiration, or scorn. But no variety is peculiar to any single man; this is made clear by the explanatory clause inserted between pa/qos and to\ au)to/.
i)/dion: contains in itself an idea of comparison, like a)/llo e(/teron, and hence takes h)/.

tau)to/n ti: the pa/qos experienced by each one, is first roughly characterized as “about the same thing,” and later clearly defined by
the explanatory e)rw=nte kte(. The variation from the pl. to the dual is interesting. The lack of a first person dual compels the first pl., with its accompanying partic. peponqo/tes, while the following dual emphasizes the exact similarity of the two experiences.

*)alkibia/dou: the mental and moral training of the rising youth was largely directed by prominent older men with whom they associated, usually according to individual preference. One of these prominent teachers, and one who made it the business of his life, was Socrates, and among the young men who clustered around him and followed his conversations was Alcibiades, whom Socrates greatly loved for his mental gifts. Owing to his great beauty he was jestingly called Socrates' sweetheart (ta\ paidika/). Cf. Prot. init. *po/qen, w)= *sw/krates, fai/nei; h)\ dh=la dh\ o(/ti a)po\ kunhgesi/ou tou= peri\ th\n *)alkibia/dou w(/ran. This is the point of the allusion here.

dh/mou: has two allusions. The son of Pyrilampes, a rich Athenian and friend of Pericles, was called Demus. Like his father, he is reported to have been especially beau tiful, and is also mentioned by Ar. Vesp. 97 ff. as a much admired sweetheart. This fact Socrates skilfully uses to characterize Callicles' relation to the Athenian demus. This people needed, like a boy, a leader and guide; but the orators, instead of governing it, regulated their actions according to its whims.
tou= *purila/mpous: is of course to be understood in the usual way, like tou= *kleini/ou. Cf. to\n *purila/mpous below, and 513 b.
ai)sqa/nomai . . . ou) duname/nou: on the gen. partic. construction see GMT. 884-6; H. 742, 982.
deinou=: is often joined with le/gein, in order to describe a skilful orator, but can also be used without this addition, in the sense of “skilful,” “clever.”
a)/nw kai\ ka/tw: like Lat. sur

sum deorsum, with metastre/fein, stre/fein (511 a), metaba/llein, metapi/ptein (493 a) denotes a changeable and uncertain course of action. Variations of the phrase are a)/nw te kai\ ka/tw, and more often a)/nw ka/tw.
bouleu/masi: i.e. the fanciful plans and designs of boys.
ei) bou/loio: which probably was hardly to be expected.
e(/tera toiau=ta: cf. above (24), toiau=ta e(/tera.
tw=n e(te/rwn paidikw=n: in the above-cited passage from Phaedo (68 a) we find the word a)nqrwpi/nwn in the same connexion.
e)/mplhktos: unstable. Cf. Soph. Ai. 1358 toioi/de me/ntoi fw=tes e)/mplhktoi brotw=n.
a)/llwn . . . tw=n au)tw=n: gen. of characteristic is not common in Greek, and is always predicate. Cf. Thuc. i. 113 o(/soi th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs h)=san. See H. 732 d.

parh=sqa de/: change from the rel. to the independent construction. See on 452 d. Here, however, we must supply the pronoun (au)toi=s) to which legome/nois is a subordinate temporal partic. equiv. to o(/te e)le/geto. We might translate de/ “although.”
e)ce/legcon w(s kte(.: see on 467 a. Here, to “prove by confuting her.”

o(/per a)/rti e)/legon: refers to 480 e ou)kou=n h)\ ka\kei=na lute/on h)\ ta/de a)na/gkh sumbai/nein. The transition from the personal to the material object is made much easier by the meaning of the verb e)ce/legcon.
ma\ to\n ku/na: the addition of to\n *ai)gupti/wn qeo/n is a humorous allusion to the animal worship of the Egyptians. See Apol. 21 e. The omission of the art. with *ai)gupti/wn is regular.

*kalliklh=s: the use of the proper name in contrast with the pronoun soi/, and its close connection with the address w)= *kallikleis, is intended to emphasize as sharply as
possible the inner conflict which must continue to rage in Callicles' soul, so long as one opinion has not decisively vanquished the other.
a)narmostei=n: applies especially to imperfection in the general harmony, while diafwnei=n is used of the discord between single tones. Two different principles exert their effects upon the soul.

xorhgoi/hn: this liturgy, which has been already mentioned in note on 472 a, was of course not possible for Socrates, and could be only for the rich. But in proportion as a victory in this kind of musical competition was looked upon as a great honor, so a failure was a great humiliation. The opt. is ideal, and to be translated “which I might conduct.”
ma=llon: frequently follows a comp. to reiterate the idea with a slight modification (rather than). Cf. below, 487 b, Phaedo 79 e, and see for other examples, Rid. § 166.

neanieu/esqai: “to act like a wild young man.” Callicles has in mind especially the insolent, bold, and reckless conduct of the rich and proud Athenian youth. This is usually the meaning of the adjective neaniko/s (so in our dialogue, 508 d, 509 a), which, however, is sometimes used only of the freshness and the vigor of youth, as below, 485 e. The verb applies especially to the training of the youth by the Sophists, which leads them to light and idle speeches and to a defense of the most conflicting principles without having regard unto the higher and earnest problems of life. Cf. Phaedrus 235 a kai\ e)fai/neto dh/ moi neanieu/esqai e)pideiknu/menos w(s oi(=o/s te w)\n tau)ta\ e(te/rws te kai\ e(te/rws le/gwn a)mfote/rws ei)pei=n a)/rista.

dhmhgo/ros, dhmhgorei=n: indicate dissatisfaction, sometimes with the length of the speeches, as opposed to diale/gesqai, i.e. 519 d, e, Prot. 329 a, 336 b; sometimes, as here and in 494 d, with the means employed by those who, unconcerned for the truth, seek only the approbation of the multitude. In the mouth of Callicles, who is the real dhmhgo/ros, this reproach sounds very strange, especially with the addition w(s a)lhqw=s. It is a kind of unconscious self-criticism.
pro\s se/: cf. 485 b below, and Apol. 21 c pro\s o(\n e)gw\ toiou=to/n ti e)/paqon, “at whose hands I had some such experience.”
dida/coi: the fut. opt. is only found in indir. disc. as a representative of the fut. indicative. It is postHomeric, the first example occurring in Pindar.

au)to/n: repeats with emphasis the subject *gorgi/an, which is already expressed. Cf. Xen. Cyr. i. 3. 15 peira/somai tw=| pa/ppw| a)gaqw=n i(ppe/wn kra/tistos w)\n i(ppeu\s summaxei=n au)tw=|. The clause with o(/ti is causal, and is explanatory of dia\ to\ e)/qos tw=n a)nqrw/pwn, which is to be connected with fa/nai, not with dida/cein.
a)gapa=n: cf. 461 c o(\ dh\ a)gapa=|s.
w(/s ge/ moi dokei=n: as it seemed to me. The phrase is found sometimes with w(s as here and Hdt. ii. 124; sometimes without, as Meno 81 a; e)/moige dokei=n Soph. El. 410.

sumpodisqei\s e)pestomi/sqh: a combination of two metaphors, both of which refer to a horse which has been caught by a noose, and then guided according to a strange will by a bridle which has been forced into its mouth. In the same way Polus, by that unlucky admission, allowed himself to be noosed, and was thus compelled to follow the lead of Socrates, wherever that might take him.
tw=| o)/nti: affirms the justice of the accusation made against Socrates by Polus.

fortika/: a word not uncommon in Plato, is used in Euthyd. 287 a of insidious catch-questions. See on Apol. 32 a, where combined with dikanika/ it is used of the tediousness of those detailed discussions from which Socrates, after the manner of an orator before a court, seeks to draw his proofs. Here Callicles probably wants to indicate the vulgarity of such illustrations and talks, as being fit only for the uncultured multitude. The rel. sentence a(\ fu/sei kte(. is connected epexegetically with toiau=ta, and thereby the conclusion from the special case is made of general application. It was indeed from the idea of the kalo/n that Socrates drew the
whole argument with which he refuted Polus.
fu/sei me\n, no/mw| de/: the opposition of natural right to conventional right (law) was first definitely maintained by Hippias of Elis. Cf. Prot. 337

c d, Xen. Mem. iv. 4. 14. After him this principle was accepted and made a commonplace by all the Sophists. It is probable that Gorgias himself did not defend it, but his teaching can be traced back to it. This principle Callicles now proceeds to unfold. Of kindred import is also the discussion between Alcibiades and Pericles, related by Xen. Mem. i. 2. 40 ff.

o(\ dh\ kai\ su\ tou=to to\ sofo\n kte(.: to\ sofo/n (artifice, trick) is used somewhat scornfully in the sense in which the sophistical Eristics employed it, with whom Callicles puts Socrates on a level. Hence he also employs towards him the word kakourgei=n, which was used among the Eristics to denote crafty tripping in discussion. Cf. Rep. i. 341 a ou)/te ga\r a)/n me la/qois kakourgw=n, by which Thrasymachus declares his ability to defend himself against such unfair treatment; so ib. 338 d. The same feel ing determines the choice of the compound u(perwta=n “to slip artfully into the question,” “ask slily”.
tou=to to\ sofo/n: is epexegetic to o(/.
e)a\n de\ kte(.: supply the same verbs as are found in the first member of the sentence.
w(/sper au)ti/ka: as, for example. See on 472 d.

e)diw/kaqes kata\ fu/sin: ‘you followed up what he meant “conventionally” by arguing upon it in the “natural” sense.’ Cope. I.e. Socrates had treated the concession of Polus, and drawn his results from it, as if Polus had therein conceded that to do wrong was by nature, i.e. of itself, more ugly than to suffer wrong. “For —so runs the argument of Callicles —that which is by nature ugly coincides with what is evil, which latter, however, is the suffering of wrong. But we must not conclude from this that what is by law the more ugly is also the greater evil.”
to\ a)dikei=sqai: as the passage stands, must be considered as explanatory of the preceding, without close construction.
ou)de\ ga/r: leads over to a criticism of Socrates' view p e r s e, the question thus far having been his manner of procedure in the case of Polus.

w(=| krei=tton kte(.: in the opinion of the masses, the same is true of all who are without the enjoyments of life. Cf. Phaedo 65 a. The regular relative after an indefinite (tino/s) is o(/stis, which frequently has a conditional idea, and then takes the cond. neg. mh/. H. 699 a.
au)to\s . . . kh/dhtai: the same ideas were presented in 480 a. Here every man is expressly thrown upon his own resources and the state abolished.
a)ll' , oi)=mai kte(.: this exposition of the origin of conventional right is designed by Callicles to show the superior authority of the natural right which he advocates.
