oi( tiqe/menoi: “the law-makers.” The active is used of the law-giver. On the force of the article with the predicate, see H. 669 a; G. 141, N. 8.

kai\ oi( polloi/: it is just this addition which contains the most important point, according to Callicles' real view, though he keeps it in the background, because for him the contrast between stronger and weaker is of more value for his argument. It is this begging of the question to which Socrates first turns his attention in 488 c ff.
pro\s au(tou/s: usually we find ble/pontes, but the preposition itself is sufficient. Kr. 68, 39, 5.

e)pai/nous, yo/gous: the people not only makes laws,—i.e. commands and prohibitions, the transgression of which is punished by penalties,—but also expresses in manifold ways, by offices, honors, etc., its judgment on the value of men and actions.
Another case of explanatory asyndeton.
e)rrwmeneste/rous: how completely this word has become an adjective is shown by the fact that it is the only partic. which admits comparison.
pleonektei=n: is an expression for every effort of self-aggrandizement, and was often used as a political watchword in opposition to i)sonomi/a. Cf. to\ i)/son, two lines below.

a)gapw=si: in mockery, because satisfaction is a sign of weakness. Cf. what Adimantus says in Rep. ii. 366 c oi)=den o(/ti plh
 ei)/ tis qei/a| fu/sei dusxerai/nwn to\ a)dikei=n h)\ e)pisth/mhn labw
 a)pe/xetai au)tou=, tw=n ge a)/llwn ou)dei\s e(kw
 di/kaios, a)ll) u(po\ a)nandri/as h)\ gh/rws h)/ tinos a)/llhs a)sqenei/as ye/gei to\ a)dikei=n, a)dunatw=n au)to\ dra=n.—
to\ i)/son: Callicles is thinking of the fundamental principle of democratic states, the i)sonomi/a and i)so/ths of all.
XXXIX.
au<*>to/: draws especial attention to the following clause, which it introduces. By its proximity to au)th/ this emphasis is still more increased.
a)mei/nw: is here probably used purposely instead of krei/ttw, as Callicles had in mind also the mental superiority of the rhetorically educated over the great multitude. Hence, too, dunatw/teron.

dhloi=: can be taken in construction with fu/sis, or, which is better, as an impersonal verb equiv. to dh=lo/n (dh=la/) e)stin. The subj. is the following o(/ti clause, whose own subj., tau=ta, has been attracted to the government of the leading verb.
pollaxou=: introduces facts in support of the general statement.—

kai\ e)n toi=s a)/llois zw/|ois: the law of nature is the principle which is at the basis of national law. Here is, moreover, an indication of the moral character of those who hold this view, in that they put the a)/nqrwpos on the plane of the zw=|on.

o(/lais tai=s po/lesi: in international relations this natural law (‘might makes right’) has preserved its force longer than in the intercourse of individual men; hence ge/nos is equiv. to gens. The clause following, o(/to . . . e)/xein, is explanatory of tau=ta o(/ti ou(/tws e)/xei.
ke/kritai: in 520 e neno/mistai is the word.
a)/rxein: is the legal, ple/on e)/xein the natural expression of the same idea.

e)pei\ poi/w| dikai/w| kte(.: is not purely neg., but has somewhat the sense: “What other right had Xerxes than that of nature?” The choice of examples shows that with this selfish, immoral view of life is connected also a lack of national feeling. Callicles himself feels the impropriety
of declaring Xerxes to be a)mei/nwn and dunatw/teros tw=n *(ellh/nwn, and therefore hastily seeks another example which will not arouse personal feeling.

a)/lla muri/a: is simply rhetorical exaggeration. The concluding summarizing clause deviates from the regular construction of the sentence, as also in a similar passage in Apol. 41 c e)pi\ po/sw| d' a)/n tis de/caito e)ceta/sai h)\ *)odusse/a h)\ *si/sufon, h)\ a)/llous muri/ous a)/n tis ei)/poi kte(.
oi)=mai: as well as i)/sws, a couple of lines below, merely softens the expression, without diminishing its positiveness. Cf. 473 a.

th\n tou= dikai/ou: if these words, which we would rather miss, are genuine, we have a case of word-play, which may be justified on the ground of the proposition above, h( de/ ge . . . a)dunatwte/rou. The same force must be assigned to tou= dikai/ou fu/sei below (484 c), though the form is different.
nai\ ma\ *di/a kata\ kte(.: a clever play upon the word no/mos. “Nature, too, has its law,—right and custom.”

h(mei=s: contains, by the implied contrast, a rebuke. Notice the heaping up of the participles, which, though connected with one verb, are subordinated one to another, quite after the Greek habit. See Kr. 56, 15, with notes.

pla/ttontes: the side-idea of artificiality and amateurishness easily attaches itself to this verb. Cf. Apol. 17 c meiraki/w| pla/ttonti lo/gous. It is applied to laws, as here, also Leg. iv. 712 b peirw/meqa kaqa/per pai=des presbu=tai pla/ttein tw=| lo/gw| tou\s no/mous.

e)k ne/wn lamba/nontes: cf. Apol. 18 b e)k pai/dwn paralabo/ntes. The usual word for ‘receiving into school’ is the compound. Cf. 516 b. The use of the simple verb here implies a forcible compulsory manner of treatment.

w(/sper le/ontas katepa/|dontes: the comparison describes with bitterness the suppression of the so-called natural freedom, in that it compares education to the taming of wild beasts (katadoulou/meqa). katepa/|dein applies to soothing by certain formulae, or charms; gohteu/ein to the employment of forms of magic and witchcraft. Meno uses the same expression regarding the dialectic proof of Socrates, 80 a kai\ nu=n, w(/s g' e)moi\ dokei=s, gohteu/eis me kai\ farma/tteis kai\ a)texnw=s katepa/|deis. In a jesting way, without feeling, e)pa/|dein is used in Phaedo 77 e, e)pw|dh/ in Charm. 155 e.
e)a\n . . . ge/nhtai: Callicles does not doubt that this future absolute ruler will come.

fu/sin i(kanh/n: “a nature which is equal to all difficulties.” There is no understatement, as in 480 a.—All the following expressions are chosen so as to be appropriate to the muchloved comparison with wild beasts. a)posei/esqai can apply both to the shaking off of any bond or yoke and to the throwing of his rider by a horse; diarrh/cas is used more of breaking a hedge or an enclosure than a halter, etc. a)porrh/cas would be more natural for the latter; cf. Hom. Z 507 desmo\n a)porrh/cas, which passage quite suits the view of Callicles.
diafugw/n: calls to mind what has been previously said by Polus (473 c).
katapath/sas: depicts the insolence of the victor to the vanquished. In *d 157 Homer makes Agamemnon say of the perjured Trojans kata\ d' o(/rkia pista\ pa/thsan.

gra/mmata kte(.: the gra/mmata denote, in contradistinction to the unwritten laws implanted in man by nature, the “written laws” which limit and regulate the exercise of the will; magganeu/mata “works of deceit and witchcraft,” which fetter the reason; e)pw|dai/ “incantations” which palsy the feelings. These ideas correspond in the reverse order to the preceding participles, katepa/|dontes, gohteu/ontes, le/gontes, and the participles just in advance a)poseisa/menos . . . diafugw/n are probably chosen with reference to them. All three ideas serve, moreover, to show from the various sides what objections can be made to the laws which are opposed to nature, and are hence crowded together for greater emphasis.
e)panasta/s: is used of one who has lain prostrate for a time and now unexpectedly shows his strength.—
a)nefa/nh: is ‘gnomic aorist.’ The single past example (aor.) serves as a norm for the general statement (pres.). H. 840; GMT. 155.
o( dou=los: as a result of katadoulou/meqa above, 483 e, “the one whom we brought up as a slave.”—
e)ce/lamye: shone forth in splendor, a poetical word also employed in Rep. iv. 435 a.

dokei= de/ moi: introduces a new element,—the authority of Pindar. Knowledge of the poets was a requirement of the culture of the period. Cf. Prot. 338 e. The last words of the fragment are restored by Bergk (Poet. Lyr. Gr. p. 344, ed. 3) from the citation of the Scholiast as follows:—
e)/rgoisin *(hrakle/os e)pei\ *ghruo/na bo/as *kuklwpi/wn e)pi\ proqu/rwn *eu)rusqe/os a)naith/tas te kai\ a)pria/tas h)/lasen.
Since we do not know the context in which these verses stand, Pindar's views cannot be determined from them with certainty; but they were probably based on the principles of religious belief. In this no/mos o( pa/ntwn basileu/s Pindar may be thinking of the power of that fate which is superior even to the gods themselves. —Geryones, son of Chrysaor (“lightning”) and the Oceanid Callirhoe (“beautiful stream”), was a giant with three bodies and three heads. He lived with his dog Orthros, or Orthos, on the fertile island Erytheia, and possessed great herds of cattle. These were stolen from him by Hercules in the expedition celebrated in the story. Cf. Preller, Mythol.^{2} ii. 202-216.
e)ndeiknu/nai: is used of all kinds of practical proof; a)podeiknu/nai, of demonstration.

ou)k e)pi/stamai: says Callicles, because the exact words of the poem are not at his command. The verb has the same meaning in Port. 339 b, Phaedo 61 b. After a)pria/tas Callicles breaks off, intending to give the sense of what follows, and resumes the idea with ou)/te pria/menos.
h)la/sato: the use of the middle instead of the active is normal, but is well suited to Callicles' conception.
w(s tou/tou o)/ntos: the use of w(s ascribes this view to Hercules, as his basis of action. tou/tou is explained by the clause kai\ bou=s kte(.
ta\ tw=n xeiro/nwn kte(.: notice the rhetorical position.

to\ me\n ou)=n a)lhqe/s: introduces a new topic, that of the value of philosophy. Its connexion with the preceding lies in the fact that Callicles looks upon philosophy as the hindrance which prevents Socrates from recognizing the truth of what he says.
e)pi\ ta\ mei/zw: is indefinite, and is employed only to depreciate philosophy and relegate it to a lower plane, as is evident from Callicles' further exposition.
xari/en: with a pleasing condescension, recognizing its merit,—but what a poor merit! Cf. 485 b.

e)n th=| h(liki/a|: “in the time of life suitable for it.” What period this is can be gathered from the expressions po/rrw th=s h(liki/as and peraite/rw tou= de/ontos. The words metri/ws and a(/yhtai are also designedly chosen.
diafqora/: Callicles assumes almost the tone of an oracle.

a)/peiron gegone/nai: “a man cannot practise philosophy and at the same time fulfil the requirements of his civil position.”
The kalo\s ka)gaqo/s, according to the idea of Callicles, is shown by the addition of eu)do/kimos, to be the man who, through practical activity, obtains reputation and honor. With me/llw we find the pres. and fut. almost equally common, the aor. exceptional.

tw=n no/mwn: that Callicles is laying great stress on the knowledge of the laws in this passage, seems at first sight inconsistent with the view which he has already expressed; but in reality he has shifted his point of view but little, since he advocates the study of the laws, not for the purpose of following them, but as being necessary for the work of the practical statesman, whether he be in the senate or assembly, or hold any public position. The force, therefore, of no/moi is much that of our “constitution.” The lo/goi oi(=s dei= xrw/menon kte(. belong to the department of jurisprudence in both its divisions, individual and national. cumbo/laia is characterized in Rep. i. 333 a, as the variety of koinwnh/mata (i.e. mutual intercourse, trade, and commerce) in which dikaiosu/nh is of especial value. It denotes, accordingly, treaties and the law-business connected with them.
tw=n h(donw=n kte(.: the enjoyment of life consists, according to Callicles, in satisfying the appetites.
tw=n h)qw=n: can be considered as a general comprehensive term, in so far as we understand by it the peculiar traits of mind and character which impart individuality to a man.
w(/sper ge: makes a concession, in order to anticipate the retort which could easily be made here.

diatriba/s: is used especially of philosophical discussions. Cf. Apol. 37 c ou)x oi(=oi/ te e)ge/nesqe e)negkei=n ta\s e)ma\s diatriba\s kai\ tou\s lo/gous, Charm. 153 a h)=|a e)pi\ ta\s cunh/qeis diatriba/s.
sumbai/nei: is in point.

to\ tou= *eu)ripi/dou: inasmuch as his works abounded in gnomes and sententious sayings, and he himself was not far removed from the sophistic way of looking at things, Euripides was frequently quoted by sophists and orators, and also by Socrates (Plato). The present passage is from the lost tragedy Antiope. See below, 485 e.

e)n tou/tw| kai\ e)pi\ kte(.: the demonstratives are antecedent to the adverbial rel. clause with i(/na, “in which each one is most successful.” The words lampro/s . . . e)pei/getai, by omitting what would not be missed, and reading ka)pi/ for kai\ e)pi/, form a trimeter. Cf. Ar. Vesp. 1431 e)/rdoi tis h(\n e(/kastos ei)dei/h te/xnhn.
i(/na tugxa/nei: is to be compared with o(/pou a)\n h)=| to show the difference between definite and indefinite antecedent.
au)to\s au(tou= be/ltistos: the gen. with sups. may be an extension of the gen. with comparatives. See H. 644 a.
a)mfote/rwn: i.e. philosophy and politics.

o(/son paidei/as xa/rin: as far as it serves the purpose of education. Cf. Rep. iii. 403 e o(/son tou\s tu/pous, Euthyd. 273 a th
 fu/sin o(/son. See H. 719 b; G. 160, 1. The opposite is e)pi\ te/xnh|, or something similar, as seen from Prot. 312 b tou/twn su\ e(ka/sthn ou)k e)pi\ te/xnh| e)/maqes, w(s dhmiourgo\s e)so/menos, a)ll' e)pi\ paidei/a|, w(s to
 i)diw/thn kai\ to
 e)leu/qeron pre/pei. Culture was the watchword of the time.
kai\ ou)k ai)sxro/n: change from the kalo/n to the katage/laston.

pa/sxw pro/s: as 482 c. The comparison, however sensible the thought therein expressed may be, still is not in place here. For it describes only the subjective impression which philosophizing at different periods of life makes on Callicles. It is therefore only a rhetorical reaffirmation of the statement that philosophy is not appropriate for a mature man. In his mind, however, Callicles has still a tertium comparationis which he does not express, viz. the objects of philosophical research afford no real interest, hence resemble paidi/a. Further, so much trouble about single ideas is like yelli/zesqai (stammering). On the contrary, safw=s diale/gesqai (le/gein) is the business of orators.

e)leuqe/rion: Callicles speaks of stammering thus, as contrasted with the restraint which the child must exercise in order to learn to speak clearly, which latter seems to him to be douloprepe/s. Note also the contrast in xari/en and pikro/n.
para\ ne/w| kte(.: the companion of (para/) a youth. The duplication of the idea is also found in Prot. 315 d ne/on ti e)/ti meira/kion.

e)leu/qeron: is amplified and illustrated by the following clause, ou)deno\s a)ciw/sonta kte(. Philosophy gives the youth an opportunity for the practice in mental gymnastics, which is as yet denied him in public life, and thus prepares him for his future career as a speaker in the assembly.
dh/: deictic. This is just the case about which Callicles raises the question.
dei=sqai: is still stronger than a)/cion, and declares that it is to the man's own interest to be so dealt with.

ta\ me/sa th=s po/lews: is emphasized together with the a)gora/, in opposition with the following e)n gwni/a|. Cf. Cic. de Or. i. 13. 57 quibus (philosophis) ego ut de his rebus in angulis consumendi otii causa disserant cum concessero, illud tamen oratori tribuam, etc.
o( poihth/s: the poet, of course, is Homer. He says, I 440, nh/pion, ou)/pw ei)do/q' o(moii/oo ptole/moio | ou)d) a)gore/wn, i(/na t) a)/ndres a)riprepe/es tele/qousin.—

katadeduko/ti: “in retirement,” as contrasted with the brilliant life of the public man. The word is used somewhat differently in Rep. ix. 579 b, where it is said of a tyrant ou)/t' a)podhmh=sai e)/cestin (au)tw=|) ou)damo/se ou)/te qewrh=sai o(/swn dh\ kai\ oi( a)/lloi e)leu/qeroi e)piqumhtai/ ei)si, katadedukw\s de\ e)n th=| oi)ki/a| ta\ polla\ w(s gunh\ zh=|.

meta\ meiraki/wn: as contrasted with association with men and with the whole people. It is evident that, in spite of Callicles' exaggeration, he is striking continually at Socrates' (and Plato's) occupation. Quite naturally and conversationally yiquri/zonta suggests again its opposite, which is added in e)leu/qeron fqe/gcasqai.
neaniko/n: for the meaning, see on 482 c above. Cf. Dem. Ol. iii. 32 e)/sti d' ou)de/pot), oi)=mai, me/ga kai\ neaniko\n fro/nhma labei=n mikra\ kai\ fau=la pra/ttontas.

After this general presentation of his views of philosophy, Callicles now proceeds to make a special application to Socrates' case, with apparent personal good-will, it is true, but still with the condescending mien of the superior man of the world.

o(/per o( *zh=qos pro\s to\n *)amfi/ona: the omission of pro\s se/ is hardly felt. Callicles cleverly illustrates his exposition of the opposition between the principles of practical life and this theoretical philosophizing by reference again to the already cited Antiope of Euripides. Antiope had borne to Zeus twin sons, Amphion and Zethus, but was afterwards taken by her uncle Lycus to Thebes, where she suffered for a long time the most cruel treatment at the hands of Ly
cus' wife, Dirce. Meanwhile, her sons were being brought up by a herdsman in the forest. Amphion devoted himself entirely to music, while the active and restless Zethus spent his time in hunting and the care of his herds. Finally Antiope escapes from her prison, and hurries to her sons. Dirce pursues, overtakes her, and is just in the act of having her bound to a wild steer, when the sons, who had been informed of their parentage by the herdsman, appear on the scene, rescue their mother from the hands of Dirce, and bind her to the steer instead. Dirce was then changed into a fountain. Amphion and Zethus attain the sovereignty in Thebes, and fortify it with walls. In this work Zethus contributed his great bodily strength, while Amphion's lyre drew after him the stones. This difference in character as related in the myth (Apollod. iii. 5. 5 *zh=qos me\n ou)=n e)pemelei=to bouforbi/wn, *)amfi/wn de\ kiqarw|di/an h)/skei) suggested to Euripides a dialogue between the brothers, wherein each praises his own calling to the disparagement of the other's. Callicles applies Euripides' words to the opposition between political and philosophical activity.

5 f. The words of Euripides are given by Nauck. Eur. frag.^{2} 185, as follows:—
. . . a)melei=s, w(=n se fronti/zein e)xrh=n: yuxh=s e)/xwn ga\r w(=de gennai/an fu/sin gunaikomi/mw| diapre/peis morfw/mati: . . . kou)/t' a)\n a)spi/dos ku/tei o)rqw=s o(milh/seias ou)/t) a)/llwn u(/per neaniko\n bou/leuma bouleu/saio/ ti.
Yet these lines do not contain all that seems poetical in this passage. In place of gunaikomi/mw| Callicles naturally, from his point of view, uses meirakiw/dei, which is quite different from neaniko/s in its meaning (boyish).
lo/gon: would give an opinion in counsels of justice.
u(pe\r a)/llou: is in the mouth of Callicles a very natural change of the word of the poet. The sing. of a)/llos, e(/teros, and of ti\s is easily used in a generic sense.

kai/toi: would naturally lead us to expect some qualification of his severe criticism; instead of this he glides over to the rhetorical question, which, while reaffirming his opinion, summons Socrates to decide. Cf. b below.
sh=|: equiv. to

sou=. Cf. 485 a eu)noi/a| th=| e(autou=, Apol. 20 e e)pi\ diabolh=|
th=| e)mh=|, Hom. T 321 sh=| poqh=|, Soph. O. C. 332 sh=| promhqi/a|. See H. 694; G. 147, N. 1.

tou\s po/rrw a)ei\ filosofi/as e)lau/nontas: has a poetic coloring, but also occurs in Xen. and in Crat. 410 e po/rrw h)/dh fai/nomai sofi/as e)lau/nein. Euthyp. 4 b. The gen. is partitive. See H. 757; G. 168.
a)ei\: when used with the art. and partic. has a distributive sense. In the present case its position between po/rrw and filosofi/as is also to be noted.

a)pa/goi: this was the summary process called a)pagwgh/, in which the guilty person, when caught in the act, was immediately arrested and brought before the Eleven. Cf. Apol. 32 b. The expression here is simply a rhetorical hyperbola, but it sounds prophetic in view of Socrates' trial later on, and was probably written designedly by the author. See Introd. § 10.
a)dikei=n: the pres. is the customary tense in accusations. Apol. 19 b, 24 b.

oi)=sq' o(/ti: parenthetical, with no effect on the construction, much in the same way as the English phraseological ‘you know.’ The Greek expression is, however, not so colorless as the English, but assumes a recognition of the truth of the observation.
ei)liggiw/|hs, xasmw=|o: vividly portray the confusion and terror of the prisoner.
o(/ti ei)/pois: this opt. and the preceding xrh/saio both represent deliberative subjvs. GMT. 186.
a)naba/s: the regular expression for appearing before a court. Its origin may have been from the location of the court; cf. Lat. descendere in forum and Apol. 17 d, 33 d.
kathgo/rou tuxw/n: “if chance so willed it.” The words pa/nu fau/lou kai\ moxqhrou= are again designedly given to Callicles by Plato. Socrates' accuser would of necessity be such a man.

qanatou= tima=sqai: if the crime had no definite punishment fixed by law (a)gw\n a)ti/mhtos), the accuser proposed some special punishment, for which the accused was at liberty to offer a substitute, and the court had to accept one or the other. Cf. Apol. 36 b ff. and for the gen. see H. 746 b.
According to Nauck, Fr. 186, the following citation from the Antiope runs thus:—
pw=s ga\r sofo\n tou=t' e)/stin, ei)/ tis eu)fua= labou=sa te/xnh fw=t) e)/qhke xei/rona.

perisula=sqai: implies that the one robbed is vanquished or defenceless, and contains the side-idea of insult added. This inf. as well as zh=n is used freely after e)/qhke to define in what respects the man who follows philosophy becomes xei/rwn.

a)/timon: ‘atimia’ in various degrees of completeness was a punishment attached to transgressions against the state. Complete ‘atimia’ involved deprivation of all civil rights. See Busolt, Gr. Alter. § 158, and cf. Andoc. i. 73-76. According to Callicles, Socrates will bring himself virtually into this condition by his continual philosophizing.

ei) . . . a)groiko/teron: see on 462 e. Cf. Lys. in Andoc. 24 proseyhfi/sasqe u(mei=s au)to\n (sc. to\n a)/timon) ei)/rgesqai th=s a)gora=s kai\ tw=n i(erw=n w(/ste mh\ a)dikou/menon u(po\ tw=n e)xqrw=n du/nasqai di/khn labei=n.

e)pi\ ko/rrhs tu/ptonta: a blow on the head was considered especially dishonorable.—ko/rrh (old Attic ko/rsh), ko/rh, de/rh, and a)qa/rh are the sole exceptions to the rule which requires a after r in Attic.
Callicles closes with a further citation from the Antiope, which Nauck, Fr. 188, gives thus:—
a)ll' e)moi\ piqou= pau=sai melw|dw=n, polemi/wn d' eu)mousi/an a)/skei: toiau=t) a)/eide kai\ do/ceis fronei=n, ska/ptwn, a)rw=n gh=n, poimni/ois e)pistatw=n, a)/llois ta\ komya\ tau=t) a)fei\s sofi/smata, e)c w(=n kenoi=sin e)gkatoikh/seis do/mois.

e)le/gxwn: is probably, like the corresponding word in the quotation, to be considered as a verb, since the contrast lies not in a single word, but in the whole following clause. Similarly Thrasymachus says, Rep. i. 336 c, mhde\ filotimou= e)le/gxwn. The verb, used absolutely, designates the kind of philosophical activity which Socrates has just practised against Polus. Cf. 472 b.

eu)mousi/an: was appropriate in Zethus' speech, as he wished to show his brother wherein the eu)mousi/a, which he sought in kiqarw|di/a, was really to be found; less so in Callicles', who probably is thinking rather of eu)bouli/a. The contrast to fronei=n would be lhrei=n or fluarei=n. Hence Callicles substitutes lhrh/mata and fluari/as (trifling and prattling) for sofi/smata.

komya/: witty, subtle, often used with an unfavorable connotation, both of persons and things; but it
is applied especially to the quibbles of the Sophists and Eristics. Cf. komyeu/esqai in Lach. 197 d.
ta\ mikra\ tau=ta: i.e. those subtle distinctions of words and ideas which in Callicles' view yield no advantage; while political activity and its results —these are ta\ mei/zw (484 c above).
bi/os: as opposed to kenoi=si do/mois means “means of livelihood,” an abundance of the good things of life.
do/ca: contrasted with a)/timon zh=n.
The delicate irony which characterizes the reply of Socrates is in striking contrast with the rudeness with which Callicles began, in 482 c above, the exposition of his view of life.
xrush=n: is pred. of th\n yuxh/n. “If the soul which I have were of gold.”
ou)k a)\n oi)/ei me a(/smenon: the main idea lies in a(/smenon.
tina\ tw=n li/qwn: equiv. to the more common ba/sanos alone.
h(=|: after li/qwn instead of ai(=s. Cf. 521 d.
e)/mellon kte(.: ‘The relative fut. after an unreal conditional is e)/mellon with the infinitive.’ Gildersleeve. Cf. Isae. ii. 25.

o(mologh/seien: the choice of this expression in the comparison is due to the nature of the discussion. The testing which Socrates is undergoing at the hands of Callicles must end in o(mologei=n (cf. e a)/n moi su\ o(mologh/sh|s).

kalw=s teqerapeu=sqai: leads back to the idea of qerapei/a th=s yuxh=s already discussed in 464 b above, and thus immediately prepares the way for making progress in the investigation. Cf. 487 a.—The subject of teqerapeu=sqai must be supplied from moi/.
e(rmai/w|: all unexpected gains (ke/rdos a)prosdo/khton) were supposed to come from Hermes, who had among other surnames that of kerdw=|os.

a)/n moi kte(.: we miss the less
an object to o(mologh/sh|s since the idea is made especially prominent by the following tau=ta. Cf. 487 e e)a/n ti su\ e)n toi=s lo/gois o(mologh/sh|s moi.
doca/zei: is a vox media. The same activity of the soul may, according to circumstances, lead to error or to truth. Cf. also do/ca a)lhqh/s and yeudh/s.—
h)/dh: at once (jam), without need of further discussion.
tri/a a)/ra dei= e)/xein: must of necessity possess three qualities. The particle a)/ra shows that this lies in the nature of the matter.
polloi=s e)ntugxa/nw kte(.: Socrates gives examples in Apol. 21 b ff.
tw\ de\ ce/nw kte(.: Socrates says what follows with an irony which applies especially to Polus; but at the same time it is a significant criticism of the parrhsi/a of Callicles.
ma=llon: see on 482 c.
w(/ ge: the ge\ emphasizes the pronoun. The irony from here on is quite distinct, and no longer veiled.

dia\ to\ ai)sxu/nesqai tolma=|: an example of ‘oxymoron.’ Timidity and shame are not usually the basis of boldness. The opposite of tolma=| is implied. The reference to 483 a is unmistakable: e)a\n ou)=n tis ai)sxu/nhtai kai\ mh\ tolma=| le/gein a(/per noei=, a)nagka/zetai e)nanti/a le/gein.
au)tw=n au)to\s au(tw=|: the position makes the contradiction beat heavily upon the ear.
peri\ tw=n megi/stwn: in contrast with 486 d ta\ mikra\ tau=ta. Cf. 484 c ta\ mei/zw.

pepai/deusai: see on paidei/as, 485 a. The addition of w(s polloi\ a)\n fh/saien *)aqhnai/wn implies, of course, the usual opposition of the many ignorant to the few capable, and this makes the tone of i(kanw=s almost bitter.

29 f. Of the three companions of Callicles we know but little. Tisander is mentioned only here. Andron appears in Prot. 315 c as a defender of Hippias. Nausicydes had, according to Xen. Mem. ii. 7. 6, acquired wealth from his business of a)lfitopoii/a. The deme Cholargus belonged to the tribe Acamantis, Aphidnae to Aiantis.
me/xri o(/poi: the only instance in Plato of me/xri with an adverb. Cf. Xen. Hell. iv. 7. 5 me/xri poi=.

e)ni/ka: has a somewhat comic effect, inasmuch as it brings before the mind the image of an earnest and thorough deliberation engaged in by some public body (i.e. the senate), followed by the putting of the question. These young men, however, judge philosophy without understanding it.
proqumei=sqai: epexegetic inf. to toia/de tis do/ca.
ei)s th\n a)kri/beian: recalls the ta\ mikra\ tau=ta above. This cautious decision contrasts remarkably with the e)leu/qeron and neaniko/n which Callicles defends in 485 c, d.

o(/pws mh\ . . . diafqare/ntes: the same state of mind is shown in the accusation brought later against Socrates, the second part of which ran thus: a)dikei= de\ kai\ tou\s ne/ous diafqei/rwn. That this was Callicles' judgment is shown by his words in 484 c ff. above.
e(tairota/tois: is found also in Phaedo 89 d.

o(/ti... lang=greek>au)to/s te fh\|s kte(.: this must not be considered as a valid example of o(/ti after fhmi/, which regularly takes the infinitive. The o(/ti clause precedes, and may have escaped the speaker's mind when he was about to make the collocation of au)to/s and lo/gos. The occurrence of two forms of le/gw in the same clause would likewise have been awkward.

oi(=os parrhsia/zesqai: you are disposed to free speech. See on 452 e. The omission of the first and second persons of the copula is rare. When ei)= is omitted, su/ is generally found. On the inf. see on 457 d.
e)/xei dh\ kte(.: with this Socrates recurs to what was said in 486 e.
44 ff.

a)\n sunexw/rhsas, sugxwrh/sais a)/n: the time is pushed into the fut. pf. by the previous bebasanisme/non e)/stai, and standing on this assumed plane, Socrates uses naturally the unreal past. The second clause is, as the au)= shows, a second thought, and being of general application, is put into the ideal (potential) optative. The whole sentence shows the narrow line that separates between unreality and ideality.
te/los th=s a)lhqei/as e(/cei: the gen., as in the Homeric phrases te/los ga/moio, qana/toio. Every effort must be directed to a terminus or completion. Here the end is perfect truth.
kalli/sth: refers to its value. It yields a rich return.
ti/ xrh\ e)pithdeu/ein: is the question about which the following discussion revolves. Cf. 492 d, 500 c, 512 e, 515 a, 521 a, 527 b, e.
kata\ to\n bi/on: refers, not to the period of life, but to the manner of living.
tou=to: Heindorf, followed by Cron, construes this word with the following verb. But it is more natural to look upon it as antecedent to the following sentence, know well this fact, etc.
ou)x e(kw/n: sc. according to the Socratic view as to the cause of wrong doing.

nouqetei=n: according to the rule, when a)/rxesqai is used with the inf. the inf. is emphasized; when with the partic. the ‘beginning’ is emphasized. So Theaet. 187 a h)rxo/meqa dialego/menoi, “we commenced the discussion on which we are still engaged.”—Here, as in 458 a, Socrates looks upon the correction of any erroneous views as a favor.
bla=ka: ‘implies feebleness both of mind and character, a dolt.’ Thompson.
e)pana/labe: we find a)nalabei=n in this sense in 506 c and Apol. 19 b.
su\ kai\ *pi/ndaros: see on 484 b.
a)/gein bi/a|: is a freer expression of the sense of Pindar's words.
mh\ le/geis: in spite of the addition of h)\ o)rqw=s me/mnhmai, the tendency of the question is towards a negative answer, as is also to be gathered from the a)lla\ of Callicles' answer.
to/te: refers to what was said in 483 d, e, and e)ndei/knusqai is accordingly imperfect infinitive.
h)=: appears to be the old Attic form.
w(s tau)to\n o)/n: on the assumption that, etc. See on 491 a.
h)\ e)/sti: begins the second member of the double question introduced by po/teron.
o( au)to\s o(/ros: cf. 470 b. The question is, whether the range of each idea is the same. A clear distinction (safw=s dio/rison) would obviate any false application.
to\ krei=tton kte(.: the position of the three terms is arbitrary; but Socrates seems to put first the two on which he lays most stress.
w(/sper . . . e)/leges: this appeal to the statement of Callicles reveals a contradiction between his statements, inasmuch as he had said above, 483 b, that the polloi/ were the a)sqenei=s.
w(s a)/rti au)= su\ e)/leges: the au)= draws attention again to the above w(/sper kai\ su\ a)/rti e)/leges. See 483 a-d.
o(/pws mh\ a(lw/sei: an ironical allusion to Callicles' reproaches of Gorgias and Polus in 482 e.

mh\ fqo/nei: a formula for entreaty and urging, still more frequent in the form mh\ fqonh/sh|s. Regularly mh/ with pres. imv. prescribes a neg.
course of action, with an aor. subjv. negatives a course of action. Socrates wishes at the outset to obviate any tendency to a refusal to answer, or hesitancy.
*kalli/kleis: the omission of the w)= is unusual.
bebaiou=sqai: to become strengthened in one's opinion. It is used with para/ to designate the quarter from which the influence comes; direct agency would require u(po/.—
i(kanou= diagnw=nai: competent to decide, with reference to 487 e.
le/gein, kathgorei=n: indir. disc. for impf. indicative. The kathgori/a proper begins with a(\ dh/. The use of dh/ implies a fact beyond controversy.
ou(tosi\ a)nh/r: Callicles with this turns to the surrounding listeners to give vent to his indignation. Cf. 467 b, 505 c.
ou) pau/setai fluarw=n: Callicles, who looks upon all philosophical activity as fluari/a, objects to having dialectical treatment applied to him.
ei)pe/ moi: the asyndeton renders the question especially incisive, and hence is a measure of excitement. The question ou)k ai)sxu/nei is a rhetorical imperative.
o)no/mata qhreu/wn: the same image is employed in Theaet. 166 c, with the substantive o)noma/twn qh/reusis to denote logomachy, where the matter at issue has been quite forgotten.

r(h/mati: in an expression. See on 450 e.
Callicles takes his stand on the identity, which he had maintained, of belti/wn and krei/ttwn, but reverses the relation of these words to each other; for while above he considered belti/wn to be synonymous with krei/ttwn, now he wishes krei/ttwn to be understood in the sense of be/lti/wn.
ou) pa/lai soi le/gw: he adds, in order to cover this change of conception. See on 456 a.

h)\ oi)/ei kte(.: Callicles allows himself to be clearly recognized as a member of that political party which applied to itself by preference the name oi( kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/, and which both during the latter part and after the conclusion of the Peloponnesian war obtained for a brief period the ascendency in Athens.
su/rfetos: from su/rw, sweep. Cf. the English colloquial words ‘off-scourings’ and ‘scum.’

a)ci/wn plh/n: without a following gen., instead of which we find tw=| sw/mati i)sxuri/sasqai by means of their bodily strength. Others construe tw=| with sw/mati, making the inf. depend upon some word of ability to be taken from a)ci/wn, but this is harsh.

au)ta\ tau=ta ei)=nai no/mima: construe with le/gein as an indignant disclaimer in the shape of a question. “Or think you I mean that if a rabble be got together, of slaves and all sorts of wretches, good for nothing unless perhaps for feats of physical strength, and these people say this or that, that these their mere dicta are to have the force of law?” Thompson.
ai)to\s pa/lai topa/zw: why So
crates does not express his conjecture, he has already explained in 453 b, c.
su/ ge: you, at least, for your part. Cf. what has just preceded in c.
a)lla\ pa/lin: in what precedes Callicles has really succeeded merely in eluding the expression of any positive view.
prodi/daske: the pro/ in composition indicates the progress or going forward, which ought to attend teaching.
a)pofoith/sw para\ sou=: run away from your school. Cf. 456 d.
ma\ to\n *zh=qon: with ma/ we always infer the negative. The allusion to Zethus, whom Callicles had brought forward as an authority, has a very comic effect.
a)ll' i)/qi: see on 451 a.

o(ra=|s kte(.: alludes to 489 c, where be/ltion and krei=tton were said by Callicles to be identical. Here he characterizes the belti/ous as a)mei/nous, showing, as Socrates declares in dhloi=s ou)de/n, that at this time there was no distinction of consequence between these two words.
ou)k e)rei=s: again asyndetic, as above in b.
fronimwte/rous: excludes the ambiguity which was still possible with i)sxuro/teros.
mh\ fronou/ntwn: the neg.is con
ditional.
r(h/mata: a clear reference to 489 b, c. r(h=ma has rather the force of “phrase.”
e)/xe dh/: see on 460 a.
e)n koinw=|: i.e. so that, as being public property, it must be distributed.

oi( me\n i)sxuroi\ kte(.: added be
cause it is just in the distribution of food that one would expect bodily strength to form the standard.
peri\ tau=ta: the acc. implies some mental activity.
e(kte/on: the verbal of e)/xw, which is quite rare, shows two forms, this and the more normal one sxete/os, also used by Plato.
tw=| me\n a)/rxein: this comes to him according to 490 a, because he is fronimw/teros. The dat. is one of cause. ne/mein is an action for which are necessary wisdom, justice, and self-control.
kataxrh=sqai: not misuse, but use up. kata/ frequently has the force of “completely” in composition. Kr. 68, 46, 10.
zhmiou=sqai: used metaphorically, of the natural result which follows the over-engorgement of the stomach with food.
tw=n me\n . . . tw=n de/: with refer ence to b.
tw=| belti/stw|: used instead of the pron. for the sake of the contrast with e)la/xiston.

peri\ siti/a: this is a very unusual construction. The gen. is the rule with peri\ after le/gw. Cron thinks it is calculated to define the region in which the speeches of Socrates move. The word fluari/as serves also to characterize all that precedes. Cf. 519 a lime/nwn kai\ newri/wn kai\ teixw=n kai\ fo/rwn kai\ toiou/twn fluariw=n, the companion passage to this one. Cf. also Dem. Ol. iii. 29 ta\s o(dou\s a(\s e)piskeua/zomen, kai\ krh/nas, kai\ lh/rous.
po/teron: the second member is to be supplied from the following question.
h)\ mh/ (sc. fa/qi): to be understood like ou)/ fhmi (nego).
manqa/nw: ironic; as if Socrates could by any means judge what Callicles did mean from a general statement of what he did not mean.
u(fantikw/taton: a sup. coined for the occasion.
periie/nai: sc. in order to show off in them; still stronger is the following (31) peripatei=n (“strut about”).
poi/wn i(mati/wn: expresses indignant contempt. Cf. Charm. 174 b a)=ra/ ge (oi)=de) to\ petteutiko/n; poi=on petteutiko/n;

fluarei=s e)(xwn: a manner of speech taken from the common life, and hence especially frequent in the comic poets. Cf. ti/ e)/xwn lhrei=s; (497 a), ti/ dh=ta e)/xwn stre/fei; (Phaedr. 236 e), ti/ dh=ta diatri/beis e)/xwn; (Ar. Eccles. 1151). e)/xwn seems to imply a kind of continual persistence. You still persist in talking nonsense.
toiau=ta, toia/de: correspond in usage to ou(=tos and o(de. The article divides the examples into classes.

w(s a)ei\ kte(.: an exclamation implying a taunt, which was so often directed against Socrates i.e. (according to Xen. Mem. iv. 4. 6) by the sophist Hippias, who receives about the same answer that Callicles does here, with the ironical addition: su\ d' i)/sws dia\ to\ polumaqh\s ei)=nai peri\ tw=n au)tw=n ou)de/pote ta\ au)ta\ le/geis. Cf. 482 a.

a)ei\ skute/as kte(.: Charicles, one of the thirty, irritated by some keen remark of Socrates, expresses himself similarly in Xen. Mem. i. 2. 37 ou)kou=n, e)/fh o( *swkra/ths, kai\ tw=n e(pome/nwn tou/tois tou= te dikai/ou kai\ tou= o(si/ou kai\ tw=n a)/llwn tw=n toiou/twn. nai\ ma\ *di/), e)/fh o( *xariklh=s, kai\ tw=n bouko/lwn ge.

w(s o)/nta to\n lo/gon: the acc. abs. is rare, except with impers. verbs. GMT. 853; G.278, 2; H.974. The inference here is that the assumption introduced by the w(s is untenable; in which case we more commonly have w(/sper.

peri\ ti/nwn: due to assimilation after peri\ tou/twn, for, acc. to the usage, we should expect peri\ ti/na after pleonektei=. Cf. Lach. 182 e oi(=s ou)de
 a)/llo me/lei h)\ tou=to zhtei=n, o(/ti a)
 maqo/ntes pleonektoi=en tw=n a)/llwn peri\ to
 po/lemon. The e)rei=s may also have had some effect. See on 449 d. For ou)kou=n e)rei=s, see on 489 e.
a)ll' e)/gwge kai\ pa/lai le/gw: see on 456 a and 489 c. Callicles' irritation shows itself again in the side-thrust, ou) skutoto/mous kte(.

tou\s krei/ttous oi(/ ei)sin: equiv. to tou/tous oi(\ krei/ttous ei)si/n. See Kr. 61, 6, 2; H. 878. Such prolepsis usually occurs after verbs which express recognition or make declarations. Here the relative clause is almost pleonastic, but this is the more in harmony with the excited feelings of Callicles.
ei)s . . . pra/gmata: denotes the object, as peri\ tau=ta (above 490 b) denotes the field, to which the fro/nhsis is directed; and from it we must take the subject of oi)koi=to.
i(kanoi\ o)/ntes kte(.: is to be considered as explanatory of a)ndrei=oi and fro/nimoi w)=sin.

e)gw\ de\ sou= tou)nanti/on: this use of sou=, with which we must
supply kathgorw=, is somewhat harsh after e)me/, with which it contrasts, and leads Cron to prefer to consider sou= as dependent upon tou)nanti/on, in the sense “the opposite of you,”—i.e. of what you say,—and the clause with o(/ti as epexegetic to tou)nanti/on, —a harsh and doubtful construction.
tou\s i)sxurote/rous: the art. is employed, because i)sxurote/rous is not merely a pred. to tou\s belti/ous kte(., but both ideas are considered as identical.
h(/keis e)/xwn: as 518 a. In English also we often say, ‘here you are with,’ etc.
tine/s: ‘ti\s may express indefiniteness of nature: “a sort of.”’ H. 702.

ei)pw\n a)palla/ghqi: relieve your mind by saying, tell and be done with it. Cf. below, e o(\ e)gw/ soi nu=n parrhsiazo/menos le/gw. The use of the aorist tense of the partic. may be simply a case of attraction; it certainly loses its connotation of past time, being practically identical with the time of the leading verb, as in Phaedo 60 c eu)= g' e)poi/hsas a)namnh/sas me. See GMT. 150, 845; H. 856 b.
tou=t' e)sti/n: does not refer to a)/rxein, but simply, as often, introduces the following clause.

ti/ de\ au(tw=n: the indefiniteness of the question shows that it is only designed to draw Callicles' attention to the necessity of some rule governing the actions of the krei/ttous to one another. According to the connexion we may supply either a)/rxein or ple/on e)/xein to govern the gen., or we may consider it as a free genitive. The idea of a man's governing himself is so entirely new to Callicles that he is unable to catch Socrates' meaning at first.
e(/na e(/kaston: the single concrete case to explain the principle.
ou)de\n poiki/lon: means that the question is about a simple matter, whereas the person addressed imag-ines something else behind the words.

w(/sper oi( polloi/: with this, Socrates calls in the authority of common usage to determine the meaning of e(autou= a)/rxein, which he defines by sw/frwn and e)gkrath\s e(autou=, with tw=n h(donw=n kte(. explanatory.
w(s h(du\s ei)=: is often used ironically.

h(du/s: corresponds best to our naive. Callicles means that Socrates still keeps the point of view of a naive—hence interesting (but cf. 485 b, c)—child, inasmuch as he has not yet laid aside his childish prejudice in favor of swfrosu/nh. Hence the words tou\s h(liqi/ous kte(. are a criticism of Socrates' view: “you mean those simple-minded fellows,— the temperate.” This passage shows that Callicles erases swfrosu/nh, as he did dikaiosu/nh, from the list of the virtues.
ou(/tw: we should naturally expect tou/tous. Of course there is a tinge of irony in the allusion to Cal licles' words.

pa/nu ge sfo/dra: sc. ou(/tw le/geis. Callicles, of course, means tou\s h/liqi/ous, and makes an effort in what follows to defend his words. For this purpose he unfolds his view of life more completely, and shows especially wherein he finds happiness. The beginning of his discourse bears a rhetorical stamp.

douleu/wn: not to be conceived literally of human servitude, but rather equiv. to a)rxo/menos and that too au)to\s u(f' e(autou=, which Callicles considers just as bad as if the slavery were to some one else, o(tw=|oun. The lot of thraldom is considered so unhappy that Callicles conceives douleu/wn, even in the sense which it has here, as the exact opposite to eu)dai/mwn. That selfcontrol is not consistent with the generally held idea of freedom is spoken plainly in Meno 86 d e)peidh\ de\ su\ sautou= me\n ou)d' e)pixeirei=s a)/rxein i(/na dh\ e)leu/qeros h)=|s, and is at the present day a principle of the opponents of the temperance movement.

kola/zein: in the sense of “discipline” is quite in place here. At the same time its use forms a link between this and the earlier discussion between Polus and Socrates. a)kolasi/a is the proper opposite to swfrosu/nh, and as such is praised by Callicles.
u(phretei=n: Callicles says this, without noticing that thereby the servitude (doulei/a) in which man stands to his appetites is recognized.
tou\s toiou/tous: viz. tou\s dunatou\s a)popimpla/nai kte(.
ai)sxro\n dh/: with ironical reference to ai)sxu/nhn.—
o(/per: introduces what follows. The reference is to 483 c ff.

oi(=s u(ph=rcen: whose fortune it was. The original meaning of u(pa/rxein, “to be as a foundation,” “to begin with,” becomes gradually weaker as time goes on. The dat. in the pred. here passes over into the acc. as subj. of the inf. (i(kanou/s and ei)=nai) as is frequently the case, especially in long periods. Kr. 55, 2, 5, 7. The cause here lies in the necessary addition of au)tou/s.

a)rxh/n tina kte(.: the word a)rxh/ can be applied to any position of power, whether in a democracy or not. Thuc. ii. 65. 9 says of Athens e)gi/gneto/ te lo/gw| me\n dhmokrati/a, e)/rgw| de\ u(po\ tou= prw/tou a)ndro\s (i.e. Pericles) a)rxh/. The idea of turanni/s is well known; cf. Nepos, Milt. 8. 3. dunastei/a combined with turanni/s is not infrequently (479 a, Thuc. iii. 62. 3) used of oligarchs, but it is also a designation of princes, both smaller and greater (524 e, 525 d).
ai)/sxion kai\ ka/kion: declare as strongly as possible the inappropriateness of the practice of virtue for such men; it becomes for them really a shame and an evil.

tou/tcis toi=s a)nqrw/pois: pur
posely placed at the end of the clause (as above dia\ th\n au(tw=n a)nandri/an), and to emphasize the contrast, a)nqrw/pwn, which is usually wanting, is added in the next clause after tw=n pollw=n.—

oi(=s e)co\n kte(.: such connexion of the subordinate to the principal clause is idiomatic in Greek and Latin. Cf. Symp. 174 e oi(= me\n ga\r eu)qu\s pai=da/ tina tw=n e)/ndon a)panth/santa a)/gein ou(= kate/keinto oi( a)/lloi. Nep. Thrasy. 4. 1 huic . . . corona a populo data est; quam quod . . . non vis expresserat nullam habuit invidiam. Notice the necessary shift in e)co/n and mhdeno\s . . . o)/ntos due to the change from impersonal to personal. The participles are both practically concessive, the neg. mh/ being due to the conditional coloring.
tw=n pollw=n kte(.: notice the assonance (pari/swsis) in no/mon, lo/gon, yo/gon.

tou= kalou=: is said with bitter irony. Callicles shows here, as well as in 486 b above, the code of morals prevalent at that time and which Xen. expresses in the praise awarded to Cyrus, Anab. i. 9. 11 fa/neros h)=n ei)/ ti/s ti a)gaqo
 h)\ kako
 poih/seien au)to
, nika=n peirw/menos.
h(\n fh\|s su\ diw/kein: as above 482 e fa/skwn th\n a)lh/qeian diw/kein.
e)pikouri/an: capacity to help (one's self); i.e. to provide means for pleasure and to ward off hindrances. So also e)pikourei=n and e)pi/kouros. Cf. below, the recapitulation of Socrates.

ta\ de\ a)/lla kte(.: the subject, which at first is only inferred as the opposite of the three qualities specified, is nearer specified first by the characteristic addition ta\ kallwpi/smata (affectations) and then by a definite expression which at the same time shows Callicles' opinion.
fluari/a kte(.: is predicate.
ou)k a)gennw=s: like gennai/ws 475 d, 521 a, transferred from its original application to the free independent conduct proper for a man of noble birth; hence equiv. to “spirited,” “brave.”
e)pece/rxei: an image from war. Cf. e)pixeirw=men 495 c.

tw=| lo/gw|: refers to the view just stated, the position defended. Cf. Prot. 345 d, where Socrates says of Simonides di) o(/lou tou= a)/|smatos e)pece/rxetai tw=| tou= *pittakou= r(h/mati. We may, however, consider e)pece/rxei as used absolutely and tw=| lo/gw| as dat. of accompaniment.
ei) me/llei tis (sc. toiou=tos ei)=nai)
oi(=on dei= (au)to\n sc. to\n a)/nqrwpon)
ei)=nai: the absence of the inf. after e)w=nta is strange; cf. 491 e above.

a(mo/qen ge/ poqen: Socrates wishes to settle beyond all cavil that Callicles sanctions the employment of all means, without limitation and in the broadest sense, to satisfy his desires. As e(toima/zein is in the same construction with kolaste/on, we must conceive an idea of obligation connected with it. Cf. Crito 51 c poihte/on . . . h)\ pei/qein.
th\n a)retg/n: the sole true virtue (manliness), which is recognized also by Callicles.
a)/ra: “it appears,” “according to your view.”

oi( mhdeno\s deo/menoi kte(.: the fundamental principle of the Cynic school (of Antisthenes), which also derived its origin from Socrates. Cf. Xen. Mem. i. 6. 10, where to the sophist Antiphon, who maintains similar principles to those of Callicles here, Socrates says e)/oikas th
 eu)daimoni/an oi)ome/nw| trufh
 kai\ polute/leian ei)=nai: e)gw\ de\ nomi/zw to\ me
 mhdeno\s dei=sqai qei=on ei)=nai, to\ d' w(s e)la/xiston e)gguta/tw tou= qei/ou.

oi( nekroi\ kte(.: Socrates mentions the prevalence of this view in Phaedo 65 a kai\ dokei= ge/ pou toi=s polloi=s a)nqrw/pois . . . e)ggu/s ti tei/nein tou= teqna/nai o( mhde\n fronti/zwn tw=n h(donw=n ai(\ dia\ tou= sw/mato/s ei)sin. Sophocles, however, makes the sorely afflicted Ajax say (Ai. 554 f.) e)n tw=| fronei=n ga\r mhde\n h(/distos bi/os, | e(/ws to\ xai/rein kai\ to\ lupei=sqai maqh=|s.
Now that Callicles has stated exactly the manner in which he looks at life, Socrates proceeds to contrast that view with his own, not directly
indeed, but by a series of comparisons and similes, which serve the double purpose of calming the feelings of the listeners and readers after the impassioned speech of Callicles and, by presenting these pictures to the fancy, of preparing their minds for the following dialectical argument.

*eu)ripi/dhs: the same poet to whom Callicles has several times appealed. Socrates also can quote for his own purpose. The passage is from the Polyidus, and has the second line completed by the words ka/tw nomi/zetai. Quite similar is a passage which has come down to us from another lost tragedy, the Phrixus, ti/s oi)=den ei) zh=n tou=q' o(\ ke/klhtai qanei=n, | to\ zh=n de\ qnh/|skein e)sti/. See Nauck, Fr. 639, 830.

e)/gwge kai\ h)/kousa/ tou: the following comparisons are probably taken from the book of Philolaus, a Pythagorean who, after having been driven from Italy, wandered to Thebes, and there engaged in teaching and writing. Socrates was acquainted with the Pythagorean teaching probably only orally, from association with his Theban friends Simmias and Cebes. For this reason Plato implies by the manner of expression that this knowledge, which Socrates himself in nowise valued, was as general as possible. See Thompson.

to\ me\n sw=ma/ e)sti sh=ma: this comparison, though ascribed to the Pythagoreans, is connected also with the Orphic saying that the body is the custodian of the soul. Plato combines both in the same manner in Crat. 400 b kai\ ga\r sh=ma/ tine/s fasin au)to\ (sc. to\ sw=ma) ei)=nai th=s yuxh=s. Cf. Phaedo 62 b.

th=s de\ yuxh=s tou=to: in order to continue the discussion, a distinction between the separate parts of the soul is necessary. This could not be given here scientifically; but as much as is needful is stated by the comparison. Elsewhere Plato distinguishes three parts of the soul,—to\ logistiko/n, to\ qumoeide/s (qumo/s), and to\ e)piqumhtiko/n. For his present purpose two are sufficient,—the really spiritual, the reason, and that part which clings greedily to the body; for the question to be decided is: Shall life be directed according to the nature of the soul or of the body?
metapi/ptein: the active is found in 481 d, e. Cf. 517 b metabiba/zein ta\s e)piqumi/as.
muqologw=n: “speaking in mythical (here allegorical) form,” in contradistinction with the dialectical method. Cf. Phaedo 61 e diaskopei=n te kai\ muqologei=n.—

komyo/s: of delicate perceptions. Often with irony, but not here. See on 486 c. *sikelo/s refers to Empedocles, *)italiko/s to Philolaus. Neither was able, in the infancy of the science, to clothe his profound thoughts in philosophical form. Cf. Cron-Dyer Introd. to Apol. §§ 3 and 8. *sikelo/s, and not *sikeliko/s, may be due to the old love song of Timocreon Rhodius, which began: *sikelo\s komyo\s a)nh\r | poti\ ta\n mate/r' e)/fa.
para/gwn tw=| o)no/mati: by a slight variation of the word. para/gein is otherwise used of etymologies which are effected by small variations in the sound.

dia\ to\ piqano/n te kai\ peistiko/n: Philolaus was very fond of such tricks of derivation (cf. Boeckh, Philolaos, p. 188). Both words are obviously, as was shown above by a)napei/qesqai and metapi/ptein, to be considered as passive, and applying to something that can be easily persuaded. In form piqano/n approaches closest to pi/qon, and hence stands first. It is usually active, yet it occurs also as a passive, i.e. Xen. Cyr. ii. 2. 10 piqanoi\ d) ou(/tws ei)si/ tines, w(/ste, pri\n ei)de/nai to\ prostatto/menon, pro/teron pei/qontai.—
peistiko/n: adapted and inclined to belief, presupposes also some persuasion.

a)noh/tous: is chosen here as the opposite of sw/frones, on account of its assonance with a)muh/tous, and denotes those who are under the control, not of the nou=s, but of the e)piqumi/a. a)mu/htoi, according to the regular usage, denotes those who are not initiated into the mysteries. Hence Plato applies it also, in Phaedo 69 c and Theaet. 155 e, to those who have not been initiated into wisdom, or Philosophy, which causes—as the mysteries were also designed to do—an actual inner purification of the soul. But here is also probably, at the same time, an allusion to the actual untransferred meaning of mu/ein, close, —i.e. the “unconfined.” With this agrees the following explanation, ou) stegano/n and tetrhme/nos pi/qos. The a)mu/htoi stand open to all the charms of sense and the outer world.
to\ a)ko/laston: an allusion to the expression of Callicles.

ou) stegano/n: which does not cover and preserve its contents, gives cause and introduction for the image of the jar. It is noteworthy that this greedy part of the soul is designated entirely by neg. expressions.

w(s tetrhme/nos ei)/h pi/qos: depends on an e)/lege, which is implied in w)no/mase. It is true, however, that after a verb of naming we find occasionally a relative clause, as Soph. O. R. 780 kalei= (me) plasto\s w(s ei)/hn patri/. The comparison reminds one of the myth of the Danaidae. With the image of the pi/qos and ko/skinon Thompson compares Shaks. Cym. i. 7
‘The cloyed will, That satiate yet unsatisfied desire, That tub both filled and running,’ and All's Well i. 3. 193 ‘Yet in this captious and untenable sieve, I still pour in the waters of my love, And lack not to lose still.’
a)peika/sas: the necessary objects in the acc. and dat. are to be supplied from the context.
tou)nanti/on: construe with soi/.

e)n *(/aidou: the following etymological explanation is found also elsewhere. It draws attention to a consideration of the beyond and the life after death, which plays an important part in the close of the dialogue. Cf. Phaedo 80 d, 81 c, d.
ou(=toi: points back, but is at the same time fixed by the addition oi( a)mu/htoi.
e(te/rw| toiou/tw|: “likewise.” The objects are different, but their defects are similar.
o( pro\s e)me\ le/gwn: Socrates again refers to his authority, because he is still engaged with the details of the simile.

th\n tw=n a)muh/twn: emphatically added, because what follows applies only to oi( a)mu/htoi. The soul is here, as a whole, compared to a perforated sieve, whereas, just before, only a part of it was compared with the jar, because thereby was meant only the part attached to the body. But the other part, the soul proper, is brought into service to this bodily part, so that it affords material for it, and even assumes its nature. Cf. Phaedo 66 d douleu/ontes th=| tou= sw/matos qerapei/a|.

a)pisti/an: no contradiction to the above peistiko/n, which was said only of the e)piqumhtiko/n of the soul. By yielding to the sensual, the soul loses its power of reception and retention, of belief and knowledge.
e)pieikw=s: reasonably, fairly, and then very likely, indeed.
u(po/ ti: somewhat, like u(po/ in u(poa/mousos Rep. viii. 548 e, belongs to a)/topon. Rid. § 131 cites Phaedr. 242 d u(po/ ti a)sebh= (lo/gon). Cf. in Lat. subabsurdus, subrusticus, etc.
mh/n: yet, moreover, like the more usual me/ntoi.

soi/: in Greek, when a pron. has been expressed once with one of the verbs of a series, it is not necessary to express it a second time, even though the second verb would require a different case, as here.
metaqe/sqai: denotes the change of an opinion or statement. Cf. Rep. i. 334 e a)lla\ metaqw/meqa: kinduneu/omen ga\r ou)k o)rqw=s . . . qe/sqai.
a)nti\ . . . e(le/sqai: epexegetic, instead of w(/ste e(le/sqai.
kosmi/ws: chiastically contrasted with a)kola/stws.
po/teron pei/qw: the question shows that Socrates himself attaches no especial cogency to the comparison. Cf. below, muqologw=.
metati/qesai: here equiv. to metaqe/menos h(gei=. Mutasne ita sententiam ut statuas feliciores esse modestos libidinosis. Heindorf.
tou=to: refers to the second part of the double question.

fe/re dh/: the employment of another simile after the preceding one is strange; but possibly the second contains an advance on the first, inasmuch as it extends the consideration from the nature to the life. It may, however, be only another version of the first one, as the scholiast suggests: h)=n de\ e)kei=no me\n tw=n *puqagorei/wn oi)kei=on, tou=to de\ *swkra/tous, w(s safe/stero/n te kai\ plhktikw/teron.

gumnasi/ou: it is not necessary to refer this strictly to the philosophical school already mentioned. It rather has the meaning of “place of general exercise,” the domain of imagination and fancy from which Socrates (Plato) draws his new image. On the ‘brachylogy’ in th=| nu=n (“where we obtained the one just given”), see Kr. 48, 13, 9.
pi/qoi polloi/: by these are to be understood only the separate desires. Pleasures are the materials with which the jars are filled.
u(giei=s: in the physical sense, “undamaged,” but with a pre-understanding of the moral judgment in regard to them; hence the contrast is formed by saqra/, as in 479 b.

pollw=n: viz. toiou/twn xrhma/twn or nama/twn. The common manner of
expression would be a)/lloi a)/llwn pollw=n or a)/lloi a)/llwn polloi\ pollw=n.
xalepa/: used absolutely and explained by the addition of kai\ . . . e)kporizo/mena. Cf. below (11), where the supplement is self-evident.
o( me\n e(/teros: i.e. o( sw/frwn.
e(/neka tou/twn: “so far as it depends upon the filling of the casks or desires.” Cf. Theaet. 148 d proqumi/as me\n e(/neka fanei=tai.
pori/zesqai: probably middle. Kr. 55, 3, 8; H. 813.
h)/: i.e. ei) de\ mh\ (pimplai/h).
a)=ra toiou/tou kte(.: comprehensive resumption of the protasis beginning with ei) duoi=n.

pei/qw ti: the adverbial acc. of the indef. neut. pron. is frequent. See H. 719 b; G. 160, 2. The repetition of pei/qw shows that Socrates attaches no value to the comparison as a proof, for one simile can be offset by an other, but it helps to clarify the idea.
to\ w(/sper li/qon zh=n: epexegetical to tou=to . . . o(\ kte(., in order to draw attention again to the earlier remark.—We must supply naturally the same subject to plhrw/sh| as to zh=n.

e)pirrei=n: Callicles takes up the simile of Socrates; but at the same time, in this treatment of it there may be some traces of the teaching of Gorgias, if, as is supposed, he accepted Empedocles' ideas of flux and reflux in his views of physics. Cf. Meno 76 c bou/lei ou)=n soi kata\ *gorgi/an a)pokri/nwmai;—*ou)kou=n le/gete a)porroa/s tinas tw=n u)/ntwn kat' *)empedokle/a; kai\ po/rous ei)s ou(\s kai\ di) w(=n ai( a)porroai\ poreu/ontai. In this light the word pori/zesqai gains especial importance.
e)kroai=s: this compound with e)k is very unusual, but also here very exact.

xaradriou=: according to Arist. Anim. Hist. ix. 11, the xaradrio/s was a bird of ugly voice and color, which lived in chasms and clefts of the rock, and came forth only at night. Others describe it as a very greedy bird, o(\s a(/ma tw=| e)sqi/ein e)kkri/nei. It is this peculiarity which explains the reference here. The duck has that reputation with us.
a)ll' ou): we might also have simple ou) (456 e), or kai\ ou) (Kr. 59, 1, 10).
to\ toio/nde le/geis: viz. as the above (a)ll' . . . e)pirrei=n) used expressions. The following answer of Callicles, le/gw kte(., saves Socrates the trouble of enumeration.
to\ toio/nde: see on 490 e.
XLIX.

eu)=ge: the verb is regularly omitted with this exclamation, which is usually ironic. By the words ta\s a)/llas e)piqumi/as a(pa/sas, Callicles gives Socrates an open field for attack. Hence the ironical praise. Callicles need only continue to make such rash statements to be soon silenced.

w(s e)/oike: by this expression Socrates reminds Callicles of the principle he had laid down in 482 e (cf. 489 a), in order, by this ironical praise of his determination which shrinks from no consequence, to make acceptable the diversion of the discussion to less pleasant subjects. At the same time, he shows that he feels himself compelled, by the results of Callicles' moral view, to carry the investigation into this field.

a)fqo/nws e)/xonta tou= knh=sqai: the gen., on account of the meaning
of the adverb (cf. fqonei=n tini/ tinos).
knh=sqai: contracted like zh=n, yh=n, etc. Cf. peinh=n in b above.
w(s a)/topos ei)= kte(.: rudeness instead of response.
dhmhgo/ros: see on 482 c.

toiga/rtoi: this strong inferential particle (cf. 471 c) serves to compel Callicles, who would gladly have evaded the answer by the general reproach w(s a)/topos ei)=, to a definite answer, by reference to 487 a, b.

a)ndrei=os: with an allusion to 491 b. It is contrasted with e)kplagh=nai, because, besides fro/nhsis, bravery is the only virtue recognized by Callicles as necessary for a statesman. He must, therefore, display this quality himself.

ta\ e)xo/mena: used absolutely would not indeed be unexampled (cf. Isoc. vi. 29 e)k tw=n e)xome/nwn gnw/sesqe), but in connection with tou/tois e)fech=s is pleonastic. Otherwise Plato's usage is either ta\ tou/twn e)xo/mena (Rep. iii. 389 e) or ta\ tou/tois e)fech=s (Tim. 30 c, Phileb. 34 d).
kefa/laion: without the article is rather uncommon (cf. 453 a, 472 c), but does occasionally occur. Cf. Dem. ii. 31.
ou(=tos: points emphatically back to o( tw=n kinai/dwn bi/os, which has already received especial stress through the preceding word kefa/laion.
ei)s toiau=ta a)/gwn: is the same reproach which was made above, 482 e.
a)ne/dhn: without limitation, from the same root as a)ni/hmi.—
ou(/tw: see on 468 c a(plw=s ou(/tws.

a)ll' e)/ti kai\ nu=n: the last attempt to come to an understanding. Cf. Crito 44 b. The answer of Callicles tends to bring into the foreground the question of the identity or opposition of the agreeable and the good.
a)nomologou/menos: is not to be connected with a)nomologei=sqai, “to repeat an admission already made and to come to an agreement,” but is from o(mologou/menos in composition with

a- privative. By this expression Callicles makes plain the recklessness of his thinking and the obstinacy of his disposition. The sentence is condensed by the omission of a selfevident clause: “in order that I may not make my statement inconsistent, (which I will do) if I say,” etc.

diafqei/reis tou\s prw/tous lo/-... lang=greek>gous: cf. Prot. 360 a diafqerou=men ta\s e)/mprosqen o(mologi/as. Callicles' words in 491 e and elsewhere gave reason to expect that he would speak his sentiments roundly without any hesitation. Cf. 492 d.
i(kanw=s . . . e)ceta/zois: has reference to 487 e e)a/n ti su\ e)n toi=s lo/gois o(mologh/sh|s moi, bebasanisme/non tou=t) h)/dh e)/stai i(kanw=s.—
ei)/per... lang=greek>e)rei=s: “if you will persist in speaking,” with a decidedly unfavorable color.
sautw=|: rather stronger than soi/.
kai\ ga\r su/: complete the sen
tence from what precedes.
a)/qrei: like skopei=n and similar verbs has the construction of verbs of fear.
ai)nixqe/nta: denotes the consequences previously intimated, though not definitely stated, by Socrates.
w(s su/ ge oi)/ei: evasive, as 473 b. The following question inquires whether Callicles still holds to his previous statement, while accepting the consequences of it.
L.
e)pixeirw=men: see on 492 d e)pece/rxei. Notice the determination and assurance of the answers of Callicles.
dielou=: because it is a question of distinction between ideas.
nundh\ e)/leges: inasmuch as Callicles had in 491 a, b classed together a)ndrei=oi and fro/nimoi.

w(s e(/teron (sc. o)/n): the omission of the partic. in the acc. abs. with an adj. and w(s is very rare; i.e. Prot. 323 b w(s a)nagkai=on ou)de/na o(/ntin' ou)xi\ a(mwsge/pws mete/xein au)th=s. But Heindorf supplies o)/n.

w)= sofw/tate su/: a humorously ironical intimation that Socrates was asking something quite self-evident. But Callicles should not recognize an e)pisth/mh and an a)ndrei/a, in addition to “the good,” if this is to find its realization in h(donh/. The argument which begins 497 d is based upon this contradiction.

o(/pws memnhso/meqa: this use of o(/pws with the fut. is distinctively a colloquialism, the majority of exam
ples being found in Aristophanes. For statistics, see GMT. 274.

*kalliklh=s e)/fh *)axarneu/s: a humorous imitation of the custom which prevailed in the public assembly, according to which any one who introduced a motion or resolution had to add to his own name the name of the deme to which he belonged; cf. the famous line which used to afford Philip of Macedon so much amusement, *dhmosqe/nhs *dhmosqe/nous *paianieu\s ta/d' ei)=pen. Callicles falls in with the humor immediately. *)axarnai/ belonged to the fulh\ *oi)nhi/s, *)alwpekh/ to the fulh\ *)antioxi/s.

tou= a)gaqou=: does not properly belong in this summing up (o(/pws memnhso/meqa) of the foregoing steps, which define expressly the fact that e)pisth/mh and a)ndrei/a on the one hand are quite distinct from h(donh/ (to\ h(du/) on the other. Still, by reason of the identity of h(du/ and a)gaqo/n maintained by Callicles, the a)gaqo/n would be very easily substituted for the h(du/.
au)to\s au(to/n: “himself,” i.e. his own mind.
e)nanti/a: i.e. logically contrary and contradictory ideas, between which a mean is not to be thought of.

a)polabw/n: used absolutely equiv. to “separately.” Cf. Rep. iii. 392 e w(/sper ou)=n oi( a)du/natoi le/gein, ou) kata\ o(/lon, a)ll' a)polabw\n me/ros ti peira/somai/ soi e)n tou/tw| dhlw=sai. The gen. tou= sw/matos depends on peri\ o(/tou (me/rous) bou/lei.
a(/nqrwpos: the same as o( a)/nqrw- pos above.
ou)d' o(pwstiou=n: by the addition of ou)=n, the relative seems to acquire the force of an indefinite. See Kr. 51, 15, 3; H. 285, 1002 a.
qauma/sion . . . gi/gnetai: “the result (gi/gnetai) so stated is unreasonable.” Note that the Greek uses the ind. of the necessary conclusion, whereas Eng. would prefer the ideal ‘would be.’
kai\ eu)= ma/la kte(.: with this formula Socrates warns Callicles of the importance of being careful in his response,—a warning which the latter ignores in the reckless assurance of his answer.
to\ peinh=n e)/leges po/teron: the question, by coming late in the sentence, gains in animation. Cf. Rid. §§ 309, 310.

au)to\ le/gw to\ peinh=n: added by Socrates that Callicles may not think at the same time of the satisfaction of the hunger. How close that idea lay is shown by Callicles' answer, in which he tries to guard himself by adding this idea.
kai\ e)gw/: manqa/nw: the asyndetic union of two such expressions, one expressing assent, the other comprehension, is quite isolated and contrary to usage. Cf. 474 c, 490 d.

a)ll)... lang=greek>ou)=n: but in any case, frequently associated with ge/. Cf. 506 b and Apol. 27 c a)ll' ou)=n daimo/nia/ ge nomi/zw kata\ to
 so
 lo/gon, 34 e, Prot. 327 c a)ll' ou)=n au)lhtai/ g) a)
 pa/ntes h)=san i(kanoi/.
sfo/dra ge: see on ma/lista in e below.
a)lla\ mh\ e)rw/ta: further questions are superfluous.

tou/tou ou(= le/geis kte(.: the concrete example diyw=nta pi/nein Socrates uses to distinguish and characterize the two ideas clearly. The generaliz
ation that pain and pleasure can both be present in the same act follows later.
ma/lista: like sfo/dra ge in d above, gives emphatic assent. ma/lista has become the general word for “yes” in modern Greek, almost to the exclusion of nai/.

ei)/te yuxh=s ei)/te sw/matos: for Socrates' argument it is immaterial whether pleasure and pain are looked upon as something bodily or something psychical; for psychology, not so. But here the question is only of the nature of the ideas them selves, the peculiarity of their association at the same place and time, which distinguishes them from that other class of mutually exclusive ideas.
fh/|s: with reference to 495 e. The answer of Callicles shows that he still maintains his statement.
ou)k oi)=d' a(/tta sofi/zei: Callicles avoids admitting his defeat by complaining of Socrates' methods. Cf. 511 a. sofi/zesqai is much the same as “subtilize,” “quibble.”

a)kki/zesqai: ‘this word and its derivative a)kkismo/s are used to denote any kind of mock modesty or prudery, especially, though not exclusively, on the part of women.’ Thompson. To Socrates' words of encouragement Callicles angrily replies, “What nonsense are you still talking?” whereby, however, Socrates is not deterred from continuing his talk in the courtly manner which is characteristic of him. On the phrase e)/xwn lhrei=s see on 490 e.

ou)k oi)=da o(/ti le/geis: Callicles sees that from this new turn Socrates will draw the same conclusion which he has drawn above (e(/teron gi/gnetai to\ h(du\ tou= a)gaqou=). Hence he repeatedly refuses to answer, and so shows plainly that he wishes to break off the conversation. This leads to the deprecatory remark of Gorgias.

mhdamw=s: don't! To be com pleted by some such general phrase as ou(/tw poih/sh|s. The omission of the verb is common. Cf. Symp. 175 b mhdamw=s, a)ll' e)a=te au)to/n.—That Gorgias here enters as mediator is quite in keeping with the role assigned him in this dialogue, in accordance with which he is distinguished from his companions by his personal dignity. See Introd. § 13.
timh/: in a judicial sense, “the penalty decreed by the court.” Hence the words ou) sh\ kte(. are equivalent to “this is no fault of yours,” “the blame cannot be laid upon you.”—
u(po/sxes: equiv. to u(p' seauto/n. See on parasxei=n 456 b and 475 d.

Callicles allows himself to be persuaded by Gorgias to continue the conversation, but not without repeated expression of his disinclina
tion.
stena/: mean, paltry, is in keeping with the view expressed by Callicles in 485 d of the relative provinces of philosophy and politics.

ta\ mega/la memu/hsai kte(.: two kinds of Eleusinian mysteries were distinguished, the greater and the lesser. In the great procession which on the 20th of Boedromion (September) conducted Iacchus to Eleusis, no one could take part who had not received previously at Athens the less and preparatory consecration (mu/hsis, ka/qarsis, prote/leia) in the month Anthesterion (February). By this he became eligible to initiation into the Greater Mysteries; and after initiation, as an initiated member (mu/sths), to the e)poptei/a or view of the mysterious sacred relics and participation in the holy rites which were connected with the arrival of the pro cession at Eleusis and took place in the so-called telesth/rion.—Socrates meets with most cutting irony the disdainful contempt with which Callicles regards dialectical methods. A different simile for the same matter is found in 514 e.
o(/qen a)pe/lipes: the interrupted argument is resumed again by Socrates at the point where it had been broken off by Callicles' refusal to answer.

h(donw=n: corresponding with what precedes we might expect h(do/menos. The noun is used owing to e)piqumiw=n, which stands on the same plane as peinw=n and as a kind of e)/ndeia (496 d) is an a)niaro/n. Hence the employment of lupw=n below.
ti/ ou)=n dh/: well! what then? See on 453 b and 515 e.
w(s e(te/rwn o)/ntwn: this seems otiose after the preceding sentence. If genuine, it must be considered as mere conversational fulness.

th=|de: refers naturally, according to the regular usage, to the argument begun in tou\s a)gaqou\s kte(. The introduction of this argument is, however, delayed by the parenthetical clause oi)=mai . . . a)/qrei de/. In this clause tau/th|, though in sense also applicable to the argument which follows, is in form to be connected with th=|de. The subject of o(mologei=sqai is general, and can be supplied from the clause pw=s ou)=n kte(.

tou\s a)gaqou/s, tou\s kakou/s: the art. as in 490 e collects the individuals into a class or species. a)gaqw=n is used on account of its nearness to a)gaqou/s, otherwise we should expect a)retw=n as in 506 d. The way in which we arrive at these ideas of distinction between species is shown by the same expressions which are employed in other places to explain the relation of the ideas to the things themselves. So besides parousi/a (parei=nai) we find koinwni/a and of things also mete/xein employed.

a)/fronas kai\ deilou/s: “unreasoning and cowardly creatures.” The absence of the art. does not cause obscurity, because the connexion shows a)gaqou/s to be the predicate. In the words a)ndrei/ous kte(. Socrates is referring to 489 e and 491 b.
ti/ tou=to: see on 448 b above.

ei)=don: the tense is due to the preceding question. English would require ‘I have seen.’ This would be permissible also in Greek. The aor. of verbs of perception states the fact; the pf. retains the image. The
negation of the fact involves the negation of the image; hence the neg. is usually followed by the aorist. The pf. with the neg. is, however, also found; cf. Prot. 310 e. But the difference in the force is evident. In 38, below, the tense may be due to the desire for consistency, or to h)/dh.
a)rkei= kai\ tou=to: gives us to understand that Socrates was expecting a more definite answer.

a)mfo/teroi ma=llon: Callicles tries to return such answers as will not afford Socrates any chance for argument. Such action borders on rudeness, and is almost equivalent to a refusal to answer. The addition that he makes, however, gives Socrates a hold. The answers which follow show that Callicles is not stating his real sentiments. The artistic design of the author is therefore now to make his defeat seem all the more decisive.

a)=r' ou)=n kte(.: this conclusion comes from the fact that Socrates, on the basis of the view set forth by Callicles in 491 e ff., uses in the predicate a)gaqoi/ in place of xai/rousi, and kakoi/ in place of lupou=ntai, whereas these same words in the subject have an entirely different meaning, which is to be seen from the explanation of Callicles in 491

c d. The two predicates are to be conceived as belonging to two different sentences, thus: oi( a)gaqoi/ te kai\ oi( kakoi\ paraplhsi/ws ei)si\n a)gaqoi/ and oi( a)gaqoi/ te kai\ oi( kakoi\ paraplhsi/ws ei)si\ kakoi/.
LIII.

a)lla\ le/geis: this statement of Callicles may be meant in earnest, inasmuch as the previous words of Socrates are really somewhat confusing, although they are simply a paradoxical conclusion from Callicles' paradoxical propositions. But by confessing his inability to comprehend, Callicles gives Socrates the opportunity of supplying a proof of his previous exposition, and setting forth the principles upon which it rests. The distinction made in 497 e now becomes of value.
kakou\s de\ kakw=n: both the subj. as well as the subst. on which the gen. depends are to be supplied from the context. Note the chiasmus of the arrangement.
ta\ de\ a)gaqa\ kte(.: the preds. are ta\s h(dona/s, ta\s a)ni/as, the art. defining a class. The art. with a)gaqa/ refers back to a)gaqw=n. We should also expect one with kaka/.
oi(\ me/n ge ma=llon kte(.: is to be completed from the context thus: oi(\ me\n (a)\n) ma=llon (xai/rwsi) ma=llon (a)gaqoi\) kte(.

di\s ga\r kai\ tri/s: this proverb is ascribed to Empedocles. Plato employs it also in Phil. 59 e, where we read: to\ di\s kai\ tri\s to/ ge kalw=s e)/xon e)panapolei=n tw=| lo/gw|. Cf. Soph. Phil. 1238 di\s tau)ta\ bou/lei kai\ tri\s a)napolei=n m' e)/ph. The first kai/ means also, and its force extends over both members, as Phaedo 63 e e)ni/ote a)nagka/zesqai kai\ di\s kai\ tri\s pi/nein tou/s ti toiou=ton poiou=ntas.

ta\ pro/tera e)kei=na: refer probably to the discussion of 494 a-495 a, where Socrates had urged Callicles to reflect whether he was determined to abide by his statement that h(du/ and a)gaqo/n are the same.

pa/lai toi kte(.: like all who try only to gain their point, not to arrive at the truth, Callicles seeks to evade the now inevitable confession of his error by representing his previous statement as a mere joke. But cf. 495 a-c.
tou/tou: e)/xesqai, to hold fast, takes the gen. See G. 171, 1; H. 738.—
w(/sper ta\ meira/kia: boys easily receive as genuine what one tries to impose upon them. Farther than this, the comparison is not to be pressed.
w(s dh\ su\ oi)/ei: see on 468 e. Callicles tries to heighten the probability that he was only joking, by himself characterizing his first statement as nonsensical.

h(dona/s: the natural position would be ta\s me\n h(dona\s belti/ous kte(. The reason for the post-position is that the word is an afterthought of Callicles, added from the sudden consciousness that ta\s me/n was not sufficiently definite. Just as if you suppose that I, etc., do not believe that some are better,—pleasures, I mean,—others worse.

i)ou\ i)ou/: exclamation of surprise and wonder, usually with a sideidea of ill-treatment (sxetliastiko\n e)pi/rrhma), as Ar. Nub. 1 i)ou\ i)ou\, w)= *zeu= basileu/, to\ xrh=ma tw=n nuktw=n o(/son a)pe/ranton, but it also expresses pleasure, as e.g. Rep. iv. 432 d kai\ e)gw\ katidw/n, *)iou\ i)ou/, ei)=pon, w)= *glau/kwn: kinduneu/ome/n ti e)/xein i)/xnos (trace) kai/ moi dokei= ou) pa/nu ti e)kfeucei=sqai h(ma=s. *eu)= a)gge/lleis, h)= d) o(/s.—
panou=rgos: sometimes associated with deino/s, denotes a rather excessive adroitness, bordering on rascality, as “artful,” “sly”; also “knavish.”
w(/sper paidi/: by a delicate use of his own comparison, Socrates characterizes Callicles' conduct in acting as if he were dealing with boys, not men, as improper and unworthy.—
to/te me\n au)=: it must be confessed that au)= in this position gives trouble. Cron thinks that it recalls a similar allegation in 491 b; but that is rather far-fetched.
kai/toi kte(.: in 495 a Socrates' faith in Callicles' parrhsi/a is shaken; in 497 a, that in his sofi/a, and now, that in his eu)/noia.
e(ko/ntos ei)=nai: on the use of ei)=nai in phrases, see GMT. 780 and H. 956 a.
kata\ to\n pa/laion lo/gon: a common way of introducing a proverb; cf. Symp. 195 b.

to\ paro\n eu)= poiei=n kte(.: a mixture of two proverbs. The first one means literally, to “treat well what is at hand,” i.e. ‘to make the best of what one has,’ according to the English saying. In almost the same sense we use the more colloquial ‘grin and bear it.’ The second proverb, de/xesqai to\ dido/menon, applies more exactly to the case in point, the dido/menon being naturally to\ lego/menon. An English proverb which has much the same force is, ‘do not look a gifthorse in the mouth.’ After tou=to, to\ dido/menon serves for a relative clause.
kakai/: we should naturally ex
pect blaberai/, but kako/s is elsewhere also used in this sense.
au(=tai me/n: resumes ai( me\n . . . tou= sw/matos.
te/los . . . to\ a)gaqo/n: cf. 468 a ff. The subst. embraces in one idea what has been said, and thus gives it a form of general application.
