su/myhfos: reminds again of the formal vote, and hence sounds somewhat solemn. Cf. 501 c and 473 e f.

e)k tri/twn: “of the third part.” Thompson. Cf. Symp. 213 b u(polu/ete, pai=des, *)alkibia/dhn, i(/na e)k tri/twn (i.e. with Agathon and Socrates) katake/htai. In Tim. 54 a e)k tri/tou is used in much the same sense.
panto\s a)ndro/s: possessive gen. in pred. See H. 732 a, c.

poi=a . . . tw=n h(de/wn: the position of the gen. shows that it is an example of e)pifora/, based on the conclusion drawn in 499 b. The use of o(poi=a after poi=a may be due to euphonic reasons, or to its distance from the beginning of the question.

texnikou=: i.e. of a man who understands the matter thoroughly, who is a master of his profession (whether art or science). Only this man can decide what is to be done and what not. The same point is made in Crito 47 a.
w(=n au)=: the au)= belongs to the dem. included in the relative. The arguments which Socrates again calls to mind were set forth in 464 b ff.

paraskeuai/: contrivances. This word, which is not found in the passage referred to, is used generally instead of e)pithdeu/seis, qerapei=ai, as drawing more attention to the end in view (mexri\ h(donh=s). The prep. shows that the contrivances are not claimed to reach h(donh/, but must be varied and directed until the object is compassed; hence paraskeua/zousai is conative.
au)to\ tou=to: i.e. the general idea, h(donh/.
tw=n me/n, tw=n de/: take up ai( me/n, ai( de/. On the part. gen. with tiqe/nai, see G. 169, 2; H. 732 a.
pro\s fili/ou: so 519 e. Cf. Phaedr. 234 e ei)pe\ pro\s *dio\s fili/ou. This adjuration is designed to remind Callicles of his ostentatious profession of eu)/noia, which he had so quickly forgotten.
mh/te au)to/s: finds its correlative in mh/t' au)= ta\ par) e)mou=, while mhde/ serves only to connect the two sections of the first member.
o(/ti a)\n tu/xh|s kte(.: implies perverseness in addition to chance. Cf. 495 a, b, and 499 c.
ou(=: depends upon ma=llon and is explained in h)\ tou=to. Cf. Crito 44 c ti/s a)\n ai)sxi/wn ei)/h tau/ths do/ca h)\ dokei=n xrh/mata peri\ plei/onos poiei=sqai h)\ fi/lous. See Kr. 47, 27, 8.
spouda/seie: in reference to an investigation which one should seriously prosecute.
smikro\n nou=n e)/xwn: indicates that the question is important for every one, not merely for statesmen and philosophers.
tou= a)ndro\s dh/: ironically added as a matter already decided, because Callicles had so defined the sphere of the “real man.”
e)pi\ to/nde: anacoluthic, as if e)pi\ po/teron xrh\ bi/on parakalei=n had preceded, whereas with po/teron we must supply tou=ton, i.e. to\n tro/pon zh=n xrh/.
diafe/rwn: on the pred. use of the partic., see GMT. 830.

w(s a)/rti e)pexei/rhsa: we think at first of the question raised in 491 d ff. as to the nature of self-control, which leads naturally to a distinction between what is good and what is pleasant, but we are also reminded of the earlier conversation with Polus and Gorgias (464 b) in which a distinction was drawn between true arts and various tricks of dexterity, which are designed only to cajole.

ei) e)/stin kte(.: to be conceived, not as an interr. clause depending upon o(mologh/santas, but as the protasis of a logical conditional sentence, the apodosis of which is formed by be/ltisto/n e)stin . . . ske/yasqai. The further investigation as to ti/ diafe/reton can only take place in case the existence of these two views of life is definitely settled.
o(mologh/santas: as well as dielome/nous and diairei=sqai, whose meaning is defined by its reference to 495 c, are used absolutely.
o(po/teron biwte/on: sc. bi/on. Cf. 485 d and Apol. 38 a o( a)nece/tastos bi/os ou) biwto\s a)nqrw/tw|.

th\n me\n kte(.: explains e(kate/ron kte(. by substituting for the somewhat philosophical phrase (mele/thn . . . kth/sews) one less technical (qh/ran). But before Socrates proceeds further he deems it necessary to have these assumptions definitely agreed to, since, although they are indeed the result of the preceding investigations, Callicles has not expressly acceded to them.
LVI.

pro\s tou/sde: the distinctions between various ideas which have been drawn in ch. XVIII.-XX. serve for Polus as well as Gorgias, inasmuch as the latter entered the discussion again in 463 e of his own accord.
diomolo/ghsai: the dia/ implies ‘finally,’ ‘definitely.’ We should be more apt to use the kai/ in the demonstrative instead of the relative clause.

e)/doca: Cron thinks the use of the aor. instead of the pres. implies that Callicles must have already at the time come to a decision, though he had not expressed one. But while such was doubtless the case, it is not easy to draw such a conclusion from the tense, for the Greeks in such an expression looked rather to the idea of the whole complex.
h( d' i)atrikh/: the clause is to be completed from the first member. The following h( me\n . . . h( de\ kte(. are arranged chiastically.
ai)ti/an: cf. 465 a, where the reference was especially to the means employed (w(=n prosfe/rei); here it is more general (w(=n pra/ttei).
h( d' i)atrikh/: the addition of the substantive at the end of the first member was not necessary for clearness, but very conducive to it. Similarly Prot. 351 a.

h( d' e(te/ra th=s h(donh=s kte(.: another case of anacoluthon. If the speaker had followed the line of construction begun in the previous clause, we should have had some
such phrase as ou)/te th\n fu/sin kte(., on which th=s h(donh=s would depend, as in the case of tou/tou above. In true conversational style, however, he is diverted from his line of thought by the relative clause, and proceeds to a detailed account of the method of the e)mpeiri/a which komidh=| a)te/xnws e)p' au)th\n e)/rxetai. The result is that th=s h(donh=s is left without government, and that too without the speaker or hearers noticing it.

a)lo/gws: as 465 a o)\ a)\n h)=| a)/logon pra=gma, because the distinctive feature of a te/xnh consists in its ability dou=nai lo/gon. This must not be conceived as closely modifying diariqmhsame/nh, but as being a general criticism on ou)de\n diariqmhsame/nh (“quite foolishly”).
w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n: probably belongs to the following negation. Cf. Apol. 17 a a)lhqe/s ge w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n ou)de\n ei)rh/kasin. See on 450 b.
w(=| dh/: refers to the whole pre
ceding clause, i.e. equiv. to tw=| sw/|zesqai mnh/mhn kte(.
toiau=tai a)/llai: “according to their nature similar, but different in their application.” Supply dokou=sin out of the preceding dokei=.
promhqi/an tou= belti/stou: designed to be in sharp contrast with the mnh/mhn tou= ei)wqo/tos gi/gnesqai above.
w(/sper e)kei=: i.e. in the case of the body.

h(/tis de\ h)\ belti/wn kte(.: is a circumlocutory reference to fu/sis, as ou)/te me/lon in the following member is to ai)ti/a. The abs. partic. me/lon is likewise combined with an appos. partic. in Phaedr. 235 a w(s ou) pa/nu eu)porw=n tou= polla\ le/gein peri\ tou= au)tou= h)\ i)/sws ou)de\n au)tw=| me/lon tou= toiou/tou.
kai\ peri\ a)/llo: indefinite and merely preparatory.
a)ske/ptws e)/xwn: like a)melw=n or o)ligwrw=n. Cf. above, b.

sugkatati/qesai: reminds again of voting (as above, 500 a su/myhfos). It is regularly used without an obj. Here we must consider do/can as taking the place of the word yh=fon, to be construed with this verb after the analogy of the regular phrase qe/sqai yh=fon. See Thompson. sugkatati/qesqai has also the meaning “lay aside for future use.”
ou)k e)/gwge kte(.: an emphatic assent (see on 453 d). But Callicles weakens it by the addition of i(/na . . . xari/swmai, referring to 497 b, c.
peri\ de\ du/o kte(.: this extension to several souls was necessary in order that the investigation might be directed to political activity.

mhde/: “without.” th\n au)lhtikh/n: Socrates so chooses his examples that he passes from species to species in an ascend ing scale, and at the same time gradually approaches nearer to rhetoric. Playing the flute passed for the lowest species of music. Cf. the boyish words of Alcibiades in Plut. Alc. 2 au)lei/twsan *qhbai/wn pai=des: ou) ga\r i)/sasi diale/gesqai. In Athens it was left mostly to such as made a business of it. Female flute-players were accustomed to appear at banquets. The instrument was probably more like a clarionet than a flute.
diw/kein, fronti/zein: these infinitives, while in sense epexegetic to toiau/th ei)=nai, are syntactically dependent on dokei=. See on 487 c.

h( e)n toi=s a)gw=sin: Plato considers as a species of flattery only that kind of cithara-playing which was practised in the musical contests at the public festivals. On the other hand, he recognizes a variety of this music which may be helpful to the proper cultivation of the soul of the individual who practises it, and indeed may elevate his moral feeling. This he himself recommends in Rep. iii. 399 d f. Cithara-playing was a part of the education of all young Athenians.

h( tw=n xorw=n didaskali/a: didaskali/a denotes the drill of the chorus for orchestral exhibition as well as for singing. It was the business of the poet. Hdt. i. 23 says of Arion e)o/nta kiqarw|do\n tw=n to/te e)o/ntwn ou)deno\s deu/teron kai\ diqu/rambon prw=ton a)nqrw/pwn tw=n h(mei=s i)/dmen poih/santa/ te kai\ o)noma/santa kai\ dida/canta e)n *kori/nqw|. What is to be understood here by choruses is explained by the addition h( diqura/mbwn poi/hsis. It is not all choric lyric which is condemned, but only that part of it which from its connexion with the Dionysus cult had found entrance into Athens and had there been much fostered by the state, which entrusted both native and foreign musicians with the arrangement and production of the dithyramb at the Dionysiac festivals, where contests (a)gw=nes) took place in it. The founder of dithyrambic melic was the just-named Arion of Methymne (B.C. 600), who resided at the court of Periander of Corinth. He was said to have introduced the strophic arrangement, and the so-called cyclic chorus (consisting of fifty members), which was thus named because the chorus was arranged in a circle around the altar. The second period of the dithyramb begins with the settling in Athens of Lasus of Hermione, a contemporary of the Pisistratidae and a teacher of Pindar. But it soon degenerated in Athens by excessive over-refinement and fantastic cultivation, until it received a new impulse towards the end of the Peloponnesian war by the more artistic cultivation of the dramatic and musical elements by Philoxenus of Cythera.

*kinhsi/as: a very popular dithyrambic poet about the middle of the Peloponnesian war, who deserves a great deal of censure for having helped to debase dithyrambic poetry. He tried to produce a striking effect by fantastic, misty, and often immoral subjects, combined with a pompous diction, excess of imagery, and shallow figures of speech. And he succeeded in a way, for he was ridiculed by the comic
poets Strattis (who composed a comedy upon him), Plato Comicus, and also Aristophanes in the Clouds and the Frogs, as a sinner against art and taste,—one of those who are called in Nub. 333 kukli/wn xorw=n a)|smatoka/mptai. Of his father Meles we know less; he was certainly less important than Cinesias, though he also is ridiculed by the comic poets.

tw=n qeatw=n: just as in English the general designation for the people who fill the theatre is ‘audience,’ whether the performance be an opera or a drama, so the Greeks used qeatai/, “the spectators,” as a general designation for the crowds who thronged the Dionysiac theatre, no matter what sort of a performance was given. So, just below (20), we find h)ni/a ga\r a)/|dwn tou\s qeata/s.

ou)xi\ h(/ te kiqarw|dikh/: this conclusion we must suppose to be permitted because at the moment Callicles can cite no example to the contrary. kiqaristikh/ (above, 501 e) and kiqarw|dikh/, which are properly distinct (cf. kiqa/risis and kiqarw|di/a Io 533 b), are here interchanged in ac cordance with colloquial usage. To fix the meaning of kiqa/risis, the adj. yilh/ was added. Cf. Legg. 669 e.

h( semnh/: viewed in the light of the result which Socrates deduces, this word as well as qaumasth/ may be considered ironic. But tragedy was regularly designated semnh/, “venerated,” as being the most noble presentation of poetry before the public mind, both from its sage maxims and from the moral effect which was ascribed to it. Socrates' actual view of poetry is well stated in Apol. 22 b, c e)/gnwn ou)=n kai\ peri\ tw=n poihtw=n tou=to, o(/ti ou) sofi/a| poioi=en a(\ poioi=en, a)lla\ fu/sei tini\ kai\ e)nqousia/zontes w(/sper oi( qeoma/nteis kai\ oi( xrhsmw|doi/.

e)f' w(=| e)spou/dake: the order of the whole sentence is involved; ti/ de\ dh/ (e)stin e)kei=no) e)f' w(=| e)spou/daken. After giving the general question, Socrates follows it by a disjunctive special one. The repetition of the art. h( is illustrated by Stallbaum from Symp. 213 e th
 tou/tou tauthni\ th
 qaumasth
 kefalh/n. It is not common.
For the construction e)pi/ tini, cf. Lach. 183 a e)kei=noi ma/lista tw=n *(ellh/nwn spouda/zousin e)pi\ toi=s toiou/tois, Xen. Mem. i. 3. 11 spouda/zein . . . e)f' oi(=s ou)d) a)
 maino/menos spouda/seien. We find peri/ ti in Phaedo 64 d fai/netai/ soi filoso/fou a)ndro\s ei)=nai e)spoudake/nai peri\ ta\s h(dona/s. For the pf. equiv. to a pres., cf. the passage from Phaedo just quoted.
po/tero/n e)stin . . . w(/s soi dokei=: the more usual idiom would require po/teron dokei= soi ei)=nai.
27 ff.

e)a\n me/n, ei) de/: this variation in the employment of the cond. particles has come to be a rule; i.e. the negative of an e)a\n me/n clause is introduced by ei) de/. If the condition is particular, we find ei) with the fut. indic.; if generic, ei) with the pres. indic., which latter is frequently omitted. In the earlier usage the custom was to give the favorable condition first; hence ei) de\ mh/ comes to have an unpleasant or unfavorable connotation, as here. Cf. also 481 b. The omission of me/n after e)a/n is probably due to its employment with h(du/. On the repetition of me/n and de/ with both clauses, see on 512 a.

a)hde\s kai\ w)fe/limon: the connexion of these two words with kai/ seems somewhat strange, when one considers both the relation of the ideas themselves and the fact that they are preceded by h(du\ me\n . . . ponhro\n de/. The design is probably to emphasize the co-existence of the two ideas, and not their distinctness. There is no contradiction to a)hde/s in the following e)a/n te xai/rwsin kte(.; it refers to the manner in which the spectators will receive his words, concerning which the poet has no reason to trouble himself, provided what he says is correct.—On the omission of o)/n, see GMT. 902; H. 984 a.
le/cei kai\ a)/|setai: viz. in the dialogue and choruses.

perie/loito: Socrates conceives
the difference between prose and poetry to lie simply in the dress, which in the case of poetry surrounds the thought as the shell does the kernel, and is only so far of value.
me/los: i.e. the musical element, the melody, which is especially prominent in lyric productions.
r(uqmo/n: i.e. the regular movement, at the basis of which lies the me/tron, syllable and verse measure.
gi/gnontai: prove to be.

dhmhgori/a: here employed without any unpleasant connotation. It might seem somewhat strange that Callicles so readily admits that dhmhgori/a is r(htorikh/,—an admission on which the whole deduction rests. The reason may be that these wordartists were very prone to extol the universality of their art, without regard to consequences. See Socrates' conversation with Gorgias (especially ch. XI.).

oi(=on . . . gunaikw=n: one is certainly justified in assuming according to this passage that women were admitted to the tragedies; whether they also had the right to attend the comedies remains doubtful. The admission of slaves to the theatre was always restricted.

ei)=en: marks the conclusion of one part of the argument, viz. the premises from which the conclusion is to be drawn. Its employment here, however, also draws especial emphasis to the fact that these premises are definitely settled.
e)n tai=s po/lesin: in the political sense of the word. Cf. Soph. Ant. 737 po/lis ga\r ou)k e)/sq' h(/tis a)ndro/s e)sq) e(no/s.

tou\s tw=n e)leuqe/rwn: is ironic. They consider themselves to be free men, although they are really, even according to the true opinion of Callicles (cf. 489 c above), slaves. Cf. Dem. Ol. iii. 30 to\ me\n pro/teron strateu/esqai tolmw=n au)to\s o( dh=mos despo/ths tw=n politeuome/nwn h)=n kai\ ku/rios au)to\s a(pa/ntwn tw=n a)gaqw=n,—nu=n de\ tou)nanti/on ku/rioi me\n oi( politeuo/menoi tw=n a)gaqw=n kai\ dia\ tou/twn a(/panta pra/ttetai, u(mei=s d' o( dh=mos e)n u(phre/tou kai\ prosqh/khs me/rei gege/nhsqe.

h)\ kai\ ou(=toi kte(.: testimony to the correctness, of this statement is found in the very numerous references and complaints found in the orators, notably Demosthenes. Of course, Plato meant by to\ be/ltiston something a little different from the orators. Cf. Isoc. de Pace § 5 kai\ ga/r toi pepoih/kate tou\s r(h/toras mele- ta=n kai\ filosofei=n ou) ta\ me/llonta th=| po/lei sunoi/sein, a)ll' o(/pws a)re/skontas u(mi=n lo/gous e)rou=sin. The apparent pleonasm arising from the recurrence of the same idea in but slightly varied form is artistic in showing that this thought lay uppermost in the speaker's mind.
w(/sper paisi/: reminds of 464 d.

ou)k a(plou=n: the word has its fundamental meaning. The question requires a double answer. Cf. Lach. 188 c a(plou=n to/ g' e)mo\n peri\ lo/gwn e)sti/n, ei) de\ bou/lei, ou)x a(plou=n, a)lla\ diplou=n. kai\ ga\r a)\n do/caimi/ tw| filo/logos ei)=nai kai\ au)= miso/logos. Cf. also 468 c a(plw=s ou(/tws.

ei) ga\r kai/: kai/ does not belong to tou=to, but to ei). Socrates expresses himself as satisfied with the division made by Callicles, but recognizes even under this condition at least the possibility of a good, commendable rhetoric.

ei)/te h(di/w ei)/te a)hde/stera: Demosthenes, who in many speeches combats the pro\s h(donh/n and pro\s xa/rin dhmhgorei=n, says in Ol. iii. 18, in harmony with Plato's teaching, a)lla\ dei= ta\ be/ltista a)nti\ tw=n h(de/wn, a)\n mh\ sunamfo/tera e)ch=|, lamba/nein.
toiou=ton ei)pei=n: speak of as such.

ti/ ou)xi\ . . . e)/frasas: in passionate questions ti/ ou) is usually construed with the aorist. The question marks impatience that a thing which is future is not past. The idea is usually modal, “why will you not?” Cf. Phaedo 86 d ei)/ tis u(mw=n eu)porw/teros e)mou= ti/ ou)k a)pekri/nato. Different in 468 c.

ai)ti/an e)/xousin: a r(h=ma me/son (vox media). Originally “to bear the blame,” it was gradually worn down until it became merely a circumlocution for le/gesqai, as Theaet. 169 a w(=n dh\ su\ pe/ri ai)ti/an e)/xeis diafe/rein, or Rep. iv. 435 e oi( de\ kai\ e)/xousi tau/thn th\n ai)ti/an (sc. qumoeidei=s ei)=nai). Usually, however, it retains its bad sense, e.g. Apol. 38 c o)/noma e(/cete kai\ ai)ti/an—w(s *swkra/th a)pekto/nate.
ou)k oi)=da ti/s e)stin: when ti/s instead of the more regular o(/stis is used after a neg., it should be conceived rather as a direct question. See on 447 d.

*qemistokle/a kte(.: it is noteworthy that Callicles passes over Aristides, whom Socrates mentions later with respect, and whom also Demosthenes in Ol. iii. 21 speaks of among the statesmen who were still honored down to his time. But Callicles was probably hardly able to appreciate the uprightness and unselfishness of Aristides, which was displayed so prominently in the formation of the Delian League.
a)kou/eis: Greek, like the Eng., often uses the pres. of the verbs of perception where the pf. would be more exact. See GMT. 28; H. 827.

*perikle/a toutoni\ to\n newsti\ teteleuthko/ta: we must guard against drawing the conclusion from this passage that this dialogue was intended to be understood as held soon after Pericles' death. See Introd. § 18. For newsti/ simply means “lately” as compared with the other statesmen mentioned, and the interval between that and the date of the dialogue may still have been a great one. Cf. Hdt. vi. 40. See also on 523 b. The same is true of the Lat. nuper, as we see from Cic. de Nat. Deor. ii. 50. 126 Quid ea, quae nuper, id est paucis ante seculis, medicorum ingeniis reperta sunt.
ou(= a)kh/koas: sc. le/gontos. A possible reference to 455 e.

ei) e)/stin ge kte(.: “yes, if, etc.” The answer is so closely connected with the preceding question that there is no need of supplying an apod. In the second member, ei) de\ mh\ kte(., for which we must supply a pred. from the first, instead of the expected criticism of the men mentioned we have a question based on the principle just proved.

tou=to: viz. to\ . . . a)popimpla/nai. As a pred. supply a)reth\ a)lhqh/s e)stin. We should expect after a)ll' o(/per . . . o(mologei=n some expression corresponding to to\ . . . a)popimpla/nai, instead of which we find o(/ti kte(., due to o(mologei=n, with which we must again supply a)reth\ a)lhqh/s e)stin to govern a)potelei=n.

e)n tw=| u(ste/rw| lo/gw|: refers to 499 e. tou=to de/ continues the recapitulation, and refers to 500 a. Instead of te/xnhn tina/, which we should expect, we find by an anacoluthon the nom. as if w(mologh/qh preceded. On the neglect of the assimilation in tou=to, see Kr. 61, 7, 4.
ou)k e)/xw: Callicles does not understand the standard of judgment, to the exposition of which Socrates now turns.

ou(twsi\ a)tre/ma: quietly, just as we are. ou(/tws is frequently used by itself to denote “under the conditions or circumstances in which we are at present,” and often with
an adverb when it is to be translated separately. Sometimes it follows the adverb, and sometimes it has itself an explanatory addition, as Prot. 351 c a(plw=s ou(/tw, w(s su\ e)rwta=|s. Cf. 460 e, 464 b, 468 c, 478 a, 494 d.
a)poblfpwn pro/s ti: with a view to something, which must, in contrast with ei)kh=|, be a definite object, as is afterwards more clearly shown. See on 474 d.
5 ff.
oi( a)/lloi . . . prosfe/rei: a case of part. apposition. See G. 137, N. 2; H. 624 d. Cf. 450 d. The thought with prosfe/rei is of the single articles out of which the object is to be made.
dhmiourgoi/: see on 452 a.

o(/pws a)\n . . . sxh=|: a general rel. sentence, giving the opposite to ei)kh=|, “that it may acquire for itself some form.” The second aor. of e)/xein is the only second aor. which seems to have an ingressive force. See Gildersleeve's note to Morris' Thuc. i. 12. 3.
ei)=dos: i.e. the outward appearance which an object displays, its figure and form, an image of which the artist of course carries in his mind and gazes upon with the eye of fancy.

ei) bou/lei i)dei=n: with such conversational expressions we should refrain from supplying any definite apod., as doubtless none was felt. The force of this phrase approaches that of a mild imv., sko/pei, after which the objective clause follows naturally with w(s. The subject e(/kastos distributes the tou\s zwgra/fous which has been appropriated as the obj. of i)dei=n.

susth/shtai: is applicable to the form as a whole, because it is only by the harmony of its several parts (to\ e(/teron tw=| e(te/rw| a(rmo/tsein) that it exists. Cf. Phaedr. 269 c to\ d' e(/kasta . . . le/gein te kai\ to\ o(/lon suni/stasqai.

kekosmhme/non: this word, as well as ko/smos below (19), has, of course, no reference to any external adornment, but only to an endowment with such qualities as are requisite for the a)reth/ of the whole. See on e below.

oi(/ te dh\ a)/lloi dhmiourgoi/: would require properly some such
pred. as kosmou=sin e(/kastos to\ e(autou= e)/rgon. But the general thought is here, as often, to be completed by a kind of zeugma from the special one to which the discussion hurries.
ou(\s nundh\ e)le/gomen: sc. in 500 e, which in turn refers to 464 b ff.—The body serves in general as an analogy for the soul.
e)/stw: the imv. indicates only a tentative concession, which Callicles reserves the privilege of recalling if he chooses. The same feeling is felt in a)na/gkh sunomologei=n below.

kai\ mh\n kte(.: is to be completed with necessary changes from the preceding question of Socrates (ta/cews a)/ra kte(.). By kai\ mh/n (and indeed) we pass to the more important part of the argument. Here also the general ideas ta/cis and ko/smos receive special limitations.
tw=| gignome/nw|: belongs to u)/noma/ e)stin, while e)n tw=| sw/mati, in looser relation to the whole, denotes the range to which the question extends.
i)/sws le/geis: in the answer of Callicles shows that, while indeed according to his feelings he would regard such a relation as false and impossible, his reason compels him to admit its truth.
e)ggignome/nw|: the use of the compound verb here, in place of the simple one in the other member of the comparison, is probably due to its close connexion with e)n th=| yuxh=|.

ti/ de\ ou)k au)to\s le/geis: on the meaning of the interr. form, see on 503 b. The question is of the nature of an evasion of the answer, which Callicles pushes upon Socrates to escape responsibility. Cf. 470 b.
fa/qi: see on 475 e.
ei) de\ mh/: see on 502 b.
e)/legxe: with this and e)pi/trepe (yield) the neuter object (“what I say”) is understood. In a similar way e)pitre/pein is used absolutely, Apol. 35 b and elsewhere.
a)reth/: used at first in the general sense of “proper function or condition,” so that it can afterwards appear in its moral force without thereby the standard of judgment being changed.

no/mimo/n te kai\ no/mos: sc. o)/noma ei)=nai. Both expressions are found elsewhere associated in order to express the idea as fully and completely as possible, e.g. Crito 53 c. Here there is the more reason to add no/mos because Callicles had previously used this word in the passage where he first gave expression to his scorn of right and law (ch. XXXVIII. ff.). The corresponding disposition is also elsewhere called ko/smios. Cf. the passage in Crito ta/s te eu)nomoume/nas po/leis kai\ tw=n a)ndrw=n tou\s kosmiwta/tous. Apropos is Phaedo 114 e kosmh/sas th\n yuxh\n ou)k a)llotri/w| a)lla\ tw=| e(auth=s ko/smw| swfrosu/nh| te kai\ dikaiosu/nh| kai\ a)ndrei/a| kai\ e)leuqeri/a| kai\ a)lhqei/a|.
tau=ta: with free reference to what precedes and without assimilation to the predicate, denotes the qualities expressed by no/mimoi and ko/smioi.
e)/stw: see on a above.
pro\s tau=ta ble/pwn: in the choice of words Socrates goes back to what was said in 503 e.

prosoi/sei kte(.: cf. above, 503 e. Although it is by the lo/goi especially that the soul will be shaped, yet
other influences may be brought to bear, just as the orator or statesman (a good specimen of such an orator was Demosthenes) has power to cause gifts to be made to the people—as, for example, the qewriko/n, the dikastiko/n, the stratiwtiko/n, and the bouleutiko/n, and the division of booty, public spectacles, etc.—and also to be taken away from them, for example, by taxes (ei)sforai/) or the abolition of the gifts mentioned.—The connexion forbids us to think of any rougher kind of deprivation, which seemed to Polus (466 c) so enviable a privilege of power.
au)tou=: poss. gen., to be closely connected with toi=s poli/tais (“his fellow-citizens”).
o(\ mh\ o)nh/sei: the generic idea causes the negative mh/.

tou)nanti/on: is certainly adverbial, and to be attached to e)/latton (o)nh/sei). The sense of this difficult passage seems to be something like this: “What advantage is there in giving to a sick man anything which cannot profit him, more or less”; literally, “sometimes more, or on the contrary, at least rightly considered, less.”
u(giai/nonta . . . polla/: is added to make the contrast stronger.
w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n: see on 450 b.
a)no/htos kte(.: see in the discussion with Polus the remark at 477 b, where the ponhri/a of the soul is described in the same way.

a)no/sios: Plato prefers to use only two endings with this adj., which usually, especially in later Greek, has three. The common collocation, as in the present passage, with several other adjs. of only two endings, may perhaps explain his usage.
ou(/tw . . . a)/meinon: sc. than if it were differently dealt with. Cf. 468 b.

w(/sper su\ nundh\ w)/|ou: refers naturally to the second member, for which a predicate is to be supplied from the first. Socrates has in mind 491 e ff. The contradiction between this admission and the statement made at the first (nundh/), Callicles seeks, in his accustomed manner, to evade.
au)to\s tou=to pa/sxwn: Calli

cles has given in the investigation also a practical example of that a)kolasi/a which he had defended in theory. For him the investigation is only a trial of wits. In ou(=tos a)nh\r kte(. we may have a reminiscence of the expression used by Callicles of Socrates in 489 b.

katalu/omen: this idiomatic use of the pres. instead of the fut. of a course of action to be immediately taken is also idiomatic in Latin and English. See Kr. 53, 1, 9. In a somewhat similar manner the pres. is used of the immediate consequence by Dem. de Falsa Leg. 32 ei) de/ fhsin ou(=tos, deica/tw kai\ parasxe/sqw, ka)gw\ katabai/nw. Cf. 513 c.
au)to\s gnw/sei: refuses to answer. “You will have to decide that.”

ou)de\ tou\s mu/qous: to say nothing of a lo/gos which is directed to a definite object. The proverb, which Socrates quotes, seems to rest upon a religious feeling, in accordance with which myths had to be completely narrated in order not to draw upon the narrator the anger of the deity. Cf. Phileb. 66 d to\ meta\ tau=q' h(mi=n ou)de
 loipo
 plh
 w(/sper kefalh
 a)podou=nai toi=s ei)rhme/nois, Euthyd. 301 e to
 kolofw=na e)pitiqe/nai.—
qe/mis: “right acc. to sacred law.”

perii/h|: the change from the pl. (tou\s mu/qous) to the sing. is explained by the freedom of conversation. Cf. Prot. 319 d tou/tois ou)dei\s tou=to e)piplh/ttei w(/sper toi=s pro/teron, o(/ti ou)damo/qen maqw\n . . . sumbouleu/ein e)pixeirei=.
w(s bi/aios ei)=: cf. 491 e w(s h(du\s ei)=.—

bi/aios: usually in contrast with pei/qein, e.g. Polit. 304 d ei)/te dia\ peiqou=s ei)/te dia/ tinos bi/as is applied here by Callicles to Socrates' persistent argument; cf. Apol. 35 d ei) pei/qoimi u(ma=s kai\ tw=| dei=sqai biazoi/mhn.
ti/s ou)=n kte(.: since the question assumes the necessity that some one take the role of respondent, a causal clause follows.
mh\ . . . katalei/pwpen: for let us no longer leave, etc.

au)to\s de\ kte(.: the question has
a tone of reproof. au)to/s is opposed to a)/llw| dialego/menos. The requirements of the question can be fulfilled in two ways,—either in continuous discourse, as 464 b-466 a, or in the form of a dialogue, which Socrates employs later (ch. LXII.).

to\ tou= *)epixa/rmou: Epicharmus was a native of Cos, but early went to Sicily (Megara) and devoted himself there to the study of medicine and philosophy, especially the Pythagorean and Empedoclean. But his claim to fame rests on his comedies. He stands at the head of the Sicilian comic poets, being noted for the ethical nature of his poetry. It was full of sententious sayings, and thereby aroused Plato's interest to the highest degree. He flourished during the Persian war, under the government of Gelo. The verse here cited reads, according to Athenaeus:
ta\ pro\ tou= du/) a)/ndres e)/legon
ei(=s e)gw\n a)poxre/w (i.e. a)poxra/w, I am sufficient.
Socrates means that he is himself assuming a burden which according to the nature of the matter requires two. The answer is in construction connected with the question of Callicles in order to disclose for the others' consideration the doubtful side, as it were, of such a demand. With this the following a)ta/r (however) agrees.
filoni/kws e)/xein: see on 457 d. Socrates wishes to direct ambition only to proper objects.

ti/ yeu=dos: yeu=dos is frequently found opposed to a)lhqe/s. Cf. Apol. 34 e ei)/te ou)=n a)lhqe\s, ei)/te ou)=n yeu=dos, Euthyd. 272 a e)a/n te yeu=dos e)a/n te a)lhqe\s h)=|. The article with a)lhqe/s is due to its position. We should also have in like manner to\ yeu=dos, did it precede ti/ e)stin. Cron thinks it denotes that truth is single, while error has many forms.
e)a\n... lang=greek>dokw=, xrh\ kte(.: is an anticipatory cond. sentence, xrh/ with the inf. having the force of an imv. Cf. e)pilamba/nou in b below.
o(mologei=n e)mautw=|: Socrates is about to combine the two roles of questioner and respondent, and hence will have to assent to his own statements.

a)ntilamba/nesqai: with the gen., means to “break in upon a discourse for the purpose of contesting a point,” as in Rep. i. 336 b kai\ o( *qrasu/maxos polla/kis kai\ dialegome/nwn h(mw=n metacu\ w(/rma a)ntilamba/nesqai tou= lo/gou. On the other hand e)pilamba/nesqai, used below in b, means simply “to arrest the discussion.” See on 469 c.
a)\n ti\ fai/nhtai kte(.: the emphasis is on the indefinite, as in 472 a.

a)ll' e)moi\ kte(.: on the assumption by Gorgias of the role of mediator, and the justice of his claim to speak in the name of all, see Introd. § 13 fin. Cf. 497 b. His request to proceed is a part of the artistic machinery of the dialogue, in that it affords an opportunity for a general summary of what has been already learned in the discussion, which was necessary in order to proceed intelligently.
ou) . . . tw: a rather unusual ‘tmesis,’ of which another example is found in Meno 72 d ou) me/ntoi w(s bou/lomai/ ge/ pw kate/xw to\ e)rwtw/menon.

bou/lomai ga\r kte(.: with these words Gorgias expresses his approbation of Callicles' opinion that a respondent is not necessary. The chestnuts are good,—but just as good without the intervention of the cat. Hence ga/r to give a reason for the continuance of the discussion, kai\ au)to/s to show his agreement with Callicles, and au)tou= to exclude the idea of co-operation. The following kai\ au)to/s in the answer of Socrates corresponds to the similar expression of Gorgias.

*)amfi/onos: Socrates answers with a pleasant allusion to 485 e. He will really assume the character of Amphion, which had been imputed to him, and as Amphion had in the plays of Euripides defended his calling, so will he prove that the claim of philosophy to be followed as a calling in life is a just and weighty one.
a)pe/dwka: the indic. is due to assimilation with the preceding indic. with a)/n of the unfulfilled condition.
a)ll' ou)=n . . . e)pilamba/nou: see on 496 d and a above.

eu)erge/ths a)nagegra/yei: this phrase is found in Hdt. viii. 85, and was doubtless technical, the fut. pf. expressing like the legal pf. the finality and fixity of the action. It was quite common for Greek states to confer the title of eu)erge/ths on citizens or strangers, especially foreign statesmen or princes, for services rendered them. The decree conferring the honor was engraved on stone and preserved. In Apol. 36 d Socrates claims the title for himself. The greatest benefit consists, according to 458 a, in freeing a man from error.

w)= a)gaqe/: a friendly manner of address, which frequently, however, has an ironical coloring, or a tone of condescension, depreciation, or correction. So in Lat., o bone, cf. Hor. Sat. ii. 3. 31; or bone vir in comedy.
w(s e)gw\ kai\ *kalliklh=s w(mologh/samen: sc. in 495 c ff. Cf. especially 500 d.
paragenome/nou, paro/ntos: the words may have been designedly chosen with reference to the nature of the ideas h(du/ and a)gaqo/n, the former being only a condition, the latter an actuality.

h(du\ de/ e)stin kte(.: on the h(du/, cf. what Callicles has himself remarked in 494 a, b, above, and especially Phileb. 53 c a)=ra peri\ h(donh=s ou)k a)khko/amen, w(s a)ei\ ge/nesi/s e)stin, ou)si/a d' ou)k e)/sti to\ para/pan h(donh=s. On the a)gaqo/n, cf. above 468 b e(/nek' a)/ra tou= a)gaqou= a(/panta poiou=sin oi( poiou=ntes and Phileb. 54 c ou)kou=n h(donh/ ge, ei)/per ge/nesi/s e)stin, e(/neka/ tinos ou)si/as e)c a)na/gkhs gi/gnoit' a)/n—*to/ ge mh\n ou(= e(/neka to\ e(/neka/ tou gigno/menon a)ei\ gi/gnoit) a)/n, e)n th=| tou= a)gaqou= moi/ra| e)kei=no/ e)sti. This distinction, however, even if intended, is not preserved, as can be seen from the following (8) a)reth=s tinos paragenome/nhs. See on 497 e.

a)reth/: the subst. to denote the form in which the Good manifests itself in persons and things. According to its real nature the Good re
mains one and the same, but its manifestation (the a)reth/) assumes various names according to circumstances.
tw)| ei)kh=|: on the use of the art. with adverbs, see Kr. 50, 5, 10. The dat. is in the same construction as those following.

ta/cei kai\ o)rqo/thti kai\ te/xnh|: the two latter words simply complete the first. We might translate them as adjs. The addition of ka/llista seems to admit the possibility of a kind of a)reth/ being brought about by other means than ta/cei kte(.
o( e(ka/stou oi)kei=os: the nature of each thing conditions the peculiarity of its ko/smos. Hence this may receive different names, according to the conditions.

su/ . . . di/daske: Socrates turns now again to Callicles and tries to draw him into the conversation, be cause the argument has now been brought just to the point where Callicles broke it off before.
le/ge: go on with your exposition. This answer is a refusal to cooperate and at the same time a neg. answer to ei) e)/xeis.

25 ff. The idea of swfrosu/nh is defined in the most general way by the expression ta\ prosh/konta pra/ttein. We attain to the idea of righteousness and piety by restricting the prosh/konta to definite domains, according to the personages (men and gods) towards whom we have duties to perform. We attain to the idea of bravery by distinguishing between especial divisions of the idea pra/ttein. Accordingly, we have on the one side diw/kein kai\ feu/gein, on the other u(pome/nonta karterei=n.

h(dona\s kai\ lu/pas: added by Socrates in his enumeration because it is just in these spheres that swfrosu/nh is usually exercised. The point at which bravery necessarily coincides with it comes out in this way most emphatically. The exhibition of bravery under such conditions is also discussed in Lach. ch. xviii.

a)gaqo\n . . . tele/ws: ‘the perfection of goodness.’ Cope. All the virtues combined make the a)gaqo\n a)/ndra. Wisdom is omitted, probably because Socrates has in mind only the earlier discussion, and besides he is taking for the moment the popular point of view; hence the collocation of o(/sion with di/kaion, as in Protagoras. Besides, as Socrates' view was that all evil-acting springs from ignorance, the fact that a man wàs di/kaios, a)ndrei=os, and o(/sios would presuppose the possession of wisdom.

to
 d' eu)= pra/ttonta kte(.: not in the sense “he who is fortunate,” so often found, but in the sense of the clause eu)= kai\ kalw=s pra/ttein a(\ a)
 pra/tth| preceding; otherwise it would be equivalent to maka/rion kai\ eu)dai/mona, and the syllogism would gain nothing. Plato therefore conceives eu)= pra/ttein a(\ a)
 pra/tth| the necessary basis for maka/rion ei)=nai, and the latter as the natural result of the former. Hence there is no case of a fallacia secundum dictionem (by the use of homonyms or a)mfiboli/a), but the conclusion o( a)ko/lastos a)/qlios is correctly and legitimately obtained by a combination of the second statement with the first and without any fallacious or sophistical reasoning.
kai/ fhmi tau=ta: the repetition of tau=ta causes these principles to appear especially weighty.

to\n boulo/menon . . . diwkte/on: the verbal is equivalent here to dei= with the inf. The regular case for the agent is the dat.; the acc. is rare. See H. 991 a, and cf. 480 e. The position of w(s e)/oiken, which belongs to the whole clause, is noteworthy.

w(s e)/xei podw=n: i.e. to the full extent of his power, a phrase whose origin can be readily seen. Cf. Hdt. vi. 116 ou(=toi me\n dh\ perie/pleon *sou/nion. *)aqhnai=oi de\ w(s podw=n ei)=xon ta/xista e)boh/qeon e)s to\ a)/stu kai\ e)/fqhsan a)piko/menoi pri\n h)\ tou\s barba/rous h(/kein, and Thuc. ii. 90. 4 *peloponnh/sioi . . . e)/pleon w(s ei)=xe ta/xous e(/kastos e)pi\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous. On the use of the gen. with such adverbs as w(s, a)/rista, and i(kanw=s, and e)/xein, see G. 168, 3; H. 757 a.
paraskeuaste/on: in a middle sense, as is frequently the case with verbals, but only when used impersonally.

h)\ i)diw/ths h)\ po/lis: disjunctive apposition to a)/llos tis tw=n oi)kei/wn. Contrasted with po/lis, i)diw/ths denotes the individual; with a)/rxwn, the common man who holds no office; with dhmiourgo/s and similar words, one who is not versed in a certain thing.—
e)piqete/on di/khn: Socrates deduces from the principles proven exactly the conclusions which, in his argument with Polus, had so offended Callicles. Cf. 480, 481.

pa/nta ta\ au(tou=: “all the powers of the body and soul.” Cf. the passage quoted below (10), and Crito 46 b ta\ e)ma/. The construction of kai\ pa/nta kte(. shows another example of the common Greek idiom of following a rel. by a demonstrative. See on 452 d.

ei)s tou=to: takes up again ou(=tos o( sko/pos for the purpose of recapitulating in its correlative clause, o(/pws kte(., the substance of what has been explained; ou(/tw again reiterates in one word the whole previous participial clause, and connects it with pra/ttein, which has the same construction as zh=n. The positive directions summarized in ou(/tw are still further fixed (after Plato's habit) by the following negative direction
in the epexegetical participial clause ou)k e)piqumi/as e)w=nta . . . plhrou=n. After plhrou=n we find the parenthetical criticism a)nh/nuton kako/n, while the life of the man who attempts what is deprecated in the participial clause, is characterized very emphatically by the appositional tag which completes this rambling, intensely conversational sentence.

suntei/nonta: the image is that of drawing the bow and aiming, to the employment of which, sko/pos has led the way. We find in Rep. ix. 591 c the same image in a similar connexion, o(/ ge nou=n e)/xwn pa/nta ta\ au(tou= ei)s tou=to cuntei/nas bi/wsetai.

a)nh/nuton kako/n: “an evil to which there is no end.” The striving to satisfy the desires is also called an a)nh/nuton e)/rgon in Phaedo 84 a, and compared with the web of Penelope, which was begun every day anew. On the apposition, see G. 137, 3; H. 626.
lh|stou bi/on zw=nta: for the appositional partic. see Kr. 56, 15, 3.
a)du/natos: in an active sense.

koinwni/a: in passing, Socrates shows that the only foundation for an all-embracing view of the world is found in correct moral principle. Both in nature and in the universe the harmony of the parts with each other and with the whole is essential for existence. The state, and, proceeding further, the moral condition of the individual soul, should therefore be modelled on the principle of general order which pervades the world.

oi( sofoi/: those especially meant are the Pythagoreans, to whose views Plato had had recourse before. Cf. 493 a. Pythagoras is said first to have applied to the world the name ko/smos. He was followed by Empedocles with his scientific system, according to which there are two principles in the world,—love, filo/ths (storgh/, *)afrodi/th, a(rmoni/h), and hate, nei=kos. The former is the cause of association and union, the latter of separation and disunion. Cf. Emped. 94, Karst. *)/allote me\n filo/thti sunerxo/men' ei)s e(\n a(/panta, | *)/allote d' au)= di/x) e(/kasta foreu/mena nei/keos e)/xqei.

sune/xein: the subj. of the inf. is th\n koinwni/an, as is shown by the art. as well as the connexion. Cf. Soph. 242 e to\ o)\n . . . e)/xqra| kai\ fili/a| sune/xetai. The omission of the art. in enumerations is common. See on 450 d.

dikaio/thta: an unusual word for justice, formed like kosmio/ths and i)so/ths. It was probably chosen here on account of the assonance. Similarly Prot. 331 b tau)to/n e)sti dikaio/ths o(sio/thti. Xenophon also uses the word.
kai\ tau=ta: the regular Greek expression for “and that too.” See H. 612 a.

h( gewmetrikh/: adds a limitation to the i)so/ths, that absolute equality, which is impossible in any government. i)so/ths alone is purely arithmetical equality (a = b); i)so/ths gewmetrikh/ is ratio or proportion (a:b::c:d). Plato distinguishes between two kinds of i)so/ths in Leg. vi. 757 b, the one th
 me/trw| i)/shn kai\ staqmw=| kai\ a)riqmw=|, the arithmetical; the second, th
 a)lhqesta/thn kai\ a)ri/sthn i)so/thta, the geometric, which is not comprehensible by every man, and which is dependent upon the judgment and decision of the gods. Of this he says (ib.): tw=| me
 mei/zoni plei/w, tw=| d' e)la/ttoni smikro/tera ne/mei, me/tria didou=sa pro\s th
 au)tw=n fu/sin e(kate/rw|, kai\ dh\ kai\ tima\s mei/zosi me
 pro\s a)reth
 a)ei\ mei/zous, toi=s de\ tou)nanti/on e)/xousin a)reth=s te kai\ paidei/as to\ pre/pon e(kate/rois a)pone/mei kata\ lo/gon. On this i)so/ths, which is here opposed to pleoneci/a, is founded the administration of justice in the state (ib. to\ politiko
 tou=t' au)to\ to\ di/kaion). Aris totle also (Nic. Eth. v. 6, 7, Bekk.) refers to\ e)n dianomh=| di/kaion back to a)nalogi/a, i.e. to i)so/ths lo/gwn, and adds, kalou=si de\ th
 toiau/thn a)nalogi/an gewmetrikh
 oi( maqhmatikoi/. Isocrates expresses himself to the same effect in Areop. (vii.) 20 ff., where he says of Solon and Cleisthenes, me/giston au)toi=s suneba/leto pro\s to\ kalw=s oi)kei=n th
 po/lin, o(/ti duoi=n i)soth/toin nomizome/nain ei)=nai, kai\ th=s me
 tau)to
 a(/pasin a)ponemou/shs, th=s de\ to\ prosh=kon e(ka/stois, ou)k h)gno/oun th
 xrhsimwte/ran kte(. Thompson also quotes Plut. Mor. 719 b, according to which Lycurgus ‘expelled from Lacedaemon arithmetical equality, holding it to be democratic and levelling in principle, and introduced the geometric, as better suited to a temperate oligarchy and monarchy.’
gewmetri/as ga\r a)melei=s: Plato considered mathematics as a necessary preliminary to philosophy. Hence the well-known mhdei\s a)gewme/trhtos ei)si/tw mou th\n ste/ghn upon his house.
ei)=en: see on 466 c. Cf. 472 d, 480 a.
h)\ e)celegkte/os dh\ kte(.: the alternative appears as the obvious and necessary result of what precedes. The meaning and construction are similar to 482 b (w(s ou) kte(.). See on 467 a.
oi( a)/qlioi a)/qlioi: if the emendation is correct, we have an example of chiasmus, as in 498 d.
ti/ ta\ sumbai/nonta: the sing. ti/ inquires for the general result, which may include various details. See Kr. 61, 8, 2.

a(\ *pw=lon ai)sxu/nh| kte(.: with this Socrates avoids the accusation that he may have defended those principles only for the sake of confuting his adversary. They are seen now to be quite necessarily bound together with a moral view of life. Note the difference in the tenses, sugxwrei=n (equiv. to sunexw/rei) and below (37) o(mologh=sai (equiv. to w(molo/ghse).
LXIV.

w(s ou)x oi(=o/s t' ei)mi\ kte(.: this objection Callicles had only brought forward as a possibility, not as an actual fact (486 a, b). Socrates treats it as the latter, but even thus it does not misrepresent Callicles' sentiments.

w(/sper oi( a)/timoi: see on 486 c. As the reading stands, tou= e)qe/lontos must be considered as a variant for e)pi\ tw=| boulome/nw|. In spite of Plato's fondness for poikili/a, it is hardly likely that he would use bou/lesqai and qe/lein as identical in meaning.
to\ neaniko\n dh\ tou=to: in appo
sition to the whole clause, but more especially to the words which follow. See on 447 a. For the meaning, see on 482 c.
o(/stis: viz. e)sti/n. The omission of the verb in the dependent question is very uncommon.
e)/ti: almost equivalent to e)/ti pleona/kis.

te/mnesqai to\ sw=ma: may be a delicate allusion to 473 c (e)kte/mnhtai) as to\ balla/ntion and kle/ptein to 486 c (u(po\ de\ tw=n e)xqrw=n perisula=sqai pa=san th\n ou)si/an), but it is more probable, owing to its common association with balla/ntion, that te/mnesqai is used generally like the Lat. secari. In view of Socrates' poverty, this savors of humor.

balla/ntion: a leathern purse for carrying money, which was fastened to the girdle. The ballantioto/moi (cut-purses) were men who made a business of slipping off such purses in the market-places and the baths, and against whom it was difficult to protect one's self. This sentence is also a commentary on the mischiev

ous results of the principle defended by Callicles, which was sure to introduce the most outrageous kinds of a)diki/a. Apropos of this, cf. also the view of Thrasymachus in Rep. i. 344, especially b kai\ ga\r i(ero/suloi kai\ a)ndrapodistai\ kte(., oi( kata\ me/rh a)dikou=ntes tw=n toiou/twn kakourghma/twn kalou=ntai: e)peida\n de/ tis pro\s roi=s tw=n politw=n xrh/masi kai\ au)tou\s a)ndrapodisa/menos doulw/shtai, a)nti\ tou/twn tw=n ai)sxrw=n o)noma/twn eu)dai/mones kai\ maka/rioi ke/klhntai.

kai\ ei) a)groiko/tero/n ti ei)pei=n: see on 462 e. The kai\ ei) shows that the word used is correct, though harsh. See crit. note on 503 a. The definite indic. is used in order to excuse the unusual comparison of arguments to iron and steel fetters. The simile is well chosen, and is a good retort on Callicles, who in 484 a had
characterized the laws and moral rules as bonds which the true man must break through (diarrh/cas).
ou(twsi/: “as matters stand,” i.e. so far as these principles have been tested. They may be attacked with new arguments, in which case new defences would have to be made.—
ei) mh\ lu/seis: the stern minatory conditional form. See on 502 b.
neanikw/teros: i.e. who is more powerful and courageous, just as Callicles surpassed Polus, and Polus Gorgias.
o( au)to\s lo/gos: cf. 506 a ou)de\ ga\r e)/gwge ei)dw\s le/gw a(\ le/gw.
w(=n . . . e)ntetu/xhka: on this unusual kind of attraction, see G. 153, 2; H. 996 a. We miss a mention of the persons with w(/sper nu=n.
mh\ ou): after a negatived leading verb, the negative of the inf. is generally made by mh\ ou). See Madv. Syn. § 211; GMT. 815.

au)= ti/qhmi: sc. as against the opposing opinions of all others. This statement now, taken as a basis (ei) de\ ou(/tws e)/xei) leads to a conclusion which is given in the form of a question. ti/qhmi is frequently used of the laying down of a principle or assumption. Cf. Rep. ii. 361 b toiou=ton qe/ntes to\n di/kaion, Theaet. 191 c.
tou/tou mei=zon megi/stou o)/ntos: notice the comparison of the superlative.
a)lla/: introduces a more definite and detailed statement of a thought involved in the previous question.

tau/thn ei)=nai th\n ai)sxi/sthn kte(.: a noteworthy instance of the employment of a very common construction, which is as old as Homer (Kr. Di. 55, 3, 8). Logically we should expect tau/thn th\n boh/qeian mh\ du/nasqai bohqei=n ai)/sxiston ei)=nai. But boh/qeian, being uppermost in the speaker's mind, is made the subject, instead of cognate accusative, drawing also the predicate after it (see on 449

b, c). In this way mh\ du/nasqai bohqei=n is characterized as a species, and the
most shameful species, of boh/qeia, which was pretty exactly Plato's opinion of the assistance which the orators were in the habit of rendering to themselves and their friends before a court. This assimilation is extended to the following clauses, deute/ran etc., for the sake of consistency.
e)f' e(/kasta: viz. kaka/, which are conceived as the enemy to be fought. Instead of ai)sxu/nh we should have expected ai)sxu/nhn.

ou)k a)/llws: it is remarkable that after his utterances in 505 d Callicles allows himself to be again drawn into the discussion. *(ekw\n a)e/konti/ ge qumw=|; For that the answer slips from him unconsciously, instead of being a willing admission, seems to follow from e)/stw soi tou=to (510 a), where his earlier disposition again becomes plain.
tou= a)dikei=n kte(.: in apposition to the duoi=n.
a)mfote/ras: the following investigation takes up each of the two cases separately.
du/namin h)\ bou/lhsin: what has been determined in 466 d regarding du/nasqai and bou/lesqai still holds good, but is expanded in what follows.
a)dikh/setai: the fut. middle as a passive occurs more commonly with pure verbs. See Kr. 39, 11; H. 496.
dh=lon dh\ kte(.: the form of the answer shows very willing agreement, which applies, however, only to this particular point.

ti/ de\ dh\ tou= kte(.: cf. Phaedo 78 d ti/ de\ tw=n pollw=n kalw=n, oi(=on
a)nqrw/pwn h)\ i(/ppwn . . .; a)=ra kata\ tau)ta\ e)/xei kte(. It is not necessary to supply peri/ or some other word; when put thus freely at the beginning of the sentence, the genitive is held up to view and the case lost sight of. See Rid. § 27. The acc. also is occasionally thus ‘freely’ used. Cf. Lyc. 28 kai\ tau=ta e)mou= qewrh/sate, w(s dikai/an th\n e)ce/tasin poioume/nou peri\ tou/twn.
du/namin kai\ te/xnhn . . . ma/qh| kai\ a)skh/sh|: an example of chiasmus. Knowledge is preserved and strengthened by practice.
w(s . . . a)dikh/sei: the causal use of w(s is not common. See Kr. 65, 8; H. 925.
au)ta/: for the neut. pl. referring to two preceding fem. sings. see Kr. 58, 3, 5; H. 630, 633.
ti/ ou)k . . . a)pekri/nw: see on 503 b.

boulo/menon: for the usual e(ko/nta, in order not to diminish the contrast between du/namis and bou/lhsis. Besides, it has just been shown to Polus that he who does wrong does only what seems to him good, not what he wishes, because the wish is always for the good.
a)dikh/somen: according to (the amended) Dawes' canon o(/pws in object clauses cannot be construed with the first aor. subjv. either act. or middle. See GMT. 363, 364.
e(tai=ron: the common word to express party affiliation (hence also e(tairei=ai, “clubs”), as in Apol. 21 a u(mw=n tw=| plh/qei e(tai=ros.

o(ra=s kte(.: expression of joy that Socrates, with whom Callicles has had so often to agree unwillingly and under protest, now speaks quite to his liking. This view is the one thought of his life. Cf. 475 a.

sko/pei... lang=greek>e)a/n soi dokw= kte(.: for the construction with sko/pei see H. 1016 c, and on 452 c. Cf. above in a. ‘What is worth noticing upon this usage is that e)a/n gives a different shade of meaning from the more usual ei). The question submitted is represented by it as a perfectly open one; whereas ei) would limit the speaker's foregone conclusion, and give a certain appearance of positiveness. e)a/n is therefore chosen for the sake of expressing more perfect courtesy, in contexts such as this, which relate to the conduct of a dialogue.’ Rid. § 64.
e(/kastos e(ka/stw|: does not de note an unlimited reciprocality, but a restricted one, as is shown by the following o( o(moi=os tw=| o(moi/w|.

o(/nper . . . le/gousin: which the wise men of old mean when they say (le/gousin). The following proverb occurs very early, i.e. in Homer r 218 w(s ai)ei\ to\n o(moi=on a)/gei qeo\s w(s to\n o(moi=on. Plato often employs it, e.g. Prot. 337 d to\ ga\r o(moi=on tw=| o(moi/w| fu/sei suggene/s e)stin, Symp. 195 b o( ga\r palaio\s lo/gos eu)= e)/xei, w(s o(moi=on o(moi/w| a)ei\ pela/zei, Lys. 214 b to\ o(moi=on tw=| o(moi/w| a)na/gkh a)ei\ fi/lon ei)=nai. Of kindred import is the well-known verse h(=lic h(/lika te/rpe, ge/rwn de/ te te/rpe ge/ronta, alluded to in Phaedr. 240 c.
o(/pou tu/ranno/s kte(.: ‘where a savage and illiterate ruler is lord and master.’ Cope. In what follows, tou/tou refers to tu/rannos, tou/tw| through au)to/n to the ti\s.
ou)d' a)\n ou(/tws: is to be completed according to the previous remark of Socrates.

a)/cios lo/gou fi/los: pred. after lei/petai. According to the nature of the case none other could come under consideration as lasting friends of the tyrant, even if they should show themselves friendly for a time.
tau)ta\ ye/gein kai\ e)painei=n: like toi=s au)toi=s xai/rein kai\ a)/xqesqai is the external sign of a similarity of disposition and friendliness. See on 473 a.

u(pokei=sqai: in the elsewhere not uncommon meaning, “to be subject to.” Its use here is to emphasize the degradation in the eyes of a free man. Cf. also Crito 53 e u(perxo/menos dh\ biw/sei pa/ntas a)nqrw/pous kai\ douleu/wn.

xai/rwn a)dikh/sei: the partic. denotes the result of the verb. “He will have no reason to rejoice,” i.e. he will not injure him with impunity. Cf. Soph. O. R. 363 a)ll' ou)/ ti xai/rwn di/s ge phmona\s e)rei=s.

ei) a)/ra tis: the case which Socrates here assumes in illustration serves not only to enliven the discourse, but also to show (as opposed to the objections of ch. XL.) how unworthy and debased an object would have to be set before educators if the possession of power in the state is to be the leading aim of mankind.— Noteworthy is the use of the direct question after the introductory protasis, and furthermore the omission of some apodosis corresponding to the protasis, like gnoi/h a)\n o(/ti, in place of which we find w(s e)/oiken. Kr. gives other similar examples in 65, 5, 14. Similar cases occur in Latin.
e)n tau/th| th=| po/lei: see on 468 e. The position is noteworthy.

mhdei/s me a)dikoi/h : mh/ was the negative of the wish, underlying the question, and is thus retained. It is therefore not necessary, with GMT. 292, 2, to suppose an idea of prevention to be involved. How could I obtain great power and no one do (prevent any one from doing, GMT.) me wrong?
diapepra/cetai: the fut. pf. is employed to express finality or fixedness. Cope translates, “he will establish for himself a lasting immunity from,” etc. See on 469 d.
e)pi\ to\ oi(/w| te ei)=nai: this is considered by Callicles and Polus as an end to be desired.—On the change of case, oi(/w| and a)dikou=nta, see on 492 b.

kai\ du/namin: the way to become powerful, says Socrates above, is to imitate the despo/ths. Hence kai\ du/namin is the power (to\ me/ga du/nasqai) obtained by this mi/mhsis (o(/pws o(/ti ma/lista o(moi=os e)/stai).

o(/ph| stre/feis: the last conclu sion of Socrates is not agreeable to Callicles, who therefore declares it an arbitrary perversion of the argument. The stre/fein a)/nw ka/tw (see on 481 e), the twisting this way and that of words and ideas so that their sense was reversed, was an important department of Eristic.

e)a\n bou/lhtai: the use of bou/lesqai again shows that the detailed explanation by Socrates of the difference between bou/lesqai and dokei=n (ch. XXIII. f.) was in vain. Hence Socrates himself ceases to regard it in his answer.
ei) mh\ kwfo/s g' ei)mi/: “otherwise I would have to be deaf.” Cf. Prot. 349 e ka/lliston . . . ei) mh\ mai/nomai/ ge.
polla/kis: 486 b, 466 c, et al.

a)poktenei= me
 kte(.: cf. Plut. Agis 20 o( me
 ou)=n *)=agis e)pi\ th
 stralla/lhn poreuo/menos, w(s ei)=de/ tina tw=n u(phretw=n dakru/onta kai\ peripaqou=nta, “pau=sai/ me” ei)=pen, “w)= a)/nqrwpe, klai/wn. kai\ ga ou(/tws parano/mws kai\ a)di/kws a)pollu/menos krei/ttwn ei)mi\ tw=n a)nairou/ntwn.”

kai\ to\ a)ganakthto/n : kai\ is climactic and the art. emphatic. “So far from this circumstance mitigating the outrage, is it not just the revolting part of it,” i.e. especially revolting? Callicles puts himself in the place of the one who suffers the wrong, but with a feeling quite the reverse to that of Agis, quoted in the preceding note. In a similar manner Apollodorus says in [Xen.] Apol. 28 *)alla\ tou=to e)/gwge, w)= *sw/krates, xalepw/tata fe/rw o(/ti o(rw= se a)di/- kws a)poqnh/|skonta. to
 de\ le/getai katayh/santa au)tou= th
 kefalh
 ei)pei=n, *su\ de/, w)= fi/ltate *)apollo/dwre, ma=llon a)
 e)bou/lou me o(ra=n dikai/ws a)poqnh/| skonta;
w(s o( lo/gos shmai/nei: assumes that the statement has already been proved by the course of the argument. Cf. 527 c.
dei=n . . . zh=n: against such an over-valuation of life Socrates declares himself also in Apol. 28, 29; Crito 48 b.
th\n r(htorikh/n: the position is very emphatic. For examples of the rel. clause preceding the antecedent, see Kr. 51, 11.
sumbouleu/wn: connected in construction with the last words of Socrates, as is frequently the case in answers. Cf. 451 d o)rqw=s ge le/gwn su/, 473 b a)lhqh= ge oi)o/menos i)/sws. See Kr. 56, 8, 7.

toiou=ton: has its correlative in ou(=, which, like other relative adverbs, often stands for a prepositional phrase, as here equiv. to e)n w(=|. Frequently we find ti\ added to toiou=ton. The sense of toiou=ton is made clear by the context.

ta\ sw/mata kai\ ta\ xrh/mata: probably this phrase was a common one, and we must therefore not press a contrast between ta\ sw/mata and ta\s yuxa/s, which latter refers especially to their lives. Thompson supposes, with some probability, that sw/mata refers to the other members of the passenger's family, who may be conceived as belonging to him. Perhaps “goods and chattels” may be as good a rendering as any.

prosestalme/nh: “retired,” i.e. unpretending. Still stronger is sunestalme/nos, as i.e. in Isoc. Panath. 230 a)ph/|ei fronimw/teros gegenhme/nos kai\ sunestalme/nhn e)/xwn th\n dia/noian (“with a feeling of humility”).
e)sxhmatisme/nh: cf. Soph. 268 a w(s a)gnoei= tau=ta a(\ pro\s tou\s a)/llous w(s ei)dw=s e)sxhma/tistai (“which he has pretended to know”).
th=| dikanikh=|: used by Socrates instead of th=| r(htorikh=| because this species of the art affords the most room for comparison.

du/) o)bolou/s: i.e. about six cents. The price was accordingly very low, if, as is shown by what follows, the fare from Egypt or Pontus (a dangerous voyage besides) for a whole family, including baggage, was only two drachmae, or about thirty-five cents.
e)pra/cato: ‘gnomic’ or ‘empiric’ aorist.

au)to/n: the regular designation for the master of the house, who is frequently opposed to the rest of the family as here. See on 447 c. The order of enumeration is noteworthy as showing the low estimation in which the women were held. The pl. may be due to assimilation to pai=das, as we say “wife and child,” or it may be collective, “women folks.”
para\ th\n qa/lattan: also effective in the portrayal of the seaman's unpretending nature.

e)n metri/w| sxh/mati: with unassuming carriage, has nothing to do with the dress, but merely with the deportment (cf. above, prosestalme/nh). Perhaps there is a slight hit at Gorgias' pompous manner. See Introd. § 5 end

logi/zesqai ... e)pi/statai: naturally not meant in full earnest, and not without some color of irony. The change of tense in w)fe/lhke and e)/blaye is probably due merely to the frequency of the form.
ou(/stinas wfe/lhke kte(.: reminds us of Matt. xviii. 6, where of those who offend it is said: sumfe/rei au)tw=| i(/na ... katapontisqh=| e)n tw=| pela/gei th=s qala/sshs.
h)\ oi(\ a<*>ne/bhsan: it is a Greek peculiarity to compare different states by employing the gen. of the reflexive. Here a clause takes its place.

logi/zetai o(/ti ou)k: the force of the neg. extends over the whole sentence, which is developed antithet ically. Since both leading clauses are hypothetical, we have a double employment of me/n and de/. The first member of the antithesis is given first only for the sake of the contrast; we should use a subordinate clause in English, and lay the most stress on the second member, and, too, on its conclusion. Cf. Apol. 28 e e)gw\ ou)=n deina\ a)
 ei)/hn ei)rgasme/nos, ei) o(/te me/n me oi( a)/rxontes e)/tatton, ou(\s u(mei=s ei(/lesqe a)/rxein mou, to/te me
 ou(= e)kei=noi e)/tatton e)/menon—tou= de\ qeou= ta/ttontos, w(s e)gw\ w)|h/qhn te kai\ u(pe/labon, filosofou=nta/ me dei=n zh=n—e)nt<*>u=qa de\ fobhqei\s h)\ qa/naton h)\ a)/llo o(tiou=n pra=gma li/poimi th
 ta/cin. See on 502 b and 499 d.

a)/qlios o(/ti ou)k a)pe/qanen: some such idea as this frequently occurs in Plato; for example, in the Republic and Laws. Cf. Crito 47 d, e e)a\n diole/swmen (sc. to\ sw=ma) a)=ra biwto\n h(mi=n e)sti diefqarme/nou au)tou=; *ou)damw=s. Socrates makes there a similar estimate of the relationship of soul to body.
LXVIII.
no/mos: usage, custom. Cf. ta\ nomizo/mena.

mhxanopoio/n: Socrates has in mind the constructors of great machines which were used in the defence of beleaguered cities, and of which the second Punic war offers a celebrated example. The military engineer saves at the same time the lives of many men,—the orator only one life at a time.
mh\ (ou)x)
o(/ti: see on 450 e.

e)la/ttw du/natai sw/|zein: this use of the neut. acc. is extended from the cognate. Cf. Apol. 30 c e)me\ mei/zw bla/yete. On the pl., cf. the adverbial use of the neut. pl. by Thucydides. ‘A chance is represented as the sum of so many contingencies; a quantity as the sum of so many smaller units.’ Rid. § 43.
mh/ soi dokei=: the answer assumed in the following kai/toi would run as above: ma\ *di/) ou)k e)/moige. For the interrogative mh/, see G. 282, 2.—
kata\ ... ei)=nai: to be comparable to, i.e. worthy to be put upon the same plane with. Cf. Apol. 17 b o(mologoi/hn a)\n e)/gwge ou) kata\ tou/tous ei)=nai r(h/twr.
to\ pra=gma: “his business.”—

katax w/seien: would cover under a mass, i.e. of arrows, like obruere. Cf. Hdt. vii. 225 e)n tou/tw| sfe/as tw=| xw/rw| a)lecome/nous . . . kate/xwsan oi( ba/rbaroi ba/llontes. The use of this word brings up the image of war and the hurling machines of the mhxanopoioi/, whose weapons, however, in this case are to be lo/goi instead of li/qoi.

le/gwn: the omission of an object clause is accounted for by the addition of parakalw=n, which at the same time extends and defines le/gwn. The use of dei=n is rather strange; it would go better with le/gwn. Perhaps there is a mixture of two constructions. For the matter, cf. 486 c.
w(s kte(.: see on 509 e.
i(kano\s ga\r au)tw=| o( lo/gos: for his case is strong enough.

a)pokale/sais: call slightingly Cf. Soph. Ai. 726 to\n tou= mane/ntos ka)pibouleutou= stratou= cu/naimon a)pokalou=ntes. The displacement of the first ou)/te from its normal position is common enough.

e)c w(=n: stands either for e)k tou/twn e)c w(=n (“for the reasons for which you praise your art”) or e)k tou/twn a(\ (“from that which you say in praise of your art”), more likely the latter. See H. 996 a.

belti/wn kai\ e)k beltio/nwn: such combinations are common. Cf. Phaedr. 246 a qew=n me\n ou)=n i(/ppoi te kai\ h(ni/oxoi au)toi/ te a)gaqoi\ kai\ e)c a)gaqw=n, Lys. in Agor. 18 dou=lon kai\ e)k dou/lwn o)/nta, Soph. Phil. 384 pro\s tou= kaki/stou ka)k kakw=n *)odusse/ws, 874 eu)genh\s ga\r h( fu/sis ka)c eu)genw=n, Paul ad Phil. iii. 5 *(ebrai=os e)c *(ebrai/wn.—In this passage, moreover, we see in its worst colors the opposition between the theory championed by Callicles and his actual practices. The former is a kind of sophistical latitudinarianism; the latter, the narrow-mindedness of Greek tradition.
mh\ e)/stin: the regular accentuation of e)sti after mh/ and tou=to.
o)/nta: constr. with the understood subject of sw/|zein.
o(poi=o/s tis e)/tuxen: “without regard to moral qualities.”

mh\ ga\r tou=to me\n, to\ zh=n kte(.: the change from the subjv. to the indic. e)sti/ may be due to forgetfulness on the part of the speaker, who, after giving the keynote to the sentence with the mh\ ga/r at the beginning, shifts to the independent, straightforward indic. construction. If the e)sti/ is to be construed rigidly with mh/, understanding again o(/ra, then we must consider that Socrates rejected the subjv., which may refer either to the present or the future, for the indic., which leaves no ambiguity as to its time sphere. That Socrates is aware of the grammatically uncertain structure of his sentence is shown by the tou=q' o(/ra below. But see Goodwin's view, GMT. 269.

to/n ge w(s a)lhqw=s a)/ndra: has reference to the lengthy exposition of Callicles in ch. XXXVIII. ff., especially 485 c, d, where the activity of Socrates is characterized as unmanly. Wherein true manliness consists, Socrates shows in his defence, Apol. ch. XVI. f. and XXIX.
e)ate/on: cf. 484 c e)a/sas filosofi/an. For the construction, see on 507 c.

e)pitre/yanta . . . tw=| qew=|: this feeling of submission to God's decrees Socrates preserved even to his death. Cf. Apol. 41 d ou)k e)/stin a)ndri\ a)gaqw=| kako\n ou)de\n ou)/te zw=nti ou)/te teleuth/santi, ou)de\ a)melei=tai u(po\ qew=n ta\ tou/tou pra/gmata: ou)de\ ta\ e)ma\ nu=n a)po\ tou= au)toma/tou ge/gonen, a)lla/ moi dh=lo/n e)sti tou=to o(/ti h)/dh teqna/nai kai\ a)phlla/xqai pragma/twn be/ltion h)=n moi.
peri\ tou/twn: for emphasis, instead of the simple acc. tau=ta. But see Rid. § 106.

tai=s gunaici/n: because these hold more firmly to what is old and time-honored, both in dialect (cf. Crat. 418 c ai( gunai=kes ma/lista th
 a)rxai/an fwnh
 sw/|zousi, Cic. de Or. iii. 12. 45) and in belief. This same old belief is expressed by Hector Z 488, moi=ran (i.e. th
 ei(marme/nhn) d' ou)/ tina/ fhmi pefugme/non e)/mmenai a)ndrw=n. It is ridiculed as an old wives' tale by the Epicurean Velleius in Cic. de Nat. Deor. i. 20. 55 as follows: Hinc vobis exstitit primum illa fatalis necessitas quam ei(marme/nhn dicitis, ut, quidquid accidat, id ex aeterna veritate causarumque continuatione fluxisse dicatis. Quanti autem haec philosophia aestimanda est cui tamquam aniculis et iis quidem indoctis, fato fieri videantur omnia? By the words e)pitre/yanta kte(., Socrates declares in a delicate way that this belief of the women harmonizes with the principles of true manliness better than the view of the highly cultured Callicles.
ou)d' a)\n ei(=s : ou)dei/s is separated for the sake of emphasis. See G. 77, 1, 2; H. 290 a.
to\ e)pi\ tou/tw|: see on 452 c. e)pi/ denotes the immediate succession.
me/lloi: is optative by assimilation to the potential a)\n bioi/h.
kai\ nu=n de\ a)/ra: introduces the application to Callicles and his relation to the Athenian state. In sense the clause depends on skepte/on above, but loosely.

tou=q' o(/ra: returns to the beginning, since the sense has become
somewhat obscured by the intervening additions. The use of soi\ kai\ e)moi/ resumes the previous unemphatic se\, inasmuch as each one wishes to obtain the others' acceptance of his own view of life.

ta\s *qettali/das: the Thessalian women were very skilful in sorcery and poisoning. They stood in close relation to the night-goddess Hecate; hence people ascribed to them the power to draw the moon from the heavens. Strepsiades says in Ar. Nub. 749 gunai=ka farmaki/d' ei) pria/menos *qettalh
 | kaqe/loimi nu/ktwr th
 selh/nhn kte(. Cf. Hor. Epod. 5. 45 quae sidera excantata voce Thessala | lunamque caelo deripit. For this, however, the goddess exacted punishment, for Suidas says ai( th
 selh/nhn kaqairou=sai *qettali/des le/gontai tw=n o)fqa/lmwn kai\ tw=n pai/dwn (v. l. podw=n) steri/skesqai. ei)/rhtai e)pi\ tw=n e(autoi=s ta\ kaka\ e)pispwme/nwn h( paroimi/a. Cf. also Plin. N. H. XXX. I. 2 (6). Aristophanes' designation of them under the name farmaki/s, while it implies that their art consisted in the manipulation of drugs, does not limit us to that view, because Herodotus, vii. 114, uses the verb farmakeu/ein in speaking of the sacrifice of white horses by the Magi to the river Strymon.
su\n toi=s filta/tois: at the risk of our dearest interests. For the asyn deton, see on 450 b.
ta\ fi/ltata: denotes the soul and its a)reth/, as in Prot. 314 a o(/ra, w)= maka/rie, mh\ peri\ toi=s filta/tois kubeu/h|s kai\ kinduneu/h|s. In ai(/resis lies a play on kaqairei=n.
o(ntinou=n a)nqrw/pwn: recalls the promises made for rhetoric by Gorgias.
mimhth/n: imitation is not to be thought of, for immoral action with a correct moral feeling is impossible. Hence the similarity must be original (au)tofuw=s).

fili/an tw=| dh/mw|: substantives involving action, either physical or mental, sometimes take the construction of their corresponding adjs. or verbs. Cf. 522 d boh/qeia e(autw=|, Apol. 30 a th\n tw=| qew=| u(phresi/an. H. 765 a.
kai\ nai\ ma\ *di/a tw=| *purila/mpous: see on 481 d.
politiko\s ei)=nai: since these words would be understood if not present, the special insertion of them can only serve to emphasize the identity of wish and result.

tw=| au(tw=n ga\r h)/qei legome/nwn: as an illustration of the sentiment, cf. Dem. Ol. iii. 19 a)ll' oi)=mai me/ga toi=s toiou/tois u(pa/rxei (“comes to the aid of”) lo/gois h( par' e(ka/stou bou/lhsis.

w)= fi/lh kefalh/: a humorously pathetic mode of address, borrowed from the Homeric usage (*q 281 et al.). Cf. also Soph. O. R. 950 w)= fi/ltaton gunaiko\s *)ioka/sths ka/ra etc. Our use of the word ‘heart’ in tender address is analogous. Cf. Shaks. Love's Labor Lost, v. 3: ‘Good heart, what grace hast thou thus to reprove?’ etc.

to\ tw=n pollw=n pa/qos: namely that they listen gladly only to that which harmonizes with their opinions, and are very loath to offer on the altar of more perfect knowledge the views they have come to cherish; hence they remain unde cided, as Meno says, Meno 95 c o(/per oi( polloi\ pe/ponqa: tote\ me/n moi dokou=si, tote\ de\ ou)/. The candor of Callicles here as compared with his earlier obstinacy is quite remarkable. For the asyndeton, see on 450 b.
i)/sws: this addition shows that the fulfilment of the condition is still very doubtful. Cf. Socrates' remarks on the necessity of time to convince, in Apol. 19 a, 37 a, b, quoted on 455 a.

d' ou)=n: but then, emphasizes, in contrast to the uncertain hope just expressed, what must happen in any case. Cf. Apol. 17 a. The Latin equivalent is certe. Socrates has in mind at the moment ch. LV. f., where, however, reference was made to the conversation with Gorgias and Polus in ch. XIX. f.
e(/kaston: subject to qerapeu/ein.

pro\s h(donh\n o(milei=n: epexegetic to mi/an (sc. paraskeuh/n). mh\ kataxarizo/menon limits o(milei=n which belongs also to pro\s to\ be/ltiston, and
requires the supplying of an indefinite subject. See on 512 d o)/nta.
kataxarizo/menon: used in Apol. 35 c with the acc. (ta\ di/kaia). diama/xesqai frequently takes peri/ tinos. See also on 502 b, 503 a.
ei) boulei: added by Callicles here, as ei)/ soi h(/dion in 514 a, i(/na soi xari/swmai 516 b, to avoid responsibility. It is almost parenthetical.

h( . . . e(te/ra: there is no need of an explanatory appositional clause corresponding to h( pro\s h(donh/n, since the inference from d is sufficient. The lacking verb (tugxa/nei ou)=sa) on account of the parallelism must be taken from the preceding words of Socrates. o(/pws . . . tou=to is added to correspond to a)gennh\s . . . kolakei/a, thus, “is directed to that end, viz.” etc. The connexion is a loose one.

qerapeu/ein: the addition of the inf. here is an afterthought, after the object which in sense belongs to it has been already proleptically connected with the preceding verb. Cf. Crito 52 c e)piqumi/a se . . . a)/llwn no/mwn e)/laben ei)de/nai. See Kr. 61, 6, 8; Rid. § 180.

w(s . . . poiou=ntas: connected (as a correlative) epexegetically with ou(/tws. Cf. Phaedo 59 a sxedo/n ti ou(/tw diekei/meqa, o(te\ me\n gelw=ntes, e)ni/ote de\ dakru/ontes. The position of the ou(/tws, which in sense is to be construed with qerapeu/ein, is due to the form of the sentence. The partics. agree in case with the unexpressed subj. of qerapeu/ein, viz. h(ma=s.
e)a\n mh\ kte(.: explains a)/neu dh\ tou/tou.—
dia/noia: i.e. the inner activity of the soul itself, its reasoning, thinking; hence it is often used for the mode of thought, the disposition, and even for the soul itself.

ei) ou)=n parekalou=men kte(.: by a series of analogies Socrates tries to show that the profession of statecraft implies various preliminary qualifications, and that the incipient statesman ought to be subjected to an examination as to his education and previous habits, instead of following the Athenian practice. Cf. Prot. 319 d e)peida
 de/ ti peri\ tw=n th=s po/lews dioikh/sews de/h| bouleu/sasqai, sumbouleu/ei au)toi=s a)nista/menos peri\ tou/twn o(moi/ws me
 te/ktwn, o(moi/ws de\ xalkeu\s skutoto/mos, e)/mporos nau/klhros, plou/sios pe/nhs, gennai=os a)gennh/s, kai\ tou/tois ou)dei\s e)piplh/ttei o(/ti ou)damo/qen maqw
 ou)de\ o)/ntos didaska/lou ou)deno\s au)tw=|, e)/peita sumbouleu/ein e)pixeirei=, Xen. Mem. iv. 2. 1-7.
dhmosi/a| pra/contes: almost equivalent to dhmosieu/ontes. —
tw=n pragma/twn: must be considered as part. gen. after dhmosi/a| pra/contes, and is not to be construed with the following clause, with Cron.

h)\ teixw=n h)\ newri/wn h)\ i(erw=n: these are themselves the greatest public works, but the addition of me/gista serves to emphasize the importance of the matter and the responsibility of the person.
po/teron: the second member of the double question is found in the h)\ ou)/ which follows the repeated e)/dei a)/n below.
e)/dei a)/n: instead of e)/dei, shows that the whole condition is purely fictitious and unreal. The simple e)/dei would have drawn attention only to the inf. GMT. 423.
deu/teron au)= to/de: to be com
pleted from the preceding po/teron kte(.
i)di/a| dia\ h(mw=n: would lead us to expect as a contrast koinh=| meta\ tw=n didaska/lwn. But koinh=| is omitted as self-evident, while i)di/a| gives a certain definiteness to dia\ h(mw=n.
diakeime/nwn (viz. h(mw=n): is used absolutely; nou=n e)xo/ntwn is to be connected with h)=n as above, 500 a panto\s a)ndro/s.
ou(/tw de/: correlative with ou(/tw me/n. See on 512 a.
a)no/hton h)=n a)/n: cf. below, e katage/laston a)\n h)=n and a)no/hton a)\n ei)=nai.
LXX.

ou)kou=n ou(/tw pa/nta: these words would seem to indicate the conclusion of the induction and the transition to its application to the question under discussion. Meanwhile, however, Socrates cites another example which is still closer to his idea. Hence ta/ te a)/lla kai/, which at the same time sums up and emphasizes.
ka)/n: is to be resolved into kai\ a)/n, the kai/ being correlative with te/, and not going with ei) in the sense “even.” For the repetition of the a)/n, two lines below, see 465 c, d, and on 475 e.

dhmosieu/ein: the general word to denote the public practice of any profession or business which is for the benefit of the community. See on 452 a dhmiourgo/s. In the case of physicians, are included not merely those who are in the service of the government, but also private practitioners. See on 455 b.
w(s . . . o)/ntes: expresses in a different form what is found above, a, in the phrase e)pi\ ta\ oi)kodomika/, viz. the department of activity to which attention is drawn.
fe/re kte(.: change to direct quotation occurs frequently as here, without the employment of a definite verb of saying.

de/: often employed in lively questions which are closely connected with the words of another. So here. Socrates offers himself to the state as a physician, but in what state of health is his own body? Cf. Xen. Mem. ii. I. 26 (in the myth of Prodicus, after *kaki/a had praised her gifts) kai\ o( *(hraklh=s a)kou/sas tau=ta, *)=w gu/nai, e)/fh, o)/noma de/ soi ti/ e)sti;

h)\ dou=los h)\ e)leu/qeros: cf. 502 d and 515 a. The distinction between slaves and freemen, which was always present to the mind of a Greek, is emphasized here because it was common for slaves to be treated by less skilled physicians, who might themselves be slaves, as we learn from Legg. iv. 720 c a)=r' ou)=n kai\ cunnoei=s o(/ti dou/lwn kai\ e)leuqe/rwn o)/ntwn tw=n kamno/ntwn e)n tai=s po/lesi tou\s me\n dou/lous sxedo/n ti oi( dou=loi ta\ polla\ i)atreu/ousi. Cf. Herm. Gr. Alt. iv.^{3} § 38.

a)nqrw/pous: from the particular to the general, which also includes the particular. We should say “people” in the same way. It is remarkable, however, how quickly Socrates returns to the first person in the next clause. One must have in mind an individual before he can give particulars.

o(/pws e)tu/xomen poih=sai: is the contrast to katorqw=sai. When one is beginning in a profession much is necessarily, from inexperience, done at a risk, and may or may not suc ceed. For the phrase o(/pws e)tu/xomen, cf. 521 c, Crito 45 d to\ so
 me/ros, o(/ti a)
 tu/xwsi, tou=to pra/cousi, “the success of your sons is left as far as you are concerned to the caprice of chance.” Prot. 353 b o(/ti a)
 tu/xwsi, tou=to le/gousi, qui quidquid in buccam venit dicunt. The usual inference is unfavorable. The partic. is to be supplied from the following verb.

ei) tw=| pi/qw| th\n keramei/an: the proverb denotes, “to begin with the large instead of with the small.” Cf.
