Lach. 187 a ei) ga\r nu=n, prw=ton a)/rcesqe paideu/ein, skopei=n xrh\ mh\ ou)k e)n tw=| *kari\ u(mi=n o( ki/ndunos kinduneu/htai, a)ll' e)n toi=s u(e/si te kai\ e)n toi=s tw=n fi/lwn paisi/, kai\ a)texnw=s to\ lego/menon kata\ th\n paroimi/an u(mi=n sumbai/nh| e)n pi/qw| h( keramei/a gignome/nh. A proverb from the potter's art was natural among the Athenians, where the art flourished (*kerameiko/s).
w)= be/ltiste a)ndrw=n: a pathetic address. See on 513 c.

a)/rti a)/rxei: on the age of Callicles at the time of this dialogue, see Introd. § 15.—On the matter, cf. Apol. 36 c e)pixeirw=n e(/kaston u(mw=n pei/qein mh\ pro/teron mh/te tw=n e(autou= mhdeno\s e)pimelei=sqai, pri\n e(autou= e)pimelhqei/h, o(/pws w(s be/ltistos kai\ fronimw/tatos e)/soito, mh/te tw=n th=s po/lews, pri\n au)th=s th=s po/lews.
fe/re kte(.: see on 514 d.
a)/diko/s te kte(.: various kinds of ponhri/a, as contrasted with the corresponding virtues. Cf. 491 e ff.
ei)/per kte(.: Socrates' opinion can be readily perceived. Between these repeated questions we must assume short pauses. On the possessive pronoun followed by the gen., see H. 691; G. 137, N. 1.
filo/nikos ei)=: the accusation is a confession of weakness, having much the same force as Crito's answer (Crito 54 d) a)ll' , w)= *sw/krates, ou)k e)/xw le/gein. See on 457 d.

e)n h(mi=n: cf. e)n toi=s poli/tais, e)n tw=| dh/mw|. In spite of the addition of dei=n, no subject for politeu/esqai is expressed. But we should not feel the ellipsis in English, and often make such without noticing it.
h(mi=n: seems to be a kind of ethical dat. See G. 184, 3, N. 6; H. 770. Cope translates the clause, ‘whether we shall find you concerning yourself about anything else,’ etc.
u(pe\r sou=: cf. Apol. 22 e w(/ste me e)mauto\n a)nerwta=n u(pe\r tou= xrhsmou=, so that I asked myself in the name of the oracle.

poli=tai: the idea of this word (as also of politeu/esqai) approaches so near that of “statesmen” that it is frequently used in that sense; i.e. in the speech of Diodotus against Cleon (Thuc. iii. 42. 5) xrh\ to\n a)gaqo\n poli/thn mh\ e)kfobou=nta tou\s a)nterou=ntas a)ll' a)po\ tou= i)/sou fai/nesqai a)/meinon le/gonta. Cf. below, e. Above we find politiko\s a)nh/r and also a)nh/r simply, used in the same sense; cf. 517 a.
e)poi/ei: sc. in the course of his activity as a statesman.
a)nti\ xeiro/nwn: the brachylogy is here harder than in the case where the relation is reversed; e.g. Polit. 308 a a)nt' e)leuqe/rwn geno/menoi dou=loi. We might have expected e)k.

h)/rxeto le/gein: here denotes not so much Pericles' first appearance before the people as the first period of his political life. This began even before the death of Ephi altes, who, owing to the machinations of his enemies, was murdered shortly after the banishment of Cimon (460 B.C.). The height of Pericles' power was reached after the death of Cimon and the banishment of Thucydides, son of Melesias (443 B.C.).— On the construction of a)/rxesqai, see on 488 a.

ta\ teleutai=a e)/legen: Socrates is referring again, not so much to Pericles' last oratorical efforts, but to the last period of his political activity, which fell within the first years of the Peloponnesian war. On the result of his last speech (430 B.C.) Thucydides (ii. 65) remarks: *toiau=ta o( *periklh=s le/gwn e)peira=to tou=s *)aqhnai/ous th=s te e)p' au)to
 o)rgh=s paralu/ein kai\ a)po\ tw=n paro/ntwn deinw=n a)pa/gein th
 gnw/mhn. oi( de\ dhmosi/a| me
 toi=s lo/gois a)nepei/qonto . . . ou) me/ntoi pro/tero/n ge oi( cu/mpantes e)pau/santo e)n o)rgh=| e)/xontes au)to
 pri
 e)zhmi/wsan xrh/masin. —On the neut. pl., see on 512 b and Kr. 46, 3, 2.
a)na/gkh|: is adverbial dat. corresponding to the adverb i)/sws.
ti/ ou)=n dh/: see on 453 b and 497 d. The reply of Socrates shows that he intends Callicles himself to draw the necessary inference from what he proceeds to bring forward.

a)rgou\s kte(.: this accusation is based upon a suspicion that Pericles, in order to bring about certain desirable measures in the government, employed bribery disguised under the names of misqo\s stratiwtiko/s, dikastiko/s, e)kklhsiastiko/s, and qewriko/s, of which, however, only the first two can be ascribed to Pericles. On this dole the Athenian citizens could live in a poor way at the expense of the state, and they lost perhaps some of that energy which was characteristic of them in earlier times.
deilou/s: the Athenians became timid, as a natural consequence of their inactivity, in that they (much later however) withdrew from personal war service, and depended on mercenaries exclusively.

la/lous: to activity in the real service of the state, principally of course in the assembly, was soon joined a desire to seek entertainment in public. For here their curiosity, a natural failing, was nourished by continual gossip and talk. This was the case in the time of Demosthenes (Phil. i. 10), of Paul (Acts xvii. 18), and is the case at the present day. See on 461 e.

filargu/rous: the desire to obtain money from the public treasury became continually stronger and more universal, and wrought great damage to the government. At the time of Demosthenes the continuance of the qewriko/n was especially injurious, because the means for military purposes were thereby greatly curtailed. Plato's criticism of Pericles was always unfavorable, which, however, is not to be wondered at, since his youth fell during the years of Athenian depression, which the oligarchy ascribed to the mistakes of the great democratical leader.—
misqofori/an: on the growth and effects of this policy at Athens and elsewhere, see Grote, Hist. xi. 281 (c. lxxxvii.).

tw=n ta\ w)=ta kateago/twn: the Laconian imitators (lakwni/zontes, lakwnomanou=ntes) in Athens were thus
named from having their ears often broken in the pugmh/ by the straps with which the hands were covered (see Herm. Gr. Alter. iv.^{3} § 37, p. 347). They formed a party, hostile to the democracy, which saw in Lacedaemon the model of a noble state, and looked to her for help. They practised Lacedaemonian severity in all external matters; hence they wore mustaches, short mantles, etc., and practised gymnastics very diligently. To harden the body, they even engaged in boxing, which was forbidden in Sparta. They became naturally, therefore, butts for ridicule. Cf. Prot. 342 b.—By this remark Callicles here accuses Socrates of partisanship.

e)peidh\ de\ kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/: with bitter irony. If they were really good, the righteousness of the judgment of Pericles would have been recognized; but if this judgment was unrighteous, then Pericles did not make them good.
u(p' au)tou= : gi/gnomai, as passive of poiw=, requires u(po/ for the agent.

kloph\n au)tou= kte(.: in the second year of the Peloponnesian war, when Pericles returned from an expedition against the Spartan coast, the slumbering discontent of the people, caused by the devastation of Attica by the Spartans and the ravages of the plague in Athens, broke out against him in the form of an accusation as a result of which he was fined a sum of money, the amount of which (15, 50, 80 talents) is not certain. Thuc. ii. 59; 65. See on 515 d. That the ostensible charge was embezzlement of the public funds is supported by this passage alone, but that various rumors were current of his dishonesty can be gathered from the story of Alcibiades' advice to him in Plut. Alcib. vii. *periklei= de\ boulo/menos e)ntuxei=n e)pi\ qu/ras h)=lqen au)tou=. puqo/menos de\ mh\ sxola/zein, a)lla\ skopei=n kaq' e(auto/n, o(/pws a)podw/sei lo/gon *)aqhnai/ois, a)piw\n o( *)alkibia/dhs: “ei)=ta” e)/fh “be/ltion ou)k h)=n skopei=n au)to/n, o(/pws ou)k a)podw/sei lo/gon *)aqhnai/ois;”

ei) paralabw/n: not designed as an epexegesis to toiou=tos w)/n, which merely gives the general
idea which runs through all the preceding thought, but added to give those details to the simile which seem to be requisite.
paralabw/n: receiving for training. See on 483 e. —The position of the words lakti/zontas, kuri/ttontas, and da/knontas is probably merely a chance one.

a)pe/deice: the word means “to show or prove as the result of a process,” often in mathematical reasoning; here as the result of training. Cf. below c a)pe/fhnen. Hence also the expression a)podeiknu/nai tina\ strathgo/n. See on 484 b.
i(/na soi xari/swmai: see on 513 e. The reply of Socrates is full of irony.
a)pokrina/menos: for the tense, see on 491 c.
e)/dei: without a)/n. See on 514 a.
a)nti\ a)dikwte/rwn: see on 515 d.
oi(/ ge di/kaioi h(/meroi w(s e)/fh *(/omhros: there is no such direct as

sertion in any passage of Homer, but the same sense is seen in z 120, i 175 h)= r() oi(/ g' u(bristai/ te kai\ a)/grioi ou)de\ di/kaioi. Here, moreover, the leading thought is the utter exclusion of any idea of dikaiosu/nh from the a)/grioi.

o(\n h(/kist' a)/n e)bou/lonto: cf. Apol. 25 d e)/stin ou)=n o(/stis bou/letai
u(po\ tw=n cuno/ntwn bla/ptesqai ma=llon h)\ w)felei=sqai. For o(/n, see on 453 e. The ellipsis is to be supplied from what precedes.
ou) . . . fh/|s: see on 450 d.

e)cwstra/kisan au)to/n: Cimon was a supporter of the Lacedaemonian league, and also caused the Athenians to send aid to the Spartans in the third Messenian war. But when the Athenians were dismissed in so humiliating a manner at Ithome, his opponent, Pericles, turning to account the indignation of the people, succeeded in effecting his banishment in B.C. 461. The term of banishment by ostracism was limited by law to ten years. But Cimon was recalled about B.C. 457, also at the instance of Pericles. Since ostracism (Herm. Gr. Alter. i. § 130) was properly not a punishment, Socrates, in the words i(/na au)tou= de/ka e)/th mh\ a)kou/seian, is merely making a point against the influence of Cimon in the state.
Themistocles was banished in B.C. 471, and went to Argos. Here he was accused by the Spartans of participation in the treason of Pausanias, or mhdismo/s, and to escape investigations fled to the Persian king, a step which was followed by the confiscation of his magnificent property at Athens.
prosezhmi/wsan: and in addi-
tion they punished, etc. Cf. Apol. 20 a sfi/sin cunei=nai xrh/mata dido/ntas kai\ xa/rin proseide/nai.—

to\n e)n *maraqw=ni: this short adverbial expression seems to have been used simply as a distinguishing epithet, and it is not likely that the Greeks supplied or felt any ellipsis such as is suggested by Cron, viz. to\n e)n *maraqw=ni (*maraqw=ni alone) parataca/menon (maxesa/menon) or nikh/santa. The epithet is the more emphatic as the victors at Marathon (*maraqwnoma/xai Ar. Nub. 986) were unusually revered by posterity. In consequence of the unfortunate expe
dition against Paros, Miltiades was, on the prosecution of Xanthippus, declared guilty of a)pa/thsis tou= dh/mou, and fined fifty talents. According to Hdt. vi. 136, his adversary demanded the penalty of death, which was averted by the intercession of friends.
ei) mh\ dia/: “if it had not been for.” The prytanis probably exerted his influence before the division, though this whole story seems to be much overdrawn.
ei) h)=san . . . e)/pasxon: opposition to generic present. Cf. 471
a. Goodwin (GMT. 410) considers this as a case of real opposition to the past.

ou)/koun kte(.: the neg. contained in ou)/koun (Kr. 69, 51, 2) applies not to the second member alone, but to the two members together; the coexistence of the two clauses is denied. This form sharply emphasizes the self-contradiction which is fundamental in Callicles' view.—The results of the whole argument are now summed up as briefly as possible.
su\ de\ kte(.: with w(molo/geis

must be supplied the participial clause of the preceding sentence. From this also we must take a verb of saying to govern a tina/s also to be supplied from ou)de/na of the clause tw=n . . . e)/mprosqen.
e)c i)/sou: has almost the force of an adj. See Kr. 43, 4, 5; H. 798 f.

ou) ga\r e)ce/peson: we find additions, such as e)k th=s patri/dos, a)rxh=s, turanni/dos, and the like; also do/chs, ou)di/as (e)k tw=n e)o/ntwn, Hdt. iii. 14). The verb e)kpi/ptein serves thus as a passive to e)kba/llein, though the image is that of a chariot driver who is
thrown out. Cf. the English phrase ‘fall through,’ as applied to a design or project.
ou)/te th| kolakikh|: sc. with which they might have saved themselves, according to Callicles' view (511 c, 486 b), but which Pericles despised.
<*>lla\ me/ntoi . . . mh/ pote: “But yet, the men of the present day are at least far from being able to,” etc.
o(\s (o(/stis)
bou/lei: used like the Lat. quivis, by a looseness of construction. Cf. Phileb. 43 d triw=n ou)=n u)/ntwn h(mi=n w(=ntinwn bou/lei, Crat. 432 a o(/stis bou/lei a)/llos a)riqmo/s. Rid. § 189.

w(/s ge diako/nous ei)=nai: as far, that is, as their being servants of the city is concerned. See Madv. Syn. § 151, GMT. 781, for examples. The distinction here drawn rests also, as is quickly shown, on what has been demonstrated in ch. XIX. ff. But it is more extensive.

metabiba/zein: “to give another direction to.” See on 493 a. This verb and e)pitre/pein are resumed by ou)de\n tou/twn, and depend on die/feron. A similar passage (without the intervening acc.) is Prot. 328 a a)lla\ ka)\n ei) o)li/gon e)/sti tis o(/stis diafe/rei h(mw=n probiba/sai ei)s a)reth/n, a)gaphto/n.
e)pitre/pein: we must supply a dat. from the preceding acc. See on 460 d. The verb has a slightly different sense in 504 c.
tou/twn: note the variety in the use of the pronouns; tou/twn is the same as tw=n nu=n above, and hence e)kei=noi is required to take the place of tou/tous above.
nau=s kte(.: cf. 455 d.
ei)=nai: equiv to o)ti h)=san.

ei)s to au)to\ perifero/menoi: similar in form, but not in meaning, to
the English phrase “argument in a circle,” i.e. a coming back again to the point of departure. Cf. Rep. v. 456 b h(/komen ei)s ta\ pro/tera perifero/menoi.
a)llh/lwn: is to be connected, as a kind of subjective or possessive gen., with the following indirect question. See H. 733; Kr. 47, 10, 8. “Each other's language.”
ditth\ kte(.: notice the position of the ti\s, which belongs to ditth/, “a kind of doubled.” See on 491 c.

h( me\n e(te/ra: the second member of the correlation is divided into two parts of which the first is indicated by o(/ti e)/stin tis kte(. (below, e), and the other by th\n de\ . . . despoi/nas ei)=nai tou/twn (518 a).
h(=| . . . ei)=nai: the shift from the regular indir. disc. indic. to an inf. is not uncommon. Cf. Rep. x. 616 b e)/fh a)fiknei=sqai tetartai/ous o(/qen kaqora=n a)/nwqen kte(. Rid. § 281; GMT. 755.
a)/ll' w(=n e)/rxetai kte(.: anything else, that the body comes to want.

poristiko\n ei)=nai kte(.: in what follows, three varieties are distin guished. The ka/phlos is the small dealer, hawker or shopkeeper, who deals properly with products of the land (among which are included wines in 518 b); the e)/mporos is the regular merchant and wholesale dealer. Cf. Prot. 313 c. The dhmiourgo/s is the one who prepares from the raw material the various articles demanded by the needs of the body.
skutodeyo/n: is unusual for bur- sode/yhs (tanner).

o)/nta toiou=ton: includes under one expression all the divisions and subdivisions of the por<*>stiko\n ei)=nai, but owing to the introduction of qaumasto/n e)stin the construction is changed and the partic. takes the place of the inf. What Socrates wishes to explain is that one who attends to the needs of the body, even though he may understand nothing of either gymnastics or medicine, may very easily himself become possessed of the idea that he is the genuine conserver of the body, as well as inspire the same belief in others.
panti\ tw=| mh\ ei)do/ti: added as a restrictive explanation to the preceding toi=s a)/llois, which is far too general a statement for Socrates.
para\ tau/tas a(pa/sas: see on ta\s a)/llas kte(. below, 518 a.
douloprepei=s: plays on 485 b and similar expressions in the earlier conversation with Callicles, i.e. 485 d. The attributes of rhetoric and philosophy are just reversed.
ta\s a)/llas te/xnas: “arts ordinarily designated as such.”

*qeari/wn: and the followingnamed persons are sometimes mentioned by later authors, *mi/qaikos for example, among those whom Athenaeus xii. 12 cites as authors of works on cookery (ta\ o)yartutika/). The title of his work can be surmised from this passage. That the art of cookery, especially in rich and proud Syracuse, was early developed, Plato testifies in Rep. iii. 404 d *surakosi/an tra/pezan kai\ *sikelikh\n poikili/an <*>)/you. Cf. Hor. Od. iii. I. 18 Siculae dapes. The a)rtoko/pos is at the same time a cake-baker. The a)/rtos made from wheat meal was a festival dainty, as is to be judged from Athenaeus iv. 14 *so/lwn de\ toi=s e)n prutanei/w| sitoume/nois ma=zan pare/xein keleu/ei, a)/rton de\ tai=s e(ortai=s prosparatiqe/nai. Sarambus probably had a wine-shop.
LXXIV.
i)/sws a)\n ou)=n h)gana/kteis: as Callicles really did when Socrates proved to him that he understood nothing at all of statecraft.
o(/ti: see on 521 b.
paraskeuasta\s a)nqrw/pous: the addition of a)nqrw/pous (“fellows”) is contemptuous.

kalo\n ka)gaqo\n: is used by Plato regularly of persons. Schanz, ii. 2 proll. 1, has collected only sixteen cases where it is not so used. Three such examples are found in the Gorgias, viz. 514 a, 526 a, in addition to the present passage.
peri\ au)tw=n: refers according to sense to gumnastikh=s, but is made general in view of b above.
a)\n ou(/tw tu/xwsin: see on 514 e. Here, “if they so chance,” i.e. perhaps.

prosapolou=sin . . . sa/rkas: Demosthenes expresses the same idea by a somewhat different simile in Ol. i. 15 w(/sper oi( daneizo/menoi r(a|di/ws e)pi\ toi=s mega/lois to/kois mikro
 eu)porh/santes xro/non u(/steron kai\ tw=n a)rxai/wn a)pe/sthsan. Also with the following a)ll' oi(\ a)
 au)toi=s tu/xwsin paro/ntes cf. Dem. Ol. i. 16 e)gw\ de\ ou)k a)gnow= me
, w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi, tou=q' o(/ti polla/kis u(mei=s ou) tou\s ai)ti/ous, a)lla\ tou\s u(sta/tous peri\ tw=n pragma/twn ei)po/ntas e)n o)rgh=| poiei=sqe a)/n ti mh\ kata\ gnw/mhn e)kbh=|, Phil. ii. 34 o(rw= ga w(s ta\ polla\ e)ni/ous ou)k ei)s tou\s ai)ti/ous, a)ll' ei)s tou\s u(po\ xei=ra ma/lista th
 o)rgh
 a)fie/ntas.
oi( d' au)=: the construction is loose, but the context prevents ambiguity.
h(/kh| fe/rousa: gives a picture,—“it is actually at hand, bringing disease with it,”—for the more prosaic “has brought about disease.” See on 491 c.
tou/tous: is defined by the following th\n po/lin. With kai/ fasi the subject changes, so that au)tou/s refers to the same as oi(/, while tou/tous furnishes the subject for kai/ fasi.

oi)dei= kai\ u(/poulo/s e)sti: the first term denotes an external swelling or bloated condition, which may, however, for the time have all the appearance of health; the latter, the internal and hence invisible seat of disease.
fo/rwn: duties and imposts which the Athenians imposed upon other states, but expended only for their own interests.
kai\ toiou/twn fluariw=n: with a side hit at 490 c and a more definite reference to 455 e. Cf. Dem. Ol. iii. 29, quoted on 490 c.
tou\s to/te paro/ntas kte(.: again the same thought as in d above.
sou= . . . e)pilh/yontai: contains an allusion to 486 a. For the partitive gen., see H. 738 a, and on 469 c.

kai\ tou= e)mou= e(tai/rou *)alkibia/dou: on the value of this prophecy of Socrates for determining the date of this discussion, see Introd. § 19. For the reader, the life of Alcibiades will serve as a most convincing proof of the soundness of Socrates' statements.
o(rw), a)kou/w: Socrates desires to emphasize that in the past as well as the present the same thing has been repeating itself.

a)ganaktou/ntwn: depends upon ai)sqa/nomai with the omission of au)tw=n. The pl. is due to the plural idea, and to the a)ndrw=n. The statement holds good for all, though the action affects the individual only.

a)/ra: postpositive, as in Prot. 355 b w(s de\ tau=ta geloi=a/ e)sti kata/dhlon e)/stai e)a\n mh\ polloi=s o)no/masi xrw/meqa a)/ra. Here it serves to characterize the assumption as a result that follows of itself.
ou)d' a)\n ei(=s: see on 512 e.
o(/soi kte(.: loose connexion. The same case, “as well in regard to those who, etc. . . . as, etc.”

prospoiou=ntai: Socrates is thinking of the task which each class assumes, viz. to make the subject of their treatment better, to endow him with virtue. The pretended statesman promises this result to the whole body of citizens; the sophist, to the individual. Cf. Isocr. xiii. 5 f.
sfa)s au)tou/s: themselves indeed, with more emphasis than the simple sfa=s, which is more usual as the indir. reflexive. Cf. 520 b.

kai/: but little different from kai/ toi (and yet) in rejoinders, espepecially to statements made by the speaker. Cf. Apol. 29 b kai\ tou=to pw=s ou)k a)maqi/a e)sti/n; Dem. vi. 16 ka|i\ ti/s a)\n tau=ta pisteu/seien;

a)nqrw/pous a)gaqou\s kte(.: sc. as one must assume, according to the statement of the sophists. The addition of e)caireqe/ntas a)diki/an . . . a)dikei=n tou/tw| (just here lies the a)diki/a) o(\ ou)k e)/xousin serves to bring out very strongly the want of consistency in the theory.
sxo/ntas: after they had gotten. See on 503 e. Cf. Apol. 19 a, Soph. E. 1256 mo/lis ga\r e)/sxon nu=n e)leu/qeron sto/ma.

w(s a)lhqw=s dhmhgorei=n: here denotes the delivery of a long, connected discourse as opposed to dialectic investigation. It is also a reply to Callicles' accusation in 482 c w(s a)lhqw=s dhmhgo/ros w)/n.
LXXV.

e)/oika/ ge (sc. oi(=o/s t' ei)=nai kte(.): is a partial assent to the assertion implied in Callicles' question, “You would doubtless be quite capable,” etc.—The following clause with gou=n seems to be urged in proof, but it is really more of a complaint.

suxnou\s . . . tw=n lo/gwn: cf. 465 e suxno\n lo/gon a)pote/taka. The part. gen. emphasizes the distinctness of the arguments.—For the agreement of the adjective in gender and number with. the subst., cf. Xen. Cyr. iii. 2. 2 pollh\n th=s xw/ras, iv. 5. 4 tw=n a)/rtwn tou\s h(mi/seis.
pro\s fili/ou: see on 500 b.
paideu/ein . . . ei)s a)reth/n: cf. Xen. Cyn. 13. 3 e)p' a)reth/n.

a)lla\ ti/ a)\n le/gois: what would one have to say? “One need not waste words over such people.” Callicles, although at bottom himself a sophist, affects to despise the class in accordance with Gorgias' view concerning them. See Introd. § 8, especially note 22.
o(/tan tu/xwsin: has here much the force of “occasionally.” See on 518 c.
tau)to/n: emphatic asyndeton, which as an answer to the question immediately preceding has the effect of a negation.
h)\ e)ggu\s kte(.: on the use of the adverb, see Kr. 62, 2, 4. ti\ goes with it as ti\s with the adj., “pretty nearly.” See on 491 c.
th=| de\ a)lhqei/a| kte(.: cf. 464 b ff.
kai\ w)/|mhn: the position of kai/ here, which would properly be connected with mo/nois, is due to the desire to emphasize this latter word by putting it at the head of the sentence.

tou/tw| tw=| pra/gmati: that which receives their training, whether it be a whole commonwealth or an individual. The abstract neut. generalizes, as in Prot. 312 c, where of the sophists themselves it is said: kai/toi ei) tou=t) (i.e. what a sophist is) a)gnoei=s ou)de\ o(/tw| paradi/dws th\n yuxh\n oi)=sqa, ou)/t' ei) a)gaqw=| ou)t) ei) kakw=| pra/gmati.

h)\ tw=| au)tw=| lo/gw| kte(.: without, at the same time. Cf. Phaedr. 245 d tou=to de\ ou)/t' a)po/llusqai ou)/te gi/gnesqai dunato/n, h)\ pa/nta te ou)rano\n pa=sa/n te ge/nesin sumpesou=san sth=nai. Cron supplies from ou)k e)gxwrei=n the words a)na/gkhn ei)=nai, but it is very doubtful whether the Greeks felt the ellipsis. Cf. 471 d.

proe/sqai th\n eu)ergesi/an: every piece of instruction given the scholar by the teacher is looked upon as a benefit, and the pay is simply a compensation for benefit received. To proe/sqai, which of itself denotes a freewill gift, is added a)/neu misqou= in order to make more plain the contrast with the practice of the sophists, which ran so counter to the customary ideas of the Greeks (cf. Apol. 19 e f., 31 b, 33 a). The practice of Protagoras, as it is told us in Prot. 328 b, c, is noteworthy in this connexion.
o(/ti ma/lista: to be connected with the partic. clause a(/ma metadidou/s, simul atque tradit.
a(/ma: on the adv. with the partic., see H. 976; GMT. 858.

ou)de
 deino
 kte(.: see on 517 a, and cf. Apol. 28 b ou)de
 deino
 mh\ e)n e)moi\ sth=|. It has much the force of the English, ‘there is no danger that,’ etc. See Gildersleeve, Am. Jour. Phil. iii. 204.
ta\s me\n a)/llas sumboula/s: almost equiv. to ta\s peri\ a)/llwn sumboula/s.
o(/ntin' a)/n tis tro/pon kte(.: epex

egetic to tau/ths th=s pra/cews, “this matter.” The a)reth\ politikh/ which the sophists professed to teach included both sides,—management of one's own household and of the state. Cf. Prot. 318 e to\ de\ ma/qhma/ e)stin eu)bouli/a peri/ te tw=n oi)kei/wn, o(/pws a)
 a)/rista th
 au(tou= oi)ki/an dioikoi=, kai\ peri\ tw=n th=s po/lews, o(/pws ta\ th=s po/lews dunatw/tatos a)
 ei)/h kai\ pra/ttein kai\ le/gein.
mh\ fa/nai . . . e)a\n mh/: generic conditional of the present. The first mh/ is due to the infinitive.
a)nt' eu)= poiei=n: the old way of writing was a)nteupoiei=n; but a verb can retain its original form only when compounded with a preposition. See H. 581. Gratitude is only a kind of justice.

w(/ste kalo
 dokei= to\ shmei=on ei)=nai: sc. as testimony to the fact that the teacher has really made him better. The common form of the conditional, where the second member is the converse of the first, is e)a
 me
 . . . ei) de\ mh/. See on 502 b. The use of ei) with fut. indic. also in the first member emphasizes the rarity of the case. The subject of eu)= poih/sas is indefinite, ‘any one,’ as of mh\ fa/nai above.

th
 qerapei/an th=s po/lews: denotes political activity in the sense shown in ch. LVI. above, and in accordance with the principles deduced in ch. XIX. ff. The correct answer to the question propounded would be: “As matters are, I invite you to neither mode; for the one is immoral, the other (as Socrates also makes plain in Apol. 31 d f.), for the present impossible.” Hence, also, Socrates intimates that the only way of engag ing in true politics is at present limited in Athens to the improvement of individuals in private intercourse. The use of the article with qerapei/an implies that both kinds have been previously mentioned,—as is more definitely stated in the following explanation. Cf. Crat. 439 a ei) ou)=n e)/stin me
 o(/ti ma/lista di) o)noma/twn ta\ pra/gmata manqa/nein, e)/sti de\ kai\ di) au)tw=n, pote/ra a)
 ei)/h kalli/wn h( ma/qhsis.

th\n tou= diama/xesqai: cf. Apol. 29 b au(/th h( e)ponei/distos (a)maqi/a) h( tou= oi)/esqai ei)de/nai a(\ ou)k oi)=den. According to Madv. Syn. 49 a, the epexegetic gen. is usually found only with the inf.
w(s i)atro/n: see on 514 d.

h)\ w(s diakonh/sonta: the two words w(s i)atro/n have caused a shift in the construction where we should have expected (cf. 513 d) something like h)\ th\n tou= kataxari/zesqai kte(. In the answer of Callicles we have a simple verbal quotation of Socrates' words, without the speaker's troubling himself to observe any fixed construction. One might supply parakalw= se.
kolakeu/sonta: pronounces such a judgment upon diakonh/sonta that its opposition to the idea gennai=os (gennaio/tate, gennai/ws ei)pe/) is strongly emphasized.

ei)/ soi *muso/n ge kte(.: when two conditional clauses are contrasted by ei) me\n . . . ei) de\ mh/, we not infrequently find the conclusion of the first condition omitted. GMT. 482; H. 904 a. The sense of this passage seems to be: “Yes! if you prefer to use the vilest name for it.” The Mysians were so despised that even slaves brought from Mysia were as little thought of as the Sardi venales at Rome. Hence *musw=n e)/sxatos was a proverb (Theaet. 209 b to\ lego/menon *musw=n to\n e)/sxaton), meaning “the vilest of the vile.” Cic. pro Flacc. 27 Quid porro in Graeco sermone tam tritum atque celebratum est, quam si quis despicatui ducitur, ut Mysorum ultimus esse dicatur? kolakeu/ein was an unpleasant word to the Greek ear, and doubtless offended the euphemistic taste of Callicles. Cf. the English proverb, ‘to call a spade a spade.’—
w(s: see on 509 e.—This passage has troubled the editors.
o(\ polla/kis ei)/rhkas: 486 a, b, 511 b. Polus, however, had already said the same.
e)a/n ti e)/xw: to be compared with xrh/setai au)toi=s in the line below.
o(/ti a)ll' a)felo/menos: o(/ti is often used to introduce a direct quotation. For examples, see Spieker, Am. Jour. Phil. v. 220.
w(/s moi dokei=s: to be understood as a sportive exclamation. Cf. 490 e.
mhd' a)\n e(/n: see on 512 e.

diafqei/rei kai\ a)porei=n poiei=: are loosely connected with kaka\ ei)/rgastai as denoting two species of the evils complained of,—diafqei/rei the more severe treatment by te/mnwn te kai\ ka/wn,—a)porei=n poiei=, the less severe by i)sxnai/nwn kai\ pni/gwn. The latter is explained by pikro/tata kte(. and peinh=n . . . a)nagka/zwn in chiastic position. It denotes, therefore, the condition of wretchedness and discomfort brought about by fasting and nauseating medicines. While diafqei/rei reminds one of the accusation before the court, a)porei=n poiei= applies especially to the customary criticisms which were made against Socrates. See on 522 b below.

ou)x w(/sper e)gw/: a compressed expression, in which ou), though really without a verb, is connected with the following clause as equiv. to ou)k eu)wxw=n, w(/sper kte(. Cf. Symp. 179 d, e (qeoi\) e)poi/hsan to\n qa/naton au)tou= (*)orfe/ws) u(po\ gunaikw=n gene/sqai ou)x w(/sper *)axille/a . . . e)ti/mhsan kai\ ei)s maka/rwn nh/sous a)pe/pemyan. Cf. Dem. Phil. i. 34. Translate ou)x w(/sper by “whereas.”
po/son: not ti/, because the uproar would be characterized by volume rather than by distinctness.

On the other hand, evil is to be greatly feared for its consequences, both here and hereafter.” to\ a)poqnh/|skein is the “act of dying,” to\ teqna/nai, the resulting condition, death, which latter Socrates discusses in Apol. 40 c.

The distinction between lo/gos and mu=qos, which are often contrasted, is that lo/gos is said of the true and the actual; mu=qos, of the fictitious. By this distinction Socrates wishes to call attention to the fact that a truth lies at the basis of the following myth, while the dress of it is a matter of indifference,—not that he actually believes the story as it stands. gai=a d' e)/ti cunh\ pa/ntwn kai\ makro\s *)/olumpos.
Socrates commences with this passage so as to be able to assume therefrom an empire of the dead, or the existence of the soul after death, as an admitted fact which requires no proof.
para\ tou= patro\s pare/labon: by making thus the sway over the world a matter of inheritance simply, Socrates avoids the common story of hostile relations between Cronus and his sons.

h)=n ou)=n no/mos e)pi\ *kro/nou . . . e)/stin e)n qeoi=s: that is, the fundamental distinction between good and evil is also an eternal one. The addition of e)n qeoi=s is appropriate, inasmuch as the law which was in force during the reign of Cronus is made perpetual by being adopted by his successors, the gods.
kai\ a)ei\ kai\ nu=n: from that time to the present.

ei)s maka/rwn nh/sous: according to Homer, d 564, Zeus transferred his favorites (Rhadamanthys and Menelaus, the latter a son-in-law of Zeus, are especially mentioned) alive to the *)hlu/sion pedi/on, where they pass a blissful existence. The first mention of the Islands of the Blessed is found in Hesiod (e)/rga k. h(. 170), who makes them the place to which the men of the fourth race, the heroes and chieftains of the Trojan war are sent after death as their reward. The punishment, on the other hand, of the men of the second and third races is that after death they must wander in Hades (ib. 152 e)s eu)rw/enta do/mon kruerou= *)ai/dao). The myth is then further developed, and the Isles of the Blessed become gradually in the common belief, largely through Pindar's influence, the abode of all the righteous after death. Cf. Pind. Ol. II. 75 ff. (Gildersleeve).

Tartarus was originally, according to Homer, the prison of the Titans; cf. *q 13, 478. Plato alone makes it the prison of all wrong-doers. The term maka/rwn nh/sous became stereotyped very early; hence we never find the prose word makari/wn used in it.
e)n pa/sh| eu)daimoni/a|: on the omission of the art., see G. 142, 4, N. 5; H. 672 b.
tou/twn de\ dikastai/: the representation of a court of the dead, with other judges besides Pluto himself, and before the souls enter Hades, is first found in the Platonic version of the myth.

e)/ti newsti/: (still more recently, when, etc.) is contrasted with e)pi\ *kro/nou, so that tou= *dio\s . . . e)/xontos forms the explanation of it. Heindorf connects e)/ti newsti/ with e)/xontos, and translates: recente adhuc Iovis imperio. See on 503 c.

zw=ntes h)=san zw/ntwn: this pres entation is quite in harmony with the mythical form which Socrates adopts. The object is to show the contrast between a judgment which is human, uncertain, and based on external appearances, and the true one, which is based on accurate inspection of the unveiled truth. For this purpose the human tribunal is supposed in the myth to have existed first; the second tribunal is then made by Plato to arise as a substitute for the first, although naturally it must be conceived as existent ever since the creation of man. The first tribunal admits of the same criticism as the one in use among men deserves.

oi( e)pimelhtai/: who these are remains uncertain. The addition oi( e)k maka/rwn nh/swn shows that they abode there, though their functions probably extended also to Tartarus. On the attraction of the preposition, see G. 191, N. 6; H. 788 a.
e(kate/rwse: i.e. as well to Tartarus as to the Isles of the Blessed; hence a)na/cioi refers both to reward and punishment.
nu=n me\n ga\r kte(.: note the re

peated employment of ga/r, which cor
responds well to the strongly marked (repeated e)/fh) direct speech.

h)mfiesme/noi: the ‘clothing’ is to be understood in the wider sense, as everything external which would affect the estimation of a man,—i.e. beauty of person, noble origin, wealth, etc. Cf. 451 e, and Prot. 319 c ka)\n pa/nu kalo\s h)=| kai\ plou/sios kai\ tw=n gennai/wn.
e)/rxontai kte(.: here the Attic court is visible behind the myth.

pro\ th=s yuxh=s: sense-perception is, according to Plato, always untrustworthy, and hence the knowledge gained through it is always uncertain, often untrue. With that, Socrates contrasts the knowledge which is gained by the immediate and thoughtful action of the soul itself, which he represents here as soul-perception.
e)pi/prosqen gi/gnetai: “comes before them,” “puts itself in their way.” Their wrappings become a hindrance to perception of the truth.
prw=ton me\n ou)=n: introduces the preliminaries which must first be settled.

tou=to: is the condition of proei/dhsis mentioned in the previous clause. Closely connected with it is au)tw=n as a gen. of possession, such as we see occurring with qauma/zein, e.g. Phaedo 89 a e)/gwge ma/lista e)qau/masa au)tou= (in him) prw=ton me\n tou=to kte(., Apol. 17 a ma/lista au)tw=n e(\n e)qau/masa. The regular const. with both verbs is an acc. of the person with a gen. of the thing.

tw=| *promhqei=: in the Attic cult, Prometheus was honored next to Hephaestus and Athena as a bene factor of mankind. As such he bore the surname purfo/ros, under which name Sophocles celebrates him in Oedipus Coloneus, where he says of the neighborhood which Oedipus enters (O. C. 54 ff.): xw=ros me\n i(ero\s pa=s o(/d' e)st), e)/xei de/ nin | semno\s *poseidw=n h)d' o( purfo/ros qeo\s | *tita\n *promhqeu/s. Of his enmity with Zeus, which Aeschylus, following Hesiod, made the
central point of his magnificent poem, there is no mention either in Sophocles or in Plato, who also, in the Prot. 320 d, in the myth of the Gods related by the sophist, says: prose/tacan *promhqei= kai\ *)epimhqei= kosmh=sai/ te kai\ vei=mai duna/meis e)ka/stois w(s pre/pei. As a Titan he is called the son of Iapetus. —Not to be mistaken is the allusion to Aeschylus P. V. 248-251, though with a modification of the tone:

*xor. *to\ poi=on eu(rw\n th=sde fa/rmakon no/sou;

*xor. *me/g' w)fe/lhma tou=t) e)dwrh/sw brotoi=s.

a(pa/ntwn tou/twn: i.e. clothes, etc., mentioned above.

*c 321 f. Minos and Rhadamanthys were sons of Europa, and born in Crete, of which Minos was afterwards king, while Aeacus was called the son of Aegina. Minos was famed as a wise law-giver, Rhadamanthys and Aeacus for their wisdom, justice, and piety.—The Greeks of Plato's time divided the earth into two parts. Cf. Isoc. Paneg. 179 th=s gh=s a(pa/shs th=s u(po\ tw=| ko/smw| keime/nhs, di/xa tetmhme/nhs kai\ th=s me\n *)asi/as, th=s d' *eu)rw/phs kaloume/nhs. Plato must accordingly reckon Crete as belonging to Asia, unless we are to conceive that he had in mind the fact that Phoenix or Agenor, father of Phoenix and Cadmus and grandfather of Europa, was king of Phoenicia. To these three, which are also
mentioned by Dem. de Cor. (xviii.) 127, the Attic hero Triptolemus is added in Apol. 41 a.

e)n tw=| leimw=ni: Socrates is thinking of the ‘asphodel meadow’ of Hom. l 539, 573. According to Homer, it seems to have stretched through the whole of Hades, and to have been the abiding place of the shades. Cf. w 13 ai)=ya d' i(/konto kat) a)sfodelo\n leimw=na | e)/nqa te nai/ousi yuxai/, ei)/dwla kamo/ntwn. Plato places it at the entrance of Hades.

dextera quae Ditis magni sub moenia tendit,

peri\ th=s porei/as: not concerning their course on earth, but as to whether they shall take the road to Tartarus or that to the Isles of the Blessed. Cf. Phaedo 107 d e)n a)rxh=| th=s e)kei=se porei/as.

ta\ paqh/mata: in stating (above, b) the condition of the body, when separated from the soul, Socrates (Plato) uses the expression qerapeu/mata kai\ paqh/mata. Here, referring to the soul, he uses paqh/mata alone. At the basis of this variation seems to lie some such theory as the following: The human body is susceptible of improvement, by care and training; this care must be exerted by the man himself; hence qerapeu/mata are the results of this care. On the other hand, a lack of care will subject the body to the evil effect of outside evil influences, and thereby to deterioration; paqh/mata are the results of this outside influence. The soul is not susceptible of improvement, being perfect at the outset; but lack of care will, just as in the case of the body, subject the soul to the influence of outside forces. There is therefore no place for qerapeu/mata when speaking of the soul.
e)/sxen: see on 503 e, 519 d.—
e)peida\n ou)=n: Socrates resumes his story where he had broken off at the conclusion of ch. LXXIX.
oi( me\n e)k th=s *)asi/as: an example of distributive apposition. See on 450 c, 503 d. The correlative second member is simply indicated in 526 c by the words tau)ta\ de\ tau=ta kte(.
e)pisth/sas: “he halts them.” They would probably otherwise go their own way.
o(/tou e)stin: see on 447 d.
tou= mega/lou basilew/s: why just this example is chosen, is seen from what is said in 470 e.
e)pilabo/menos: see on 519 a.
katei=den: another case of ‘gnomic aorist,’ which gives a certain degree of liveliness to the recital. So ei)=den, a)pe/pemyen. See on 484 a.

ou)de\n u(gie\s o)\n kte(.: the following passage can be traced in Tac. Ann. vi. 6 neque frustra praestantissimus sapientiae firmare solitus est, si recludantur tyrannorum mentes, posse aspici laniatus et ictus, quando
ut corpora verberibus, ita saevitia, libidine, malis consultis animus dilaceretur.

diamemastigwme/nhn: after the analogy of the body, which belongs to a mastigi/as (cf. above in c). Likewise skolia\ kai\ ou)de\n eu)qu/ corresponds to diestramme/na, and kai\ . . . ei)=den may also have some connexion with paxu/s above c.

a(/: refers to both the previously named conditions; see on tau=ta above, d. Socrates shows us the immoral condition of the soul under three aspects: 1. The vital principle of morality is dikaiosu/nh, hence a)diki/a is placed first. Beside this, as its worst form, stands perjury, the punishment of which after death was assumed even in the Homeric age; cf. *g 278, T 259 *)erinu/es, ai(/ q' u(po\ gai=an | a)nqrw/pous ti/nuntai o(/ tis k' e)pi/orkon o)mo/ssh|. a)diki/a accordingly corrupts the very nature itself of the soul. 2. The natural development of the soul depends upon its knowledge of the truth. Lies restrict that development, and hence warp and twist the soul. This image at the same time corresponds to the familiar view of the nature of truth. 3. Since the activity of the soul is from within outwards, there is need of fixed, definite limits. If this quality —swfrosu/nh—is lacking, or rather if it lapses into a)kolasi/a, which according to its surrounding conditions appears as e)cousi/a, trufh/, and u(/bris (a)krati/a is a general term, applicable to all forms), then the proper relation between the separate parts of the soul is destroyed, and its form as a whole becomes unsymmetrical and ugly. One naturally thinks of the extension which the e)piqumi/ai strive for.
a)ti/mws: corresponds to the a)timi/a imposed by earthly judges.—
eu)qu\ th=s froura=s: for the gen., see G. 182, 2, and on 486 a.
LXXXI. prosh/kei kte(.: the purpose of the punishment determines also its measure. To the consideration of this point, Socrates now turns.
timwroume/nw|: the passive of the middle. See H. 499 a; Kr. 52, 10, 11.

h)\ paradei/gmati kte(.: in this
also, as is shown by what follows, the object is improvement, but of others rather than the one punished. The terror-theory is put in the mouth of the Sophist in the Protagoras, who says Prot. 324 b o( meta\ lo/gou e)pixeirw=n kola/zein ou) tou= parelhluqo/tos e(/neka a)dikh/matos timwrei=tai, a)lla\ tou= me/llontos xa/rin, i(/na mh\ au)=qis a)dikh/sh| mh/te au)to\s ou(=tos mh/te a)/llos o( tou=ton i)dw\n kolasqe/nta. Plato's theory concerning the punishments of the lower world implies, though it does not expressly mention, the doctrine of the wandering habits of souls which he expounds in other treatises. For the dat., cf. 479 e, and see G. 136, N. 3; H. 941.
fobou/menoi: because fear leads to reflection, reflection to more correct views, which result in avoidance of evil and corrupt moral habits.

w)felou/menoi/ te kai\ di/khn dido/ntes: the second partic. is logically subordinate to the first (“by undergoing”), though formally co-ordinate. See on 460 d. The correlative to oi( me
 kte(. is oi(\ d' a)
 kte(., in c, which assumes that form on account of his proximity to oi(\ a)
 i)a/sima kte(.

a)ni/atoi: since wrong-doing strikes at the very nature of the soul, the soul becomes more or less injured with every new evil deed. And indeed it may go so far in the path of wickedness as to be at last incapable of turning back; that is, it may become incurable. Cf. Phaedo 113 e oi(\ d' a)\n do/cwsin a)nia/tws e)/xein dia\ ta\ mege/qh tw=n a(marthma/twn kte(. We must note, however, that the punishment is not determined according to the evil acts as such,—these the judge may not even know,—but by the condition of the soul as brought about by them.
ta\ paradei/gmata: the art. is employed on account of the previous mention of this in b, as a result to be gained.
paradei/gmata a)nhrthme/nous: as we are accustomed to hang up warnings that the passer-by may think over them carefully.
e)n *(/aidou e)n tw=| desmwthri/w|: both expressions are placed side by side by the sxh=ma kaq' o(/lon kai\ me/ros.
qea/mata kai\ nouqeth/mata: the second substantive gives the design of the first.
*)arxe/laon: cf. 470 d-471 d.
ei)=nai . . . gegono/tas: participial periphrasis. See Kr. 56, 3, 3, and crit. note on 510 b.

dunastw=n: men possessed of power, not merely in monarchical and oligarchical, but also in democratical states; hence the addition of the explanation with kai/. Cf. 479 a, 524 e, 526 b and see on 492 b. Below (30) in the same sense we find e)k tw=n duname/nwn.

22... lang=greek>dia/ th\n e)cousi/an: cf. above, 525 a. The expression very forcibly reminds us of the representations of Polus and Callicles, when praising what they conceived to be the highest happiness.
tou/tois: “to these statements,” “to this view of the matter.”

*ta/ntalon, *si/sufon, *tituo/n: cf. Hom. l 576-600. All three were rulers: Tantalus, the founder of the house of the Pelopidae, was king in Sipylus; Sisyphus, in Corinth; Tityus, in Euboea. Thersites was a bad and despicable man, but his sphere of action was limited and he experienced rough treatment even during his lifetime; B 211-277.
e)ch=n: sc. ta\ me/gista kai\ a)nosiw/tata a(marth/mata a(marta/nein. This was the reason why Thersites was not held to be a)ni/atos.
eu)daimone/steros: Socrates here expresses himself with less exactness than in 473 c.

a)lla\ ga/r: for, you see. The clause thus introduced serves a two-fold purpose. It expresses more plainly and definitely what had already been implied above, and it paves the way, by the words kai\ oi( sfo/dra ponhroi/, for the new thought which begins with ou)de\ mh/n.
kai/: “also.” Is closely connected with tw=n duname/nwn.

a)/gasqai tw=n gignome/nwn: cf. 482 d ou)k a)/gamai *pw=lon. The acc. is rare and states simply the obj.; the gen. gives the cause, and may be a person or a thing. With the person is generally found either a participial or an adverbial clause. See H. 784.
gignome/nwn: after e)ggi/gnesqai, as Crito 44 d e)rga/zesqai after e)cerga/zesqai, is quite in accordance with the customary usage.

xalepo\n ga/r: in our admiration for the ‘self-made’ man we forget that he has had every incentive to rise, while we withhold our sympathy from fallen greatness, which has had every temptation to fall.

o)li/goi: as also oi( sfo/dra ponhroi/. The most stand in the mean, according to Phaedo 90 a, b oi)/ei ti spaniw/teron ei)=nai h)\ sfo/dra me/gan h)\ sfo/dra smikro
 e)ceurei=n a)/nqrwpon h)\ ku/na h)\ a)/llo o(tiou=n; h)\ au)= ai)sxro

 kte(.;
th\n tou= diaxeiri/zein: notice the epexegetic gen. See on 521 a.

a(\ . . . e)pitre/ph|: sc. power or property, or whatever it be. Plato is probably thinking of Aristides' position as general of the confederate army during the war against the Persians and as one of the founders of the Delian league, by which especially he gained his reputation for probity. Cf. Plut. Arist. especially ch. XXIII.-XXV. The kai/ before ei)s has almost the force of “and that, too.”
LXXXII. o(/per ou)=n e)/legon: goes back to 524 e.
ou)/q' o(/stis kte(.: sc. as was the case in life, when the name of the man was followed by the name of his father to indicate his family.

e)pishmhna/menos: in accordance with the results of his scrutiny, the judge puts upon him a mark and thus decides his fate. Cf. Rep. x. 614 c shmei=a peria/yantas tw=n dedikasme/nwn, —also of the judges of the dead.

a)/llhn kte(.: the omission of yuxh/n is so harsh that Heindorf inserts it—but unnecessarily—after h)\ a)/llou tino/s. These latter words form with what follows (ma/lista me/n instead of h)/, “whether philosopher or not, but especially,” etc.) an explanatory apposition to the general idea, i)diw/tou.
met' a)lhqei/as: cf. the opposite description in 525 a above.

ta\ au(tou= pra/cantos: ‘to attend to one's own business,’ was for a Greek to be both sw/frwn and di/kaios. That this did not, however, exclude him from taking interest in other people's lives is shown by Socrates' words in Apol. 33 a ta\ e)mautou= pra/ttontos. The contrary of this phrase is poluprag- monei=n, “to meddle officiously with, and to attack unreasonably the rights of others.” Cf. Apol. 31 c.

r(a/bdon e)/xwn: the staff was the badge of public authority, and was borne by heralds, seers, priests, generals, and others, but especially by judges. Cf. Dem. de Cor. (xviii.) 210 kai\ paralamba/nein ge a(/ma th=| bakthri/a| kai\ tw=| sumbo/lw| to\ fro/nhma to\ th=s po/lews nomi/zein e(/kaston u(mw=n dei=. Also skh=ptron (from skh/ptesqai, to lean on, r 199) had originally this value; i.e. A 234 ff., b 37, but became later the name for the badge of a ruler alone.
The quotation is from Hom. Od. 11.569.
a)pofanou=mai: the simple fanou=mai is always middle, in the sense “appear”; the compound a)po- is almost always transitive or active in sense, “present,” “show.”
a)ntiparakalw=: with reference to 521 a and 485 e ff.

to\n a)gw=na: brings up before us at once the public games, at which a prize was awarded. The name is quite applicable to the progress of human life, which is really a contest between different systems as practised by different men. Cf. the passage from Phaedo quoted on 527 e. But a judicial trial was also called a)gw/n, and such a one awaits every man at the last judgment. Cf. Apol. 34 c ei) o( me\n kai\ e)la/ttw toutoui\ tou= a)gw=nos a)gw=na a)gwnizo/menos e)deh/qh.

o(/ti ou)x oi(=o/s t' e)/sei kte(.: corresponds closely to the objections urged by Callicles in 486 a, b, nu=n ga\r ei)/ tis sou= labo/menos kte(. In what follows, the words kai\ e)pi\ ko/rrhs express even an augmentation of the insult.

LXXXIII. w(/sper grao/s: cf. the proverb o( lego/menos graw=n u(/qlos Theaet. 176 b. So also in Latin, German, and English. Cf. Hor. Sat. ii. 6. 77 Cervius haec inter vicinus garrit anilis | ex re fabellas.

a)lhqe/stera: of course in comparison with other views which can show less claim to truth. Cf. 493 d. Grades of truth are conceivable as steps in that approximation to the perfect truth which abides with God. This approximation is nothing more or less than knowledge, which has the stronger claim to be considered truth the better foundation it has.

sofw/tatoi/ e)ste: such (ironi
cal) flattery was submitted to by the Sophists the more easily since modesty did not prevent them from applying this epithet to themselves. Cf. Prot. 337 d, where Hippias says h(ma=s ou)=n ai)sxro
 th

 fu/sin tw=n pragma/twn ei)de/nai, sofwta/tous de\ o)/ntas tw=n *(ellh/nwn kte(.
e)kei=se: like e)kei=, of life beyond the grave; opposed to e)nqa/de 525 b. The terminus in quem is used, inasmuch as the effect is meant, which reaches even to the beyond.
h)remei=: “stands fast and immovable against all attacks.”

ou) to\ dokei=n kte(.: as Aeschylus makes the messenger of Amphiaraus say in Sept. c. Theb. 592 ou) ga\r dokei=n a)/ristos a)ll' ei)=nai qe/lei. These words, as is well known, were applied by the Athenians to Aristides. Plut. Arist. iii. end The two modes of life discussed admit of distinction according to appearance and reality.
to\ gi/gnesqai: sc. di/kaion.
e)pi\ to\ di/kaion: epexegetic to ou(/tw.
e)moi\ ou)=n peiqo/menos: begins the conclusion, which is peculiarly pathetic.

e)ntau=qa: “in the direction of the attainment of our own perfection.” See on e)kei=se above in b. Cf. Apol. 36 c e)ntau=qa ou)k h)=|a, oi(= e)lqw\n mh/te u(mi=n mh/te e)mautw=| e)/mellon mhde\n u)/felos ei)=nai. For the adverb of ‘place where’ with a verb of motion, see on 456 b.
w(s . . . shmai/nei: cf. 511 b.

su/ ge qarrw=n: thrown in with emphasis, because what follows in
flicts the deepest disgrace, pata/cai. With pata/cai the repetition in thought of e)/aso/n tina is the easiest construction. On the common object of the three infs., see on 493 c soi/.
th\n a)/timon tau/thn kte(.: says Socrates, with reference to 527 a and 486 c.
ou)de\n ga\r deino\n pei/sei: external rough treatment will not affect the real man.
ka)/peita: refers to a)skw=n, but it is more exactly defined by ou(/tw . . . a)skh/santes.
to/te h)/dh: emphatic position. The addition e)a\n dokh=| xrh=nai indicates that they may then find something more important to do.
e)piqhso/meqa kte(.: cf. 521 d. This is the answer to Callicles' advice in 484 c ff. On the other hand, o(poi=on a)/n ti u(mi=n dokh=| can serve for Polus. Cf. 466 c ff.
to/te: explained by belti/ous kte(.
w(s . . . e)/xein: a polite expression which can hardly be misunderstood by those present.
a)paideusi/as: in contrast to the paidei/a on which Callicles and Polus prided themselves. See on 461 b, c.
w(/sper ou)=n h(gemo/ni: the lo/gos is treated as a living being, to whose guidance one can trust himself. It is the principle from which all other moral regulations proceed.
ou(=tos: finds its explanation in kai\ . . . teqna/nai.

34 f. For the conclusion, cf. Phaedo 114 c a)lla\ tou/twn dh\ e(/neka xrh\ w(=n dielhlu/qamen pa=n poiei=n, w(/ste a)reth=s kai\ fronh/sews e)n tw=| bi/w| metasxei=n: kalo\n ga\r to\ a)=qlon kai\ h( e)lpi\s mega/lh.
